libro de motu cordis ¶yet soule chap 3 soule vnbodilye substaunce intellectuall receiueth lyght first last relation definition know first cheife propertie soule man spirit receiueth lyght god next angells also soule defined two manner ioyned bodie two manner vnderstand mouer thing moued also shipman setteled shippe thereto according remigius defineth soule manner soule bodilesse substance ruling bodie saint austen booke de anima et spiritu saith manner soule certeine substaunce partener reason betaken bodie shall ruled definition propertie taken soule certeine necessitie loue gouernaunce kindly giuen ruling bodie ioyned thereto héereby appeareth soule streighted neither spread length neither bredth bodie ruleth gouerneth vertue soule body ruled moued calcidius putteth example commento super thimeum spider sitteth middle web féeleth manner mouing toucheth webbe either within without soule abiding middle heart without spreading selfe giueth lyfe bodie gouerneth ruleth mouing luns compared body ioyned vnto forme perfection defined philosopher lib de anima manner soule endelichia first act perfection kindly bodie hath lims might haue life definition manifest though soule ioyned bodie may fastened manner bodyes onely kindly bodie hath lummes first kindlye disposed receiue reasonable soule also ye soule spirit defined foure manner waye • first comparison creature generally booke de anima spiritu austen saith manner soule made likenesse wisdome beareth selfe liknesse thing like earth essentia water imagination aire reason firmament vnderstanding knowledge heauenly ioyes sixt manner defined comparison god maker thus soule like god quickening lyfe héereby knowe soule begotten father mother compound created god liuing bodie also seauenth manner described comparison god end made thus soule spirit intellectuall ordeined blisse selfe héereof shineth propertye soule meane soule béeing departed body onely beautified angelles angell felicitie thereof inlarged bodie glorified iohannis damascene homel 26 comprehendeth difference definition vnder generall discription sayth soule substaunce liuing simple bodilesse kinde vnléene bodilye eyen neyther shall die reasonable vnderstanding without shape limmes vseth bodie giueth thereto heart lyfe growing begetting hath none vnderstanding selfe pure cleane eye bodie intellect vnderstanding soule hath frée aduisement chaungeable couenable maye fréelye take eyther refuse spirit taketh grace made hée hath béeing •• kinde hetherto speaketh iohn damascene bernard describeth right property saith thou soule beautified made fayre image lykenesse god spoused spirit faith bought christ owne bloud assisted angells pertaker blisse heyre saluation partener reason hast thou doe flesh thou sufferest much many diuerse definions description diuerse sundrie property soule knowen touching béeing kinde grace ¶how soule philosopher described chap 4 thing soule vnknowen many men matter wée reade olde philosopher gaue diuerse contrarie determination liber de anima aristotle rehearseth plato sayde soule béeing mouing selfe zeno sayth soule number moueth selfe pythagoras calleth soule harmonie concord melodie paphinons calleth idea manner example asolepides calleth manner corde setteth fiue wittes worke hipocras calleth subtile spirite spread bodie eraclius philosopher calleth soule lyght sparcle béeing democritus calleth vncerteine spirit athomis little thing meates sunne beame hée sayth bodye soule lyttle thing permenides saith made earth fire epicurus sayth soule manner kinde fire ayre ipertus saith soule firye strength iuxta illud igneus est illis vigor et coelestis origo sith wise men haue spoken many wayes diuersely soule time onelye shall suffice sayde holy men soule manner spiritual reasonable substaunce god maketh naught giue lyfe perfection man body substaunce maye receyue contraryes receiueth vnderstanding yet subiect forgetting vertue mallice without chaunging léesing substaunce bodilesse spread length neither breadth bodily wit inasmuch simple kinde therfore may grow ware neither neyther lesse one time therefore greater bodye greater lesser bodie lesser sayeth austen also though bée simple chaungeable substaunce yet hath many sundry might vertue multitude might vertue maketh neither ne lesse kinde multitude might vertue belongeth dooinges effect hée thrée vertues one neither lesse one thrée thus known ye soule hath many propertyes definition touching thing soule condition soule shall bée cléerelye knowne setting name ¶how soule tooke name gentile chap 5 isidore sayeth anima soule named gentile opinion winde breath drawing ayre mouth séeme liue opinion openlye falsée soule put bodye long ayre bée taken mouth liueth béeing mother wombe lorde maketh soule putteth therein called soule liueth giueth lyfe bodie put called spirit hath selfe spirituall animall kindlye lyfe maketh bodye spirare breath also thing anima animus anima leadeth lyfe reason animus counsaile guiding therefore philosopher saye anima lyfe abideth animus counsaile also anima soule called men minde app • areth aboue head mindeth soule man image god also many name soule bée coupled together oftentimes one name put another soule one called diuerse name diuerse respectes called anima bodye giueth lyfe men whilest hath minde animus whilest hath racio déemeth iudgeth rightfully spiritus breatheth sensus féeleth propertyes soule cunning qualytie soule called sciencia hath name sensus féeling hetherto speaketh isidore liber 15 chap 14 ¶of power soule first instrument lymme hearing needeth soule take heede foras vvhe man spoken vnto mind basied another way vnderstandeth vvhat spoken long thoughtful intendeth diuers thing lesse mightie doe deed vertue hearing sée many beset welnigh heare nothing thought taketh héed therfore nothing perceiued hearing hearing made manner two sinewes come inner part brayne fastened gristle bone eare sinewes hearing middle rounde head arist saith li 12 ye hearing manner winding taketh aire smit straight forthright also wit like wit grieued destroyed great noyse pleased preserued temperate sowndes wherefore examiron ambrose sayth men country riuer nylus ariseth voyd hearing horrible roaring noyse riuer falling downe top high hill smiteth eares men countrey maketh astonied deafe wit wit haue hath ofte many griefes sometime lost called deafenesse somtime diminished called heauinesse hearing sometime passeth course cause griefe commeth sometime default brayne sinewe waye hearing sinew stopped grieued euill letteth office thereof also default eares sometime corrupt grieued diuers humor sometime rotten filththerein stoppeth hollownes thereof sometime grauell powder falleth therein letteth passage aire may come spirite hearing sometime sinewes hearing grieued itching fretting wormes sometime instrument lyms hearing infected grieued corrupt ayre hot colde sometime let winde great ventositie closed pore ye sinewes hearing appereth séeme heare pipe horne belle thing hearing diminished lost shall sayd treatise eares ¶of smelling cap 19 olsactuthe wit smellyng perceiueth knoweth smelles make wit perfect spirite animalis néedfull cause efficiens dooing néedeth haue lymme expedient wit perfect disposition nosethrills small péeces flesh hanging downewarde shapen teates proper lymmes smellyng receiue spirite animalis certaine sinewes come downewarde brayne nosethrills properly ye instrument smellyng gristly therefore insensible appeareth yt haue nosethrills cut away though animal putteth property bloude saith euery beast hath bloud hath lyuer heart therfore euerye beast hath bloud lesse bodie vertue beastes haue bloud flesh cut bloud runneth except flesh dead corrupt also euery beast good disposition temperate bloud much drinke new wine neither lyttle fat body beast fat body haue lyttle bloud fatnesse wareth bloud diminisheth also euery body sanguine rotteth soone speciallye nigh bone man hath verye subtill bloud respect beast beast haue blacker bloud thicker man bloud namelye bull ass nether part body bloud thicker blacker ouer part also bloud bréedeth great quantitie cause sicknesse commeth thinne made watry therefore perchaunce man sweateth bloud suppose much superfluitye thin bloud kinde thinketh discharge superfluitie throweth watry part vttermost skinne auoydeth sweating also man sléepeth lyttle bloud appereth wonder kinde draweth inward helpe vnkindly vertue ye benefite thereof may doe hir workes bloud farre within vtter partes bodye pale bloudlesse therefore sléeping body cut sticked commeth much bloud waking sayd bloud sodde distilled thereof may make fallowe greace perchaunce vnctuo •• ye thereof temperate seething crudded beeing white tourned tallowe faite also bloud altered course kinde corrupt goe stomacke nosethrilles also blouds rotteth anye member taken skill kinde tourneth venyine scaba hetherto speaketh constantine lib 3 lib 12 saith veynes vessells bloud thereof followeth bloud last meat beastes haue bloud also bloud friend nature beast hath bloud fedde thing accordeth bloud séene flyes wormes sit flesh sucke bloud take thereof féeding beast fed meate leane euill disposition fed therewith wareth good disposition effect foode meate bloud ye meate made clérre good body whole euill body sicke also default moystureas vvhen man great heate ouer much drink danteth povvers likevvise horse vvhose grease molte colde vvater suffocateth choked earthly bloud congea • ̄th hastely soone therefore euery beast yt hath subtill bloud cleane hot hath better wit beast cleane bloud subtill hot mouing according wit derstanding also beast yt hath bloud fearfull beast hath bloud therefore hée hath cleane bloud hot lyght little moued dread also yt bloud bull congealeth cruddeth ••• itily ye bloud beast bloud beastes congealeth lesse except bloud hart hare beast lyke yt bloud congealeth aristotle saith lib 3 se • 2 bloud bull cruddeth swiftly excesse heate drinesse bull bloud dronken rawe slayeth venyme sayd philosopher dranke ye bloud bull slew himselfethemistocles athens also aristotle li 33 saith bloud hotter ye right side lefte side therfore strength hot bloud side right hand generally ready able worke lefte hand therfore liber primus aristotle saith lion mooueth right foote lefte super aphoris saide woman childe masculine sodainelye called moueth first right footeagility vvoman proceedeth hot bloude worketh sull hir conceiueth male childe also eodem li sayd bloud first principall matter heart lyuer therefore heart hollowe receiue bloud thicke saue kéepe bloud member bloud without veynes heart onely bloud goeth heart certaine veynes place body bloud commeth place heart heart wel dissolue commentator saith viatico tractatu de pannicul macul oculorum fine ¶of euill propertie bloud cap 8 property bloud lesse praise foresaid property much bloud well disposed friendlye profitable nature much corrupt hurtfull thereto causeth grieous sicknesse body mallice humour medled bloud sodainly felt hid friendship bloud hath kinde therefore kinde ware mallice humor hid vnder ye friendship bloud kinde dreadeth griefe humour hid fareth feauers called hemitritaeon hemitritaeō tercian veting leuer medled red burnt cholar medled bloud soone knowen kind phisitions galen saith super aphorls also ther superfluous bloud ye body breedeth wonderful euills men except ye sooner voyded kinde phisicke fareth bloud called sanguis menstrualis bloud womē great moysture default heate holden beyond due time cause occasion full great griefes sickenesse sometime stiffeleth ye principall member sometime causeth dropsie sometime phrensie open disease corrupt bloud long held shut sent forth diuers place bodye plavnly contayned lib palsionarum galen therfore peril best remedy voyd corrupt bloud quickly meruayle bloud thus corrupted grieue bodye seeing also chaungeth wonderfully inserteth bodyesmēstruall bloud poyson lib 10 cap 12 isidore saith touch bloud menstruall fruite groweth dryeth burnt hearbes dye tree loose fruite yron fret rust brasse mettall wareth blacke hound eate thereof ware mad thing called glutinum aspalti hard yt may delaide water fire yt bloud menstrualis touch glutinum aspalti falleth isidore saith bloud bred woman bodyes superfluitie moysture féeblenesse heate therefore shuld grieue kind gendred mother poumpe expulsed put due manner cleanseth caseth body mother disposeth maketh able conceiue therefore aristotle saith lib 9 menstrum fine mensis mulieribus maxime viget et ideo tune vtiliter expellitur sanguis talis quia sicut dicit isid lib 16 sanguis menstrualis non habet certam temporis reuolutionem sed maiore parte accedit diminutione lunae hoc est rectum quia corpus animaliū sunt tune temporis frigidiora alteratur sanguis efficitur ex eo superfluitas menstrualis quae si tune expellitur talis euacuatio laudabilis est naturalis quia si vitra tempus vel propter grossiciem sanguinis vel propter altitudinem matricis vel propter defectum expulsiue virtutis retincatur multis molestijs periculosis corpus mulieris aggrauatur quod quidem geueraliser est verum quarto decimo anno v que ad quinquagenum quia iuuenculis meatus sunt angusti virtu debilis quinquagelimo veroanno antea sanguis minoratur fi • gescie calor destiuit tepescit vnde istae duae aetates talus immundicia sunt immune scilicet senectus vetularis iuuentus puellaris retmet ramen natura sanguinem menstrualem post mulierum impregnationem ad nutrimentum foetus conceptus conseruationem vnde arist li 15 menstrum est fanguis non purus sed indiget digestione operatiua hic sanguis mixtus cum spermate cibus est animali vnde mulier post conceptionem frequenter patiens fluxum menstrualem solet facere abortiuum aut enim debiliatur foetus aut moritur hoc propter nutrimenti subtractionem vnde retentio sanguinis menstrualis signum est impregnationis ex iam dictum causa quod autem superfluit de sanguine menstruali detrahitur ad mammilla vt inde lac generatur materia enim lactis est sanguis decoctus mammillis vt dicit aristo lib 16 18 lac inquit est sanguis digestus non corruptus item oportet vt fluxus sanguinis menstrualis actualiter sit corpore antequā muher impregnetur sicut dicit aristo li 15 con sicut oportet arborē primo florere quā fructus facere item quodo venit talis fluxus naturaliter semper accidit aetate lunae aetati etiam mulieris conuenenti item aues animalia non patiuntur talem fluxum quia talis superfluitas transit plumas pilos vt dicit arist itē dicit ruffus mulieres nimis se exercentes sepius mouentes non multū menstruant sed quae quiescunt multū comedunt suauiter que viuunt tale multa purgatione indigent item quando sanguis talis vel frigidare vel crassirie os venarum constrinengte debito modo non exit ad exeundum alias vias querit vt vena nariu • u emorroidarum quas si clausas inuenerit ad alia membra se diffundit grauem naturae infert passionem nam tale vt dicit viatico const defectum appetitus patiuntur nam cibaria bona abhorrent puluerem vero carbonum laterum appetunt similium nam sanguis retentus maliciosum fumuin terrestrem ponticum conuertitur quo rapto ad orificium stomachi appetitus rationalis subuertitur irrationalis generatur vnde omnia talia corpus sunt maximis morbis apparata ¶of fleame cap 9 ihohannicus saith •• eame humour halfe sedde working vnperfect heate colde matter moyst kinde gendred aristotle lib 15 saith fleame vndissolued superfluitie meate ye matter bloud fleame bée diuers seething lesse fleame made bloud strēgth working heate returning bloud tourneth neuer fleame cholar chaungeth melancholy againward saith auicen fleme humour kindlye colde moyst wearish kinde sendeth humor member lymmes made pure body nourished humour defied note fleme vnkindly kindly kindly fleame colde moyst white color fléeting substance sauour somewhat swéete tast eyther wearish vnsauourie bred lyuer place heate apte tourned chaunged bloude chaunge full made body sustayned thereby though fleame selfe thicke vnsauery strength heate chaungeth yet taketh lyknesse sauour bloude swéete appeareth fleame called swéete fleame néerenesse lykenesse fleame hath bloud fleame néedefull lymmes bodye therfore prouident kinde made fleame passe bloude veynes bodye néede profite constantine sayeth bloud fayleth heate dissolueth fleame taketh héede féede member lymmes thereby fleame nobler cholera melancholia may ruled bréeding bloude benefite bloude lymmes bodye preuayle bee fedde also presence fleame néedfull bloud yt feruour strength bloud may tempered fléeting fleame thicknes bloud may kept temper yt bloud may borne feeding member lyghtly speedelye also fleame profitable make moyst ioynts moueable partes moysture therof ioynts part let theyr office heate mouing neyther hot bloud neither dr • nesse might fall ther • ome • anne vnkindly fleames sower colde drye minglyng melancholy salte hot drye infection red cholera swéete meddlyng bloud glassie called lykenesse coulour glasse fleame far heat therefore thicker manner flemes harder dissolue turn bloud humor corrupt bredeth diuers sickness ye body ye superfluitie fleme knowenthe flegmatike constantine saith diuers token fleumaticke man body vnlastie heauie slow dull wit thought forgetfull softe flesh quauie coulour white face fearfull heart full spitting • euelyng rooking full sloth sleeping lyttle appetite lyttle thirst fleame salt medlyng hot humour salt sauour felt mouth soft yeolow straight haire soft great slowe pulse vrine white thicke raw euill coloured stature hée fat great short crooked extremity skin playn smooth without ha •• e dreameth hath sodain appearance great moyst ¶of cholar cap 10 isidore saith cholera sayde cholarick humor calor heate passeth temperance cholera kindly vnkindly naturall cholar kindly hot drye subtill substaunce cléere red color bitter sauor certain sharpnesse hotter redder colour ye bitter dealed two part one passeth forth bloud sent vnto chest gall goeth bloud entermixeth bloud necessitie helpe needful mingled bloud make tēper feede ye cholarick member ye bloud needeth yt red cholera indéede due proportion th • se member also cholera helpeth maketh bloud subtill may passe • lyghtly straight wayes fade inner part body parte cholera drawen • ybet gall sent thereto neede helpe néedfull clensing bodye feeding gall also helpe stomacke heate bowells pricke may discharge superfluity therefore falleth gnawing passion coli •• waye stopped betwéene gall bowel unkindly cholar commeth strong humour medled therewith redde cholera mingled watrie fleame bred cit • na cholera lesse h • noyfull cholars fleame great thicke bread red yeolow cholar two manner choler notable thirde manner cholera called prassiua virida gréene colour bitter sharpe hearbe named marubium horehoūd blacke archangel • seagirdle 〈…〉 blade faci porrus latine manner cholera bred stomacke thē vse continually rate hot heart léekes onyons garlyke kinde happen cholar taketh strength greene hearbs rawe colour seemed galen auicen noteth praxina gē dred yeolow cholar ouerburnt burned burning bréedeth blacknesse therein blacknesse medled citrine gréene colour gendred fourth manner cholera called erugmosa rastie bred cholera named prassina burning burnt moysture thereof dryed draweth whitenes ashen colour moyst bodye heate bréedeth first blacknesse moysture destroyed bréedeth manner whitenesse fareth trées wood burning first turne coales ash colde contrariwise moyst body bréedeth whitenesse drye body blacknesse last manner choler worse venemous venemous qualytie whereof bréedeth body euill passion pestilence death herisipila noli tangere c kindly cholera passe ye bound kinde maketh humour subtill comforteth digestion cleanseth congealings corruption maketh body stretch length breadth thicknesse bréedeth boldnes hardinesse mouing lyghtnesse stirreth wrath desire reuenge also prouoketh ye work venus helpeth vertue expulsiue cléereth thicke matter maketh mooue middle vtter part chaungeth vtter partes coulour citrine blacke cholaricke men generally wrathful hardie vnméeke light vnstable vnmercifull body long slender leane colour brown haire black crispe hard stiffe touch hotte pulse strong swifte vryne thin substaunce cholar spice thereof sufficeth ¶of melancholy cap 11 melancholy humour boystous thicke bred troubled congealyngs bloud hath name melon blacke calor humoure wherevpon called melancholia blacke humour phisitions • cholera nigra blacke cholar coulour thereof declineth toward blacknes melancholy kindlye vnkindly kindly melancholy colde drye bred bloud lées wine substance wherof thicke earthy sauour therof betwéene swéete • ower brackish manner melancholy diuided two partes one abideth bloud setteleth therewith member neede helpe néedeth meddeled bloude make bloude apte couenable féede place head excellent place bodie braine white kinde receiue lykenesse coulour hath much spirit haue much mouing therein also hath much marrow temper slake sharpnesse heat bread commeth moouing hath little bloud least infected smitten coulour therof thing apprehended séeme redde also moist without bloud may soone chaunged likened kinde féeling sayth constantine diuided thrée celles den braine hath thrée hollowe place phisitions call ventriculos small wombes formost cell wombe imagination conformed made middle reason hindermost recordation minde formost called prora latine fore shippe hindermost called puppis ship puppis hinder part lesse part fewe sinewes come thereof puppis hard sinewes mouing may moue easilier sooner colde drie hath little spirit marrowe colde holde better sooner hath litle spirit bréeding rest hath little marrowe comparison formost parte meanely harde printing shape likenesse therin longer holden prora formost part soft hotter floating sinewes feeling may come thereof soft sinewes féeling may disposed receiue sooner féeling hotter bée able receiue shape forme fléeting moyst somewhat sinewe féeling easilyer moned cell wombe middle betwéene prora puppis hot moyst hath spirit marrow spirit perfect discreation made therein reason member digestion cleane pure departed vncleane vnpure hath much spirit haue much moouing much marrow temper moouing imagination dome made last dome reason shape likenesse sent cell wombe puppis betaken vertue minde braine round able receiue spirit also bée lightly hurt defend braine two garment bée néedfull called mother braine one great called hard mother set vnder skull middle braine waxeth greate sadde haue strength ioyned skull departed therefrom beclippeth braine harde mother néedfull defende milde mother tender hardnesse skull binde togethers vaines organe concauite braine also fulfill voide place second web skinne called pia mater méeke mother set vnder hard mother ne • softer hard mother compasseth substance braine departeth asunder foresayd cell milde mother superfluous neither much harboureth holdeth togethers veines braine within kéepeth knitteth braine togethers flow neither faile ye fléeting softnesse thereof also milde mother helpeth beclippeth braine defendeth harde mother also vaines hath nourisheth braine organe small vaines conteineth sendeth spirit thereto also braine member moouing ruling lower member bodie giueth limmes féeling mouing braine let body let braine well bodye better disposed also braine hath property • éeleth followeth mouing moone waring moone braine wareth waneth substaunce vertue waning moone braine gathereth togethers selfe fully obedient spirit feeling séene lunatike epalentike men bée gréeued moone newe also olde aristotle saith liber 12 signes good bad braine braine sayth drie either moist doth worke déed maketh bodie colde melteth spirite therfore falleth sicknes loosing wit vnderstanding dyeth last also beastes haue greate braine bée full slouthfull happeneth reason moisture resolved commeth thereof changeth smoake stoppeth vaines braine causeth sléepe also aristotle sayth place braine hath selfe feeling touching bloud superfluity animal hath féeling touch body al beast ye preseruation kinde wonder yt braine giueth feeling part body notwithstanding selfe selfe feeleth nothing also saith place euery beast hath bloud hath braine membe stéed braine beast many féete lyke thereto though euery beast hath bloud hath braine yet braine conteineth bloud substaunce marrow aristotle sayth liber 3 also liber 16 aristotle saith substance braine colde moyst therefore set afore well heate beast wit heart moysture temper superfluitie heat drinesse arterves small vaines cau • ye braine wone haly sayth artery small vaines come heart yt made meruailous cause braine wound wrapped cau • e spirit féeling laied ruled spirit vertues braine passe mē bers therefore aristotle sayth braine first member making beast making heart galen saith braine well complectioned ought tēperate foure quality haly sayth kindlye complection braine ought bee colde moyst hot dry néedfull coole foresaid cau • e • ake accidentall heate braine commeth continuall moouing thereof alsō liber 15 aristotle saith among beastes quantitie onely man hath braine heart hotte therefore masterye heate good complection man good wit vnderstanding beast child may long hold vp head greatnesse heauinesse braine till made lighter heate heart arteryes organe good disposition braine euill knowne deedes substaunce braine soft thinne cléere receiueth lightly féeling printing shape lykenesses thinges hath braine swift good perseueraunce teaching contrarye braine softe eyther troubled hath braine receiueth slowly féeling printing thinges neuerthelesse hée hath taken receiued keepeth long minde signe token drinesse sluxibility forgetting token moisture haly sayth vnderstand quality token hotte braine dry ensample man bée busie mooueable vsage vnstable variable hardy wrathfull seemeth one hath hot braine contrarye betokeneth coldnesse braine sluggard slowe sorrowfull sleepie cold braine moyst token moyst braine likewise great waker strong minde signifieth drinesse braine dry brain passing great moysture heate ther much superfluitie many disease chaunce ye head hot moist moist braine heat distempered grieue one namely southerne ayre northerne winde helpeth one sléepie maye wake long time sléepeth happeneth haue subeth false restvnkindly rest hath troubled sight vncléere wit drinesse increaseth heat ther falleth commeth worse synthomata euills sickness sauing bée many superfluity haue wittes sufficiently cléere cleane superfluity wake • men hardie great boaster vaine speaker vnstable waxe bald youth though haue much hayre afore also cold passeth drinesse bée wont haue cléere wit cleane wayes superfluity youth vtterlye without sicknes age cōmeth waxe feeble light cause olde age commeth swiftly appeareth soone ye head haue soone hoare haires drinesse stronger colde hoarinesse waxe balde cold stronger ye drines waxe bald ye cold passeth moisture cōmeth deep sléepe wit men euil ther much superfluitie colde either moysture waxeth strong man falleth apoplexiam euill withdraweth man minde mouing féeling else hée falleth palsie eyther dieth disposed shall bald galen saith tegni comment halye sayth sufficeth spoken property head braine ¶of caluaria chap 4 caluaria formost parte skullcalua skinne hath name caluaria balde bone default haire called vertex vertex toppe crown ye head also liber decimo cap secundo isidore sayth vertex part head without haire kit haire woundē occiput powle ye hinder part ye head set capitium formost parte ye head waxeth soone bald drines therof ouer part latter powle last neuer superfluitie humour property haire seeke within eyen chap 5 libro 10 chap 1 isidore sayth oculus eyen bée sayde hidde liddes couer hide griefe come hurt else called haue light secretly hid within among wittes eyen bée next soule eyen iudgement soule eyen séene knowne disturbaunce gladnesse soule also loue wrath passion bée called lyghts receiue light without conuey send forth eye bée instrumentes sight constantine saith bée two least happe one diseased might supplye lacke thereof eie steede write spie kinde setteth highest place bodye eye made tenne thing seauen smal curtils thrée humour among humour first whitish second cristaline thirde glassie seauen curtills bée seauen skinnes either webbes beclippe foresayde humour diuideth sunder middle humour sight formed kinde ordinate togethers foure bée formost parte first called tela aranea webbe spider second vuea • grapic third cornea hornie fourth coniunctiua able ioyne thrée bée inner part three bée called rethina • derina • th •• tica hard shall bée shewed héereafter among one alone instrument sight humour cristalline hath name cristall lyke christall coulour humour christallinus constāntine sayth white bright cléere plaine without set middle shoulde serue euenly passable cléere bright may sooner bée chaunged coulours opposite haue take lykenesse coulours indifferently also round shape substaunce bée lightly h •• rt grieued also superfluitie gathered ye corner thereof superfluitie might happely bée grieued shoulde much moueable much roundnesse somewhat plaine measurable swiftnesse euery thing round hurt side vnstable vnsteadfast constantine saith humour sight made thus proued ought bée closed betweene humour spirite fight humour thing working dooing sight away faileth spirite sight may pearce come therto sor let betwéene humour springeth ouermost part braine pure thinne bright letteth passing light properly speake blacke eie called middle eye point eie therin porperly vertue sight seeing wherin vnto v beholding néere appeare certeine image mirrour thereof shall speake heereafter humour set middle two betwéene glasse white glassie humor cleane pure bright glasse ye may see called gelados ye language arabia helpeth two manner first principally taketh bloud nourish humour cristalline maketh white able turne soone substance humour cristalline conuenient cleane pure humour receiue vnpure feeding doe ye red bloud defied whited made subtill occasion medled wt humor cristalline second wise helpeth defendeth kéepeth humour christalline frō touching sharpnesse tunicles respect thereof hard boistous likewise humour called albugineus another name called euagaidos ye part helpeth cristalline two manner saueth hurting grieuing moisture tempereth christalline humour albugineus • yen moist christalline yt called also christallidos drie also humour albugineus thicknesse gathereth togethers comforteth spirit sight thrée part ye eie though •• called humour yet properly humor soft fléeting humour haue much thicknes themselues humour haue also liuing body haue kindly vertues long humor yet called humour haue softnes cleerenesse mēbers ye body obedient working ye spirit vertue féeling thē lims féeling three humor departed sunder ye rumes inner vtter shuld medled togethers seuen curtils ordeined manner fast ye humor christalline neather side ye curtel called rethina rume springeth commeth vaines hollownesse skinne called ye middle mother manner web • aul beareth feeding humor vitreus sendeth feeling ye sinewes thereof christalline next rethina immediatly followeth ye second curtel bread commeth middle mother feeddeth defendeth ye curtel rethina hap broke hurt third curtel followeth called sclirotica yt ful hard commeth hard mother braine defendeth hardnesse bone bend eie formost part next christalline humor immediatly curtel called tela aranea called subtilnesse therof may passable spirit bread commeth subtill part curtill called rethina curtil set betwéene christalline humour albugineus kéepeth fret togethers curtil tela aranea ioyned inner part rethina maketh ye first roundnes two curtills close humor christalline within followeth curtill called vuea grapie hath name like coulour blacke grape wise counsaile kinde haue spoke composition eie white cléere sheddeth spirit sight therefore néedeth haue therwith curtill vuea grapy gather light ye eie blacknesse thereof blacknesse coulour gathereth sight also rume full hole spunge conteineth thrids sinewes constā tine saith cleanse purge humour christalline frō superfluous moisture curtell vuea grapie ioyned farther part head ye curtel secundina inner part ioyned maketh ye second roundnesse closeth humor albugineus kinde setteth make spirit cléere giue kind moisture ye humor christalline curtell followeth curtell called cornea hornie hath name therof sul like bright horne bright cleere ye spirit sight brightnes cleernesse thereof reason somewhat thicknesse therof helpeth somwhat spirit sight gather ye sight also strength therof sadnes defendeth inner curtells lesse strong vtter griefes curtell cornea hornie ioyned ye inner curtell called sclirotica hard maketh another roundnesse two curtells cornea vtter sclirotica inner conteine close within themselues rounde humour vitreus glassie last vtter part eye without set curtell coniunctiua commeth downe braine panne couereth eie remaineth corner eien bindeth holdeth abide due stedfastnesse disposition eies cha 6 eie disposed perfectly mē bred spirit sight brought manner formost part ye braine come two hollowe sinewes called optici fixe themselues ye substance humor christalline two hollow sinewes bée pight ye eien come either ouerthwart either crosse wise ioined point maketh kind wisely yt one eie closed let spirit sight may come ther perfectly déede blacke eye art seeing comforted ioyning vertue sight fareth shooter close one eie shoote euen also spirit vitalis therefore ioyned together susteining may bée strong therefore also come méete together bounde touch one thing séeme twaine fall eyther eye sunder sawe owne image therefore néedeth vertue sight conteined one limme one well vertue springeth ye black eie saith authour perspectiue fareth set theyr finger vnder eyen blacke one eye borne downewarde blacke eie vpwarde spirite sight departed dealed one thing séemeth twaine cause light commeth one eie vpward downwarde beame light yt commeth either eie touching vttermost part thing séene setteth space aire betwéene séeth two body yet one neuerthelesse euery squint looker séeth though eies vneuen stéepely beame passeth right line vttermost partes thing séene said afore ye third booke chapter sight well disposed eye considered touching perperfect composition part said afore also touching scituation challengeth highest place dignitie subtiltie namely néerenes hath soule sayth isidore aristotle also touching due proportion quantitie eie ought strained far neither lifted vp high betokneth disturbāce discretiō neither déep ȳe betokeneth default matter vertue ȳe mene worthy praised li 19 aristotle saith déep sight séeth far moued lightned ere come ȳe lim light departed neither deled beame ye sight passeth forth right thing séene shewed sight also considered diuers mouings ought moue meanly ye eie much mouing betokeneth excesse heate betokeneth also vnstedfastnes thought mutablenesse affection moue slowly betokeneth contrary disposition excesse colde obstinatnesse thought meane mouing praised signifieth easie perceiuing minde thing perceiued due fastning therfore aristotle saith li 12 closing eye must meanely swifte great opening little closing betokeneth shamefastnesse folly saith li 1 opening slowly betokeneth default vertue compaction matter sinewes obedient ye working spiritaddition fareth yt haue lethargia forgetfulnesse impediment cōmeth colde rume ouer moistered impatience doth lie hinder part head braine pan also eies considered properly touching perfection working eie apprehendeth well lightly without againe smiting déemeth séeth betokeneth good disposition fareth eien egles spéedely behold sée sun roundnes working eie déemed considered sharp dim hath subtile sight séeth well far néere sight much séeth farre subtill hath full discerning thing séene eie litle sight aristotle saith li 19 shall sée well farre thicke spirit séeth much farre bignesse perfectly thicke little spirit subtil séeth nigh perfectly far scarcitie ye spirit sight séeth perfectly yt reason subtilty therof little sight thicke seeth far scarcitie therof seeth perfectly ye thicknes therof thicker troubled spirit yt man hath féebler vneasier sight also eye déemed chaunging colour li 19 aristotle saith eien beginning bréeding gréene coulour chaunge black either yeolow either anye meane coulour séemely thereto ther much humour little spirit sight disturbed happe blacke coulour therein strengthened little humour image séene therein small child bee called pupilli blacke eye called cleane pure puella little maid childe phisitions say image sée eyen bée séene eyen ye shal diea secret knovve sick shall die thrée dayes afore sayd image bée séene certeine token death blacke hath circle yt called corona ye corona blacke eye marked bounded white part eye departed therefrom corona roundnesse thereof highteth blacke eie corona yt fayrenesse eye hetherto speaketh isidore halye saith blacke eye glasse appeareth image thing séene eye eye reumes humoures eyther helpe serue blacke eye therefore sitteth middle quéene blacke eye little quantity vertue among member therfore least taketh comprehendeth thing spirit commeth braine within taketh lykenesse receyueth without lyght light taketh selfe lykenesse thing séene sendeth perseueraunce soule partes thing seene line come togethers make pirami toppewise either shield wise steeple sharpe ende blacke eye broade ende thing seene shewed afore sight looke blacke eye perceiueth hath discouering coulours shape thinges vtter part hath lyking middle coulours figure shape lynes perspectiue expressed corrupt vttermost partes eyther least heauie faint contrariousnesse saith philosopher also séeth déemeth al • thing without set afore neuer séeth selfe lynes vpon lykenesse thing séene commeth sight séeth selfe hapneth reflection rebounding beames likenesse thing séene first multiplyed reboundeth myrrour myrrour againe sight sayth authour perspectiue therefore peraduenture spirite sight hath lyking sight myrrour somwhat fortified strengthened tourned agayne selfe reflection rebounding beames also blacke eye comprehendeth thing corner whether lymmes passe blacke eye thing séene eyther come blacke eye thing séene alway ioyned middle center black ye eie wer corner corner wise yt corner touch méeting two line forsomuch lynes yt sight shapen ioyned cornered middle ye blacke eye therefore philosopher saith well properly eye se • eth thing corner also among part bodye blacke eye soonest feeleth nobilytie preciousnesse complection thereof passible therefore soonest grieued hurte worst hardest daungerous healed therefore kinde hath giuen thereto curtills rimnes couerings defence may better put win without thing grieue property passion eyen blacke therof serch within special treatise li 6 ¶of eye lyddes cap 8 eye lyddes couerings eyen called latine cilium hath name celare couer hele couer eyen sauegard saith isidore lib 11 cap 2 eye lyddes substaunce • nowie thinne easie mouing theyr continuall mouing put awaye aire kéepe defende eyen without grieuing hurting aire eye lyddes called cilium latine palpebre also palpitando ofte féelyng moue alway close vnselye togethers féede busie mouing saith constantine isidore also eye lyddes warded kepte rowes hayre put anye thing fail chaunce come neere eyen eyen open sléepe quietly surelye eyen closed therein also meanly may cutting ayre quicken kéepe saue sight cleere bright hetherto speake isidore cap sup constantine saith eye lyddes haue haire straight somewhat bent crooked kinde hath wisely ordayned make able stronger close themselues put mightely griefe hurt fall also growing eye lyds haue kinde certaine quantitie thereof haire spreadeth neither wareth heate head haue certaine poynted proportion therefore constantine sayth eye lyds soft neyther full poores rather harde hayre groweth thereon may hard somewhat crooked bend shoulde growe soone length hearbe yt groweth harde lande lyttle vpright hearbe yt groweth within softe lande kinde giueth eye liddes beautye bodye helpe eyen therefore libe 12 aristotle sayth euerye beast gendereth onelye hath haire eye liddes euerye foure footed beast closeth eye ouer lidde bird stéede eye lydde hath heler couer kéepe sighta cōtrary closing eye closeth ye eye web ordained therfore vttermost part eye kinde eye watrie moyst therefore néedeth keeping also euery bird closeth eye nether lydde also euery foure footed beast wanteth eye lyddes féeble sight fareth fish hare aristotle saith li 4 c ¶of browes chap 9 browes called supercilia set aboue eye lid furnished much haire intent helpe eyen put humour sweate commeth downe head middle space betwéene ye browes bare without haire named intercilium isidore saith lib 11 browes helpe eye lyds saith constantine kéepe griefe hurt come yt eyen without also adorne make person seeme honest faire man séemelye without browes browes haue vertue hid sheweth outward passion soule saith aristotle browes straight lynes signifie womanly softnesse either lightnesse head also hanging browes ouer measure betokeneth enuious man aristotle saith lib pri also high browes thicke haire signifie hardinesse euenlong browes little haire signifie towardnesse also thick long haire somewhat shaddowing sight betoken passing excesse heat also much fleshie lyttle haire signifie harde blunt wit colde hath masterie principall member also bée without haire signifie corruption yt bloud gladnesse heuinesse constantine saith verye truth soothnesse forhead aboue halfe rounde full hard neither full softe néedefull temperate yt hurt neither griue place nigh eyen safely warded couered imaginatiue thing sorrowfull either gladde seemely either vnséemelye sodaynly brought perseueraunce reason déemed also forehead tower defence sinnewes come downe brayve make féelyng somewhat perfect hole pressed wrong trapping humour contained within temple teares fall eyen ¶of eares chap 12 eare instrument hearing hath name auris haurio take catch taketh catcheth ye voyce sound greekes cal voyce audensiden eares called audes hearer voyce smiting comming winding eares maketh sound noyse eares take perfection hearing ouer part eare called pinnula latine men call pinnum sharpe haec isidorus instrument hearing hole set stonie bone yt sinewes fastened come frō braine bringeth eares féelyng mouing bringeth lykenes voyce receiued hole iudgement soule hole wreathed wound spindle presse vice hearing also hearing feebled time moyst complection namely ofte serue venus disturbaunce spirites yt maketh hearing perfect aristotle sayth oft seruice venus grieueth body hart haly saith aristotle saith lib 12 man eares kindlye set middle round head eare heareth onely straight one wayes rather euery side foure footed beast haue ye head hanging downward earth body reared vpright eares ouerpart head fareth oren ass horse eares beast moue greatly high place yt moue much toward diuers place take sownd noise much reboūding also ari saith beast layeth egs hath care growing vpright without yet beast haue priuy wayes also bird fowles fly haue none eares outward neuerthelesse haue meane hole open way heare perfectly alsoconcerning nature among beastes man eares moue least also shortest dimention seituation place heare able liuely sayd lib pri goodnesse complection wherefore great excesse greatnesse eares man signes token agreeing thereto token dulnesse slow wit vnderstanding aristotle saith ¶of nose cap 13 isidore saith nose instrument smellyng hath name nosethrills nosethrills called wee smell sauouring vitall thing discerns betwéene swéets stinking smellyng remaine v called nosethrilles contrary men blockish carelesse vnskilfull ignoraunt called without nosethrills constantine saith nose hath two hole diuided sunder manner gristle bone one two hole commeth hollownesse ye roofe mouth passeth skinnes brayne drawe ayre brayne bring spirite féelyng nosethrils make sense smellyng perfect first hole néedfull put superfluity come brayne draw spirite breath make perfect smellyng properlye speake instrument smellyng two holow fleshy peeces hang nosethrills scale receiue first themselues aire drawen sendeth inner part brayne teates vtter nosethrilles serue drawing aire closing within themselues making subtil lightlyer perfectlye changed likened lymmes smellyng sinewe commeth brayne entereth sayd teates nose giueth spirite féelyng saith constantine meane ayre nose draweth fumositie ioyneth selfe spirite feelyng spirite taketh lykenesse smoake presenteth brayne gouernment soule therefore constantine sayeth nose needfull drawe ayre temperately cleanse pourge ye braine suiting place temper ye kinde heate dennes chamber braine also giue perseueraunce know smoke resolued dispearced substaunce whether smell swéetely stinke seruently therefore lib 12 aristotle saith wit smellyng departed wit hearing except doe acte déede smelling also witte smellyng draw ayre beast yt hath nose lim yt nose midle ye formost part head kinde setteth nose middes three instrument f •• lyng tongue ballaunce mouing breth needfull wit gather briefly thesethings aforesayd yt nose member office knowe drawe put ayre déeme smellyng clense purge ye brain great superfluityes serue spirit feelyng drawing ayre open close lung therfore constantine saith nosethrills bée set euen afore lung thwart ouer colde aire whyle commeth lung grieue dust anye thing entereth ayre annoye lunge also gregorie super cantica sayeth nose beseemeth face insomuch nose lacketh parte face vngoodly vnseemely disposition nose meane passe due manner length breadth highnesse nosthrills thin either wide great drawing aire betoken fiercenesse heart indignation thought disposition member bodye affection soule foreshewed déemed sayd iu principio philosophiae accident ye soule often chaunged according accident body white wine taketh lykenesse coulour redde glasse poured therefore meanes disposition betokeneth mean goodnesse philosopher saith libro suo principio super pronostica gaien saith nose let dooing working hée sayeth also sharpe nose hollowe eyen c strength heate wasteth moysture token deathand therefore nosethrilles ware sharpe eyen déepe sharpe feauers token death falleth nosethrils galen saith kinde heate féeble maye stretch spreade selfe vtter partes therefore followeth spirite bloud maye come together vtter partes colde slayeth lymmes shrinke togethers heart altered commeth sharpnesse nosethrils worst signe token deadliest haue ague also nose let constantine saith lib 9 cap 15 euill disposition brayne sometime stopping sinewe smelling sometime fulnesse replection stinking corrupt humor teates nosethrilles somtime bréeding superfluitie corrupt flesh hole nose sniuelards leaper grieueth onely smellyng also decayeth voyce sometime grieued superfluity humor flitte dennes chamber brayne chat commeth dissolution dealyng heate either great constrayning closing commeth colde fareth oft reuine falleth breast sometime repletion sharpnes veynes neuerthelesse bléeding nose speciall cause dissolution euill many sickness certayne token recouery health fareth sharpe ague ende passe away ofte bleeding aphoris saide good woman deficientibus men • truis bléede nose ¶of cheekes cap 14 bucca faux genathe chéekes neather partes eyen wherof beginneth yt beard saith isidore li 11 cap 2 genos gréeke barba latine english beard part called maxilla latinemaxilla ye bone cheeke mala roūd vnder eye haue name mali per diminutionem male called high partes set vnder eyen defence eyen called male either wer round vpward eyen greekes call mala el aboue maxilla chéekes maxilla diminutiue male praxillus diminutiue palo sayth isidore requireth heedfulnesse addition vnderstande malae malae leure space face close side nose roofe mouth vnto eye browes constantine saith ye chéeks made compounde within sinewes bone bone therof ioyned braine pan yt therfore compound made manye diuers péeces least one haue anye hurt grieued outwardly hot fleshie tē per asswage colde bone gristle eares nosethrills also serue succour heate limmes féelyng therfore chéekes set vnder eyen defend saue set middle sens seruice foode hot fleshie slake colde lymmes féelyng bée white red beard cap 15 constantine saith beard isbarba seemlines ornament man face appearing couering cheekes one part beautifieth another helpeth hairinesse thereof defendeth sinewes chéekes colde aire therefore beard needfull feature cheekes beard token vertue strength kindly heate ye cause man hath beard woman man kindly hot woman therefore man smoake matter haire increaseth woman kinde sufficeth wast smoke putteth driueth two place head beard therefore sometime woman hot moyst complection haue heards wise men colde drye complection haue lyttle beard therfore men gelded growe beard haue lost hot member bréed hot humour smoake matter hayre followeth thicknesse beard signe token heate substantiall humour strength certaine assay know difference betwéene men woman child grow beard though hot moyst superfluitie sumositie matter hayre passeth turneth waxing féeding child huc vsque constant aristotle sayth li 19 ye haires bearde lyke haires head disposition thereof presenteth sheweth qualytie vapour fat humour gendred humour smokie hot drye haire well beard head shall crispe curled falleth passe two contrarye wayes earthie part moue toward neather partes heate moueth toward neather part haire curled crispie feeblenesse thereof happeneth scarcitie moysture multitude plentie earthy part great heate crispie curled vapour ful moyst hayre shall softe long humour runneth making slipperie till come haire therefore haire head beard dwell thracia thracia region europe vvhich standeth constantinople time called byzantium softe smoothe complection moyst arye dwell moyst contrariwise hapneth men haue drye brayne dwel hot region countreyes drynesse ayre dwell saith coulour hayre bearde chaungeth chaunging age therefore age beard wereth hore féeblenesse heat plentie colde sometime hayre beard falleth away withdrawing heate moysture f •• eth men gelded sometime corrupt humour fareth leper aristotle sayth fallyng haireas ye bay tree boxe holme others kind lyke fallyng leaues tree cause heereof withdrawing hot humour fat therefore leaues trées fat humour fall huc vsque arist lib 19 ¶of iawes cap 26 isidore sayth libro 11 mandibulae iawesmandibula ae gingiua kinde bée much grieued ayre colde defended couering lyppes also vtter part lippes ruddye happeneth constantine sayeth subtiltie skinne lyppes casilye receiue deale ruddye qualytie sanguine beate ware white age also sayd néedeth know beast many téeth ioyned togethers long life beast téeth set thin sunder short life also said euery foure footed beast getteth gendereth beast lyk • selfe hath néedeth yt matter carthie part draw beast toward ye ouer part turne téeth man haire feather beast bornes therefore beast horne maye haue téeth either iawe also li 16 saith onely téeth among bone grow horrible man burden soule wit c ¶this sufficeth time voice good euill rehersed afore thinges letting voice treatise tongue yet shall spoken héereafter throate chap 24 throate vttermost part pipe lungsgutter ri lugulus curgulio canna pulmonis lung pipe vvesen sayth constantine double helpe first draw send aire second receive bring meate drinke make voice sownd substaunce pipe gris • lye harde ayre goeth voice shuld bee cleere hearsenesse voice commeth moysture organe lung voice made composed thrée gristells first knottie bending outwarde within hollowe second first set fast mouth stomacke third gristell middle betweene first second three gristells throate made cheined togethers maye open close substaunce throate closed within clothing skinnes cloth tongue roose mouth hollownesse throat ayre commeth hath bodye composed lyke tongue gristells fatnesse skinnes phisitions cal ye tongue throat cataracta first instrument voice sayde voyce may bée cataracta waye bée closed waye throate bée open voyce maye wise bée ayre passeth little little therefore ware throate needfull withholde • ose breath throat somtime grieued humour come downe head thereof commeth hearsnesse ye throat cough sometime happeneth drawing corrupt drie aire sometime chaunceth entering dust therefore throate hath nerues gristels withstande let dust grieuous thinges enter lung needfull make voice fayre strong readie releeueth aire commeth tempereth coldenesse thereof therefore men die tongue throate cut much ayre entereth cooleth throat lung throat needfull instrument make shape voyce bring meate dislike first place digestion stomacke long round drawe put much aire easily coole heate heart hollowe eyther end straight middle shape voyce better made composed diuers gristells couer themselues cup bee stronger bend selfe easilier varie voyce tendernesse gristell • inde ordeineth wisely aboute throate double •• ce néedfull beast double hollownesse waye hath pipe waye drawe ayre breath hath open way hippocrates also sayth right pappe woman goeth two childrena note vntimely birth wareth tender soft man childe shalbe borne time lefte pappe waxe soft female shall borne hir time pappes grow tender softe child shall borne afore time commento galen telleth cause héereof sayeth smalnesse pappe betokeneth scarsitie milke therefore childe hath due feeding hée must need dead born time also hippocrates saith ther woman superfluitie hot bloud turneth pappes betokeneth madnesse galen telleth cause thereof sayth superfluitie seruent hot bloud commeth pappes may turned milk passing great heate abundaunce therof dispearced turned sharpe smoke goeth vp head troubleth brayne breedeth madnesse also saith thou wilt make bloud menstruum woman lesse thou shalt set coppe ye papcopping boxing meanly hard token childes health great smalnesse leannesse pap conception token childe féeble corrupt token childe shall dead born el borne afore time saith woman childe man childe right pappe lefte e ouer hard commeth great sicknes sore called pilosa addition kindly humor lacking heate moysture turned vlceration beginneth swelling like ball wenne humour retourne shortlye delyueraunce pilosa dis among ye great gut first called latine orbum hath mouth subtill ende gut hath name rest made window without mouth gut haue two mouth gut hath one therefore fareth sack receiueth much putteth lyttle kidneyes drawe watrye moysture bloud lyuer sende bladder passe aristotle lib13 saith reynes bée made bladder working bladder better perfect reynes cleanse superfluitie moysture runneth bladder also saith right reyne higher lefte euery beast hath reynes right side heate higher stronger also sayth beast haue reynes left reyne lesse fatter right higher kinde right side light mouing heate heate dissolueth wasteth fatnes also reynes vttermost inner member therefore neede greate heate consider reynes hot keepe kindly heate temper coldnes ye ridge ioynts ridge bone drain watry humour lyuer dyeth coloureth bloud comforteth vertue kinde bréedeth seminall humor fleshly hollow round couered fatnesse fleshly powrie drawe receiue easelier watrie superfluitie round gather humour rotting let office reynes grieued liuer also sometime reynes fail diuers griefes sayth constantine lib2 cap34 veynes lyuer stopped reynes lacke humour blend féeding therefore leane small neather wayes constrained straighted heate either colde ye presence superfluous humour commeth substance ouermuch stretched dilated consequently corrupted el humor fordried putrifie tourne stone addition reynes shapen long round hollowy massiue sad sad stedfastnesse hollowe lightnesse mouing kinde bone great mouable maketh hollow bone two cause full marrowe one least breake reason hollownesse fedde marrowe therefore wosing marrowe woseth bone poores flesh next bone swéeter flesh also bone bound strayned togethers certaine sinew fall neither depart asunder great mouing helpe effectually first ioyning ye bone though horne nailes clawes beast bils foules maye made softe fire crooked straight bended yet bone may made neither softe crooked euen bone may cut bewen hacked item idem li 2 beast haue hairie prickes stéede boanes haue lyttle bloud also euery beast hath téeth euery iawe hath bone marrowe marrow lyke fatnesse grease bone thicke hard whereby séeme wildout marrowe bone lyon eliphants marrowe beastes lurketh hid poores ye bone gather spoken bone foundation body colde hard drie colde hath masterie bone white strong stedfast hollow within full marrow bound togethers sinewie bondes beare euery continually lesse mored rooted couenably ioyned ye lesse ye wō derfull craft kinde bone couered cloathed flesh skinne sustentation flexible bound togethers ioyntes sinewes string receiue temperance kind heate flesh bloud also bone feele case bone bée hurte either grieued grieue body full sore namely broken sore hurt bée nigh ye sinew whose bond knit together bone somtime grieued outward breaking cutting smiting hewing wrasting falling ioynts somtime working within oftentimes sretting gnawing woode enraged matter fareth haue euill disease called herisipila men call holy fire addition herisipulas greeke word among latines named apostenia calidum tearmed ignis facer shingle burning humor pricking whose blister lyke wheales white matterie colour beginneth necké shoulder sometime ouermuch gathering repletion humour ioynts boanes fareth haue gowte sometime grieued corruption marrowe within falleth leaper sometime wasting humour marrowe fareth haue etike wasted consumed hath name moysteth bone comforteth tempreth coldnesse sayth isidore constantine saith marrowe substaunce hot moyst bred hollownes bone ye purest part vnetuous humour nourishment marrow heate thereof tempereth coldeth bone moysture moysteth drynesse bone substantiall propertie feedeth nourisheth saueth vertue féeling marrowe receyueth brayne influence spirites namely ridge boanes marrowe called nucha among phisitians marrowe meake certaine veynes serueth member set beneath necke giueth féeling mouing saith constantine lib 2cap 10 also isidore saith marrow ye subtiltie moyst vnctuositie varro beast haue sad bone voyde marrow seldome moued bodelye lust eliphant vàrro saith marrowe followeth kinde stone waxeth moone waxeth moone waneth minisheth priuie inspiries sentings féeleth vertue shall full wormes lyghtly rot perchaunce happeneth reason superfluous moisture graffe gratfed receiueth say superfluitie thereof may bee ruled neither haue digestion kinde therefore humour sent ye fruit cause bréeding wormes soone rotting also aristotle li 12 sayth beast hath téeth eyther sawe hath marrow like fatnesse beast haue little marow lyon hath hard boanes thicke little marrow doe faine lyon hath marrowe dioscorides sayth marrowe full medicinable also healthfull namely foules wilde beast healeth breaking stripping chin cliftes whelk lippes slaketh ache sore eares maketh softe beheaded bée raunsomed sayth isid else haue yt name seruire serue bée put vile seruice office bée couenable lord theyr child isidore sayth bée thrée manner seruants seruants bond borne bondage haue manye paine lawe may sell giue away theyr owne good cattell neither make contractes neyther take office dignitie neyther beare witnes wtout leaue lord wherefore though childhoode bée oft punished paine childhoode seruauntes bée bée called empticij taken straungers alien enimies bée bought solde held lowe vnder yoake thraldome third manner seruaunts bée bounde fréelye theyr owne good serue reward hire commonly called famulus haue name famulando seruing sayth isidore wicked seruante haue many euill condition rehearsed • actatu de ancilla euill seruaunt chap 16 heereto shall put condition yet couet desire haue grace men haue shew none math 18 forgaue thee al thy debt thou praidst mée wicked seruaunt also vnware vnaduised forgetfull vncunning hée hath minde hée shall giue lord account outrage luke 12 lord tarryeth come also hee wrathfull deceiueable trecherous disturbeth grieueth meynie lu 13 seruant beginneth drink dronken smiteth beateth meinie lord shall come c euil speker tale teller al thing namely speaketh euil lord fared ziba miphiboseths seruaunt accused king 2 regum 15 ecclesiast 7 heare seruaunt speaketh ill thée also delicatly vsed presumeth withstandeth lord prou 29 nourisheth seruaunt delicatly shal finde rebell becommeth seruaunt haue lyking deinteous thing also full fraude guile layeth wait entrap lord sometime slaieth spilleth 4 regum 29 king seruauntes set waite vpon slew owne house also hée doth lorde wrong flyeth srom lord forsaketh goeth serueth lordes aduersarye 3 reg 2 semey seruaunts fledde geth et primum reg 25 seruaunts encreased fled theyr lord euil doth amisse scarcely leaueth malice word ecclesiast 23 seruaunt arained vnderstand chastised torment ofte amendeth trespasse wereth angry wroth sayth seruaunt amended tormentes rather appayred vnkinde knoweth grace lorde doth vnto thinketh lord doth dutie debt grace eccle 3 slake thine hand thy seruant asketh fréedome also though doe amisse blamed lord without scourging scarcelye knowledge truth ecclesiast 42 worst seruauntes side must blade glos seruaunt chastised word must chastised wound guilefull deceiptes hateth trauaile hee called worke trauayle faineth hée sleepeth though heard tourneth one side side prou 29 seruant may taught heareth thou saist hath despite giue answere et luke 12 seruaunt knoweth lord shall bée beaten many stripe condition good seruaunt cap 18 condition good seruant standeth diuerse doinges good seruant wil taught wittie ready vnderstand pro 28 wise seruaunt shall haue mastery lordship vpon nise child et ecclesiast 7 thou hast wise seruaunt let thée thine owne soule c also good seruaunt meeke seruiceable whatsoeuer becommeth psalterio lord thy seruaunt sonne thy seruing woman handmaide philip 2 méeked himselfe tooke shape seruaunt also hée merry glad meate seemely seruaunt merry gladde chéere seruice displeaseth seruant haue glad chéere gene 45 shall gladde serue king esaye 60 seruauntes shall gladde praised ioye gladnesse c also hée good gratious speake seruauntes bée well loued bée goodlye good speake therefore sayde dauid serued saule 1 regum 18 dauid loued al people kinges seruauntes sayde loe thou pleasest king seruants loue thée also manly bolde hardie putteth himselfe enimyes lorde 1 regum 15 let man heart faile thy seruaunt shall goe fight philistine c trusty true thing betaken busie pursue lord néeds luk 19 well thou good faithfull seruant et ecclesi 12 seruant moses mine house méeke skilfull procure profit lord good seruaunt taketh héede multiply increase lord good cattell owne multiplyeng lord good cattell hée procureth owne profite luke 19luke 19 10 talent supposed bee value 100 poundes euery talent ye signified many giftes noble man called seruauntes betooke ten mina mina certeine weyght value said seruants merchaundise till come c also good seruaunt wise ware cunning giue accountes reconing hée hath receiued deliuered lordes good cattell hée hopeth certainly haue mede rewarde making good account thinges bée accounted alway doubt dread sayde luke 19 loe lorde thy mina hath made ten mina lorde sayde bee thon hauing power ouer tenne city also good seruaunt busie studieth heart thought araye ordeine lord profit rather owne hee ordeyneth lordes meate drinke bedde hée dispose himselfe eate goe bedde take anye rest good seruaunt accounteth neuer profite done séeth lorde trauayleth luke alway ready hand hath waite vpon lord shall please hee hath lack neither default seruice receiue benefi • e good lord psalmo 〈…〉 seruing woman hand ladye c also good seruaunt ceaseth neuer trauaile neuer idle alway busie profit loode hée doth eate fast sleepe wake wit thought alwaye ordeyne doe profite lorde iob 13 hart desireth shadowe hired man abideth c also good seruaunt neuer costly lorde meate drink neither clothing sometime holdeth content olde cloth lord yeare long hee knoweth hée shall haue lord seruice commeth therefore lawe commaunded lord shal let seruant goe seuenth yeare tell wise man default wil loue thee tell foole default shall hate thée good lord chap 19 name seruaunt name subiection name lorde name souereigntie power might therefore rightfull lordship ordeined lord commeth might power without lorde might common profite stand saf • ly neither ye company men might peaceable quiet power might rightfull lordes withhalde taken away mallice frée goodnesse might strength subiects also gregory saith knowen name lord name might right wisenesse lord rightful loueth right wisenesse face séeth equitie therfore rightful lord way rightfull lawe heareth determineth cause plea strife betwéene subiects ordeineth euery man haue owne draweth swoord mallice putteth forth shield righteousnesse defend innocent euill doer deliuereth small child fatherlesse motherlesse widowes ouerséeth pursueth robber rouers théeues euill doer vseth power owne hée ordeyneth disposeth lawe asketh name lord name equitie also name fréedome frée heart righfull lordes bée frée méeke heart sayd hest 23 subdued world lordshippe neuer misused greatnesse might power would rule subiectes mildenesse softnesse c therefore lord sheweth himselfe frée gift speach men except euill dooers loueth bée loued feared knoweth hée hath lordshippe ouer men liueth rightfully ouer beast vnderstand ouer beastiall men wicked euil gregorie sayth vpon genesis 9 yeur dreade vpon beast c man sayth gregorye sette ouer reasonable beast ouer vnreasonable beast onely dreaded men also beastes kind bringeth forth al men like power might diuerse worthinesse dispensation god worde setteth men dredeth righteousnesse god may dreade ye punishment man strength dread lord shall proude hée commaundeth busie winne get owne ioy stoutnesse saue maintaine right subiectes haue lordshippe ouer men neyther turned kinde thereof last meate incorporated tourned kinde bodye hotte moyst passeth kinde bloud flesh colde drye kinde sinewes boanes younglings meate taken corporate nourisheth increaseth bodie olde men repaireth kinde heate restoreth spent wasted kéepeth bodie lost meate many diuersities meate tourneth soone bloud substantiall moisture heate lykenesse hath bée bloud contrarywise contrary cause tourneth later bloud meate nourisheth much bréedeth much bloud nourisheth lyttle chargeth bodye féedeth yet somewhat refresheth bodye generally meate bréedeth good bloud conuenient ruling health yet men trauaile groser meate conuenient breedeth thicker bloud also meates bréedeth much bloud haue lyttle superfluitye contrarywise meate breedeth little bloud bréedeth much superfluitie generallye diuersitie meates complection member bée diuerslye disposed take quality bodie sayth constantine liber 1 meat thinges men shall take héede men doe dicting galen saith super aphorism wit meat substantialitie qualitie quantitie néede eateth conenable time néedeth also know substance qualitie meat kéeping ruling men body meate nourisheth purely chaungeth eastly meate kéepeth saueth kinde meane meate lightly turned helping kinde meate pestilentiall corrupteth kinde venimous meate chaungeth kinde destroyeth bodye therefore needeth knowe substaunce qualytie meate men take venim steede meate qualytie meate knowne either remission slaking qualyties element vnderstand full little colde heate drinesse moisture meate colde hotte first degree vttermost hugenesse quality heate drynesse colde moysture meate colde hot drye moyst fourth degrée else meane qualyties meate thirde degrée second hath lesse quality also constantine sayth men must take héede meate subtill substance qualitie meat soone digested much therof naurisheth little au • cen saith meat bréedeth subtil bloud soone wasted member therefore nourisheth little saith meate greate harde de • e lyttle thereof nourisheth much breedeth grose blond soone spended neyther wasted member isaac sayth small meate subtill bréede small bloud subtill contrariwise temporate substaunce quality meate cleane pure commendable great neyther small neyther subtill good wholesome contrariwise auicen sayth raw gréene hearbs fruite full good meate reason passing moysture maketh bloud full watrye disposeth rottennesse aphorism sayd scarcitie dyet sicke men fall meanenesse meate good restoreth lost bodie kéepeth saueth vertue strength increaseth bloud tempereth heate sharpeth wit giueth vertue working giueth saueth health bodye breedeth swéete sléepe soft lyking wherfore meate restoreth wasted lost working heate meate increaseth bodye maketh fareth younglings wasting losse bee meate restoreth bodye wareth leane lesse sayleth fareth age restoring losse euen lyke kéepeth body one state fareth young men men shuld take héed meat dooing thereof comparison eate thereof addition rath greedy feeding licorousnesse tast many dish present pleasaunt eating followeth pining surfet sodaine choking one meate accordeth whole man another sicke man one young man another olde manone trauaileth another yt resteth many meate contrarye euill dreade increasing euill therefore sick man shall haue lesse meate féeding shall vertue strength sicke man qualitie substance ye meat héereby profit meat déemed knowne also sayeng ipocras olde men may easilye fast sadde men somewhat easilye child maye least fast olde men kinde heate féeble strong therefore meate néedeth swage heate young men child lesse olde men cause resting men shall eate drinke lesse trauailing men heate strong trauailing men féeble resting men shall bée shewed afterward also féeding men take héede couenablenesse time men néede greater larger diet winter summer ipocras saith womb springing time winter bée kindly full hotte long sléepe time many meat shall bée giuen kinde heate much nourishing féeding c winter strong appetite digestion heate full strong summer contrarie winter kind heate commeth inwarde gathered within summer draweth lyking likenesse vtter heate effused diuided departed lesse bodye within therefore winter time much digested appetite much excited mooued fareth child haue much heat therefore greate appetite much • esiring néedéeth much meale lykewise champion harde strong trauailing men whem strong harde trauayle kinde heate therefore néedeth greate abundaunce much meate drinke galen setteth ensample meate right necessarie néedfull euery beast according conuenient one manner temporate much neyther lyttle often greate repletion meate cause death bodie soule namely great hunger great repletion meate perillous sayth auicen kinde desireth maye defie therefore meate shall bée taken appetite saturite drinke cap 22 drinke fléeting substaunce néedefull séeding beast sayth constantine libro 5 capitu 27 drinke needfull many manner cause moysteth drie bodie resolueth tempereth moist body restoreth body drinke meate brought far place ye meate thicknesse boistousnes may passe narrow way streight without helpe moisture drinke constantine saith auicen also ther thrée manner diuersities drink drinke onely drinke water ye nourisheth bodie drinke drinke meat wine constantine saith beareth meate nourishing partes bodye nourisheth beateth spirit bloud comforteth kinde heate drinke medicinable taken manner waye drinke lawe rule medicine sireppes drimell decisakara constantine sayth kéepe healthe heale sicknesse water néedfull therefore néedeth phisition bée negligent knowe condition kindes water hée may take good water beware euill water water fauourie vnsauourye sauourye water cléere substance well springeth eastwarde lyght soone hot soone colde water constantine sayth good kéepe heale grieuing commeth soone meate reason cléere cleane meddeled filth hoare reason lyght easie defie y• soone hot soone colde subtile substaunce thou wilt knowe two water whether subtill substance better drinke wet thou linnen cloth one water another cleane linnen cloth hang drye sunne two clothes wareth soonest drye water wet subtill water next unto wholsomenesse water springeth northward set betwéene east north reson springeth northward open vppon north windes tossed made subtile winter kindly hot summer cold northerne colde driueth heate inner partes fountaines lye open heate gathered within standeth colde heateth denie water ye well contrary sūmer thē heat aire ouercōmeth cold driueth head well colde gathered ioyned cooleth water sayth machrobius constantine also water springeth runneth strongly swiftly mountaines vppon cléere stone grauell hath second degrée wholesomnesse water great riuers saith constantine constantine saith raine water better water sauourye light cleane ipocras saith raine smoake water sonne draweth vpward kind sun draw vpward y• subtill therfore raine water better thē water defied subtiltie thereof soone putrifie yet constantine saith blamed rottennesse worthye praising subtiltie cléerenesse thereof water soone corrupt subtill grieueth rotted bréedeth hoaresnesse feauers best bee rotted therefore néedeth well ware rotting also constantine saith water gathered smallest rain séemeth best raine water falleth thunder best thunder mouing maketh smoake thereof cléere subtill also constantine saith drinketh oft colde water shall escape colde sicknesse namely age constantine sayth hot water washeth ye fasting stomacke purgeth cleanseth drasts meate sleme rottennesse cleanseth laxeth purgeth wombe reléeueth comforteth kind oft vsed noieth grieueth softeneth stomack distroubleth letteth vertue digestion • maketh bloud runne nosethrills also hotte water best fasting early namely bée •• onke ouer night auicen sayth olde wise men witnesse sodden water maketh small swelling pearéeth entreth bodyes bée medled therewith bée dissolued departed working fire bée compelled goe downward heereto hée sayth corrupt phisitions suppose subtill breatheth passeth vpward séething great thicke subtill abideth still false substaunce water made one manner part great séething might bée nothing abide drasts alone earthly partes faceth water salt made strong séething water molten snowe haile earthlye worst except water lake marreys beware water constantine saith make spleane greate hurt humour stomacke make skinne foule vnseemely bréede diuers feauers stone may bée esthewed authoritie auicen may boiled sodde librro met aristotle saith water snow molten heat commeth againe first cleernesse subtiltie foure manner water vnsauorie constantine saith salt smoketh brimstone slime mettall men saye salt water biteth fretteth guttes taxeth maketh soft wombe salt water oft dronken wasteth humour bindeth maketh wombe harde drieth bodye maketh whole scabbes itching helpeth haue dropsie bée eate dronke brimstone water doth cause colde euills heateth sinewes wasteth humour betwéene skinne flesh looke afterward ye shall plainly vnderstand vertue brimstone slunye water glowie cooleth drieth stencheth running bloud bealeth emoroydes mettally water followeth booing kind mortall water passeth beuis yron stoppeth hardneth wombe comforteth member vnstoppeth splene helpeth postumes water metall brasse helpeth moisture straineth stranguria hath disease euill called stranguria pisseth oft little water mettall siluer cooleth drieth manner water much vsed freed drink helpeth onely ye vse medicine drinke meate drinke wine ehere diuersitie wine touching substaunce wine greater harder nourishing wine subtill lyttle nourishing passeth soone stomacke withdraweth cholarik head ach maketh one pisse fast wine meane temporate working without consideration wine touching substance constantine saith men shall take heede wine soure manner diuersitye time liking smell sweete sauour cléerenesse coulour time wine diuerse wine ye new wrong pressed passeth first degrée heate libro de simplics medicina galen sayth wine made foure substaunces watrye airye firye earthlye longetin • wa • trye parte consumed wasted airye parte comforted dide wine better better also smell insauour wine diuerse wine smelleth sweet nourisheth well strong smell breedeth euill bloud headach also taft wine diuerse wine swéete tast nourisheth moistneth womb ponlike comforteth stomack malteth harde wombe griueth breast purtenance sower bitter lesse hot wine also colour hiew heate wine diuers white lesse hot citrine hot pearceth member constantine saith bréedeth cholarike bloud causeth head ach browne norishing redde reddish hot earthly greater white citrine pearcing neyther hurting wine meane foresaide condition better comforteth kinde heate nourisheth lyfe member bréedeth gladnesse hardinesse giueth vertue bodye voydeth red cholar sweate vrine tempereth blacke cholar restoreth moysteth member foredried default humour restoreth might vertue fatteth body creiteth appetite helpeth succoureth vertue digestion sharpeth wit vnderstanding openeth stopping spleane liuer destroyeth consumeth superfluitie bodie doth aware webbes blearenesse eyen causeth faire speaking breaketh stone reines sheddeth bringeth grauell reines good heale woundes helpeth pallaice said h • st 1 constantine sayth smoak meate commeth braine men sléepe easily additionyet curious may counsailed beware nisenesse prodigalitie spendeth credite men good wherby followeth many bankerouts sleepe chap 25 aristotle saith sléepe rest vertues feeling mouing strength naturall vertues vertue feeling mouing bound sléep kindly vertue strongly worketh vertue digestion sléepe comforted strengthened libro de quā • nime austen saith otherwise saith yt sléepe kindly vnféelingnesse common passion body soule sleepe cōmon saith sleep kindly vnmoueablenes help ye wit saith kindly vnsensiblenesse sayde difference thing kinde wherfore saith yt sléepe priuation waking blindnesse priuation sight priuation destroieth vertues thing kinde sléepe helpeth comforteth kinde kindly waking also soule hath liking priuation hath liking sléep sleepe priuation kindly disposition sléep defined otherwise manner sléepe liking passion yt stoppeth wayes ye braine wit comforteth kinde vertue reduceth kinde heate vtter partes inner partes sléepe inner partes heate vtter partes coole heat déepe within lymme common wit bounden lymme centrum middle part particular wit spring therof stretch lynes drawen middle poynt circle roundnesse thereof lym stopped ye particular vertues may stretch vtter part lymmes wit féelyng maketh kinde beast rest wilfull mouing impossible moue voluntarily away constantine panteg sayth sléepe kindly vnkindly thereof shal speak nothing time kindly sléep commeth temperate moysture braine smoake moyst cléere commeth bodye vp brayne smoake thicketh spirites • lleth sinewes bindeth wit austen saith predicto li sléepe commeth either meat come without el temperate humour within ye resolued coueteth come braine resolued colde parte droppeth downewarde heate passeth vpwarde colde dropping downward swageth heate heart letteth proces working austen sayth aristotle also heart well working good euil springeth heart sléepe vertues féelyng mouing rest vertues spirituall naturall hande séene knowen pulse breathing digestion sléepe best digestion auicen describeth sléepe sayth speake naturally sléepe turning againe spirite lims féeling mouing well well instrumentes spirites haue spring beginning kinde sléepe againe tourning spirites deepenesse fastnesse meate drinke may defied fareth sleepe trauayling men sleepe dead fast alexander sayth water aboue heauen set colde fleeting moyst •• frore heauie property haue contrarinesse among themselues bee contrary either berely ordinaurie wisedome god water vpon aboue firmament god • seat also firmament therefore lord hath set water beneath vnder reason colde moyst néedefull condition generation corruption set water aboue reason cléernesse néedfull conseruation world aristotle describeth nouus iste orbis qui firniamentum dicitur aristot • le vocatur primum mobilē seu supremuscibis first lacke figure seate holy blessed trinitie god father sonne iesus christ holy
