whereof earth lowest twelue circui • e vnder inclosed coelum emperium mathematician omit burning heauen adde tenth call primum mobile ninth call secundum mobile thus primum mobile secundum mobile firmamētum saturne iupiter mar sol venus mercury luna ignis aire aqua terra schoole men omit seate god place put thrée moe appeareth resitall ninth coelum aqueum christallinum adamantium waterish ycie harde heauen harde adamant stone tenth primum mobile eleuenth coelum emperium burning heauen coelum emperium primum mobile coelum aqueum christallinum adaniantiom firmamentum saturne iupiter mar sol venus mercurius luna ignis ayer aqua terra ¶of heauen emperio cap 4 coelum empereum first highest heauen place angells countrey habitation blessed men hath name empireum pir fire fullye called fire burning light shining isidore sayth heauen bright shining giueth lyght shining vnto heauen christalline next thereto heauen owne kinde part lyke without starres shapen rounde damascenus saith round contayne spirituall bodely thing kindly quiet immeucable vnmoued heauen néedfull continuance generation lower thinges alexander saith complection full perfection worlde bodyes certaine endes aske ordayned according middle one ende darke earth lyght coelum imperium either bodye vttermost highest lowest selfe vnmouable quiet rabunus describeth property heauen taketh wordes basilius exameron saith manner coelum emperium first bodye simple kinde hath least torpolentnesse subtill first firmament foundation worlde quantitie bright qualytie round shape highest place farthest middle point world containeth spirites bodyes seene vnséene highest dwellyng place god though god euery place yet sayd specially heauen working vertue shineth ther therfore heauen speciallye called god owne seate bodye worlde kinde heauen fayrest damascene saith heauen vertue god worketh openly ¶of ethere shining chap 5 ethere gréeke shining isidore saith ouer part fire aire called ether euerlasting shining lyght brightnesse anaxagoras saith name ether name fire aristotle sayth troweth burning commeth swiftenesse mouing thereof anaxagoras meaneth thing burneth called name ether alarcianu • saith ether place departed nether worlde vnséene comparison yt nether suffereth many manner diuersitie chaunging ethere place day euerlasting night commeth day light wonder shadowe earth cause night commeth high place place called ether li metheororum arist saith ether nought el kinde one element none foure element thing aboue ye roundnes ye moone kinde departed kinde nether element therfore ether neither heauie light thinne thick may departed thirling holing another bodie corruption alteration may come enter kind called ether neither part thereof came composition element corruption shoulde come therein yet anaxagoras saith ether aire set fire saith sometime cōmeth downward hid within earth subtiltie thereof ruled vpward downward therfore commeth earth shaking vertue ether closed inner partes earth aristotle sayth saieng erronious subtill thing moueth downward also though moued downwarde yet make working macrobius sayth shining ether vnder roundnesse heauen blaseth shineth roundnesse worlde contayneth selfe roundnesse seuen planet moue agaynst mooing firmament neather parte aire swiftnesse mouing setteth fire ouer part matter elementall setting fire roundnesse fire gendred bred sayd libro de coelo mundo sine ether set fire matter set fire taketh chaunging neather thing though neather thing take chaunging thereof ¶of sphere heauen cap 6 sphaerathe sphere heauen isido sayth certaine kinde shapen round moueth round middle thereof euen space time one poynt philosopher tell sphere hath neither end beginning therefore mouing thereof soone knowen beginneth endeth shape according heauen shape sphere simplicitie therof conteining receiuing also likenes accord isido saith also alphrag •• sayth sphere round vttermost part heauenly body fired starres contayned sphere goeth vppon two pole one thereof north goeth neuer downe v called polus articus north pole polus antarticus south pole neuer seene v farre v el earth betweene v betweene two pole betweene two endes ye world sphere heuen moueth turneth round mouing ther starres pight therein borne rauished aboutdravven east west againe west east mouing day night space soure twentie houres sphere heuen moueth great swiftnes planet met letted swifte mouing thereof made moderate shape world shoulde fall therefore alphraganus saith seauen roundnesse planet vnder sphere euery one meeting crossing roundnesse planet passe couenable meeting meete come ramishing stemament withstandeth tarieth swistnes thereof body sphere mooueth slont middle lyne named axis axis certaine line vnderstoode stretcheth straight midle bal thing one pole another line vnderstood heuen roundnes heuen moueth whéele moueth axi • tree endes line named axis called cardinales coeli pight foresaid pole called cardinales moue ye hollownesse pole sharpe corner doore moueth herre cardinales hollowe crooked inward isid saith halfe ye sphere called emisperium parte seene v desaulte sight séemeth toucheth earth circle sight stretcheth endeth called orizon end sight sayth isid knowe thou heereof shortly sphere heauen bright substance shineth euen middle thereof earth roundnesse thereof farre middle poynt earth therfore substance thing full great heauen seeme full little sight far sphere containeth nether thing ordaineth informeth cause effectiue generation liuing rauisheth draweth selfe contrary thing violence mouing draweth planet mette passeth forth harmonie accord ari saith li de proprietacibus elementorū ordinate mouing sphere contrarye meeting planet worlde commeth harmonie accord macrobius saith putting mouing roundnesse heauen noyse made tempereth sharpe noyse lowe noyse maketh diuers accordes melodie default hearing also passing measure noyse melodie harmony accord heard v likewise may perceiue see sunne moue though moue cleerenesse beames ouercommeth sharpnesse sight ¶of circle heauen cap 7 circle heuen many ye twaine seene twaine bée called galaxias zodiacus addition zodiacus ouerthwart circle deuised heauen astronomer declare course sunne alway betwéene tropikes cancer capricorno poyntes commeth either déepest winter highest summer declyneth little little backe againe emisperia circle equinoctialis toucheth circle called zodiacus two signes one named aries libra weigher ballaunce circle called solsticialis estiualis stinting sunne summer sunne therein sunne stinted stinteth winter dayes beginne long another circle called parallelus additiō paralleli line sphere world equally distaunt whereby sunne passing causeth variation houres day called antarticus also beginneth north pole passeth round signes called cancer capricornus tourneth againe owne beginning called south colurus additiō coluri two great circle sphere doe declare time called aequinoctia sayeth libro ciceronis definition plato light roundnesse circle commeth sunne plato thimeo saith manner god master thing maketh warely wisely deere light call sunne whose brightenesse shining heauen nether thing lightned measure hath life libro de elementis aristotle saith sunne hath owne light star moone receiue light sun glasse set candle receiueth lyght candle therefore marcianus saith sunne passing middle circle departed signes sendeth himselfe twelue beames ouer bodyes nether lightened vertues property sun speaketh dionisius libro de diuinis nominibus cap 5 saith manner sunne hath owne one manner shining light inlighteneth many essencias quality thing seene felt bée diuers lyght sun renueth féedeth maketh plenteous encreaseth chaungeth setteth place planteth renueth ministereth thing word propertie sunne knowen owne kinde owne effect owne substance hath simplicitie hath substanciall composition part vnlike contrary part foure element haue thing made element hath manner simplicitie manner kinde lykenesse accord therefore hath euerlasting substaunce without corruption compowning cō trary thing well corruption aristotle saith simplycitie sunne hath lyghtnesse substaunce thicknesse boystousnes naturall partes cause well heauinesse lyghtnesse body sunne hath ablenesse moouing light bodyes doe moue easely sunne swifte subtiltie substaunce ablenesse mouing hath actualti • vertue working simple thing kindly might hath diuers working dooings therfore couenably dionisius saith sunne lyght euen like shining light sayleth neuer though séeme sometime light taken away v earth moone set betwéene v also hath vertue renewing openeth poores hole ye earth bringeth foorth hid more rootes cloatheth reneweth ouerpart earth hearbes twigges flower entering vertue sunne pearreth inner part earth winter time like old thing fordryed withered earth euery yeare renewed gréene thing faire also hath vertue nourishing sunne beame commeth inner part more rootes séedes dissolueth departeth moysture earth owne heate lyke vertue drawing vertue séedes more rootes therfore draweth moysture tourneth féeding norishing thing spring ye earth also hath vertue kéepe saue thing nether world element contrarye rach contrary destroy themselues except recō ciled saued influence vertue • eauen kept due béeing alexander saith also hath vertue make perfect thing elemental heat beginneth work generation body heate sunne perfecteth bringeth forth due full ende alexander saith also hath vertue distination making knowing colour thing kindes shape thing vnknowen darknesse vndistinguished presence lyght brightnes sun knowen distinguished sunner also hath vertue vnitie accord aud himselfe also accident himselfe ioyneth reconcileth accordeth planet owne effectes doings also accordeth togethers element contrary wherefore marcianus saith macrobius also sun middle among planet make harmonie accord heauen sunne owne circle maketh thing middle string maketh instrument musike also accident heate ioyneth thing one kinde dissolueth departeth thing diuers kindes matter asketh workketh gathereth departeth also hath vertue plentiful vertuousnes giueth vertue generation nether thing bring forth thing diuers kindes ari saith man sunne gendereth man nothing bringeth foorthe srulte groweth sun beame reacheth thereto also hath vertue comforting sun ariseth circle y• called orizont vertues beastes made stronger euen till y• sun come middle ye heauen increase passing west ward downward farnesse body féebled vertues fall asleepe fareth flower open sunne rising close sun shining vpon earth maketh day disposition ye sun diuersthe 4 horse phoebus red white yeolovv blacke gules arg • nt sabella pyrois fuous ae • hon philegon name ye day diuers first ye sun red betokeneth northerne winde beda saith also hath vertue comfort nether thing isidore sayeth farnesse nighnesse sunne men face beast body disposed strength heat therefore marcianus saith constellation sunne men fayre nimble ••• id • wift • therefore fa •• e paynted feather chiteish face therefore called phoebus farre also peholomous saith sun maketh man corpulent great body faire face welt coloured great eyen maketh man able work gold owne exhaltation workes brasse disposeth abating also hath vertue cleansing purging spreding beames clenseth cléereth • ayre disperkleth sheddeth dryeth away pestilent aire also though hot himselfe yet hath vertue beating • éeming burning commeth contraction rebounding méeting beames mouing ouer par • body namely body beames come vpon bée shewer cleane bright sayd science perspectiue also hath vertue drawing • heate draweth sea fumositie vapor maketh thick turneth clowdes made thicke clowdie dissolueth sheddeth hayle raine snowe therefore marcianus saith sayd fable sunne fast occean vapor drawen vp • urned nourishing féeding thereof therefore men tell strong heate commeth strong rayne great drawing vapour strong impression beames heate wombe hollownesse clowde aristotle sayth also hath vertue giuing lyfe séene knowen nothing may lyue sun beame may reach therfore ptholemeus saith cooke sunne signe called leo house raineth ariete reigne duana one ye light vnderstand principall lyke sunne greatnesse fairnesse isid saith said exameron moone fairnesse night mother humour minister lady sea measure time follower sunne changer aire hath light hir selfe borroweth taketh plentie sunne taketh forme shape figure sun far néere sunne also moone lacking lightnesse hir selfe taketh lyght well 〈◊◊〉 sunne therefore sayd 〈◊◊〉 elementor • aristo moone alway halfe shired sunne receiueth light reboundeth towarde earth hath kinde like shewer hath proper colour taketh lyght another neerer sunne looseth lyght earthward cléerenesse • ee • eth neather side towarde heauen therefore shining vpward euer side therefore coniunct sunne sendeth light earth side heuen vpward fully shining sunne shining toward earth nothing towarde heauen beda sayeth macrobius also also moone chaingeth figure shape sheweth towarde earth diuers face lyght showeth hir selfe shaped bow wise circle round sight men moynoydus dictotomos amphitricos pancilenos moynoydos new seemeth horned dictotomos halfe full eight dayes olde amphitricos doubt full roundnesse eleuen twelue dayes olde pansilenos shineth ful fourtéene dayes olde also moone sheweth hir selfe three state sunne coniunction next sunne aside passeth froward sun afore sun goeth first froward sun hee seemeth horne bowe alway horne tourned eastward commeth coniunction receiueth figure shape horne alway turned west ward side turned ward sun seemeth alway voyde side toward sun full lyght moone increaseth humour priuye passing kinde floude ebbe increased multiplyed hir waning marrow ye bone braine head humoures body made lesse wexing increasing hir increased therefore thing hath compassion default moone also draweth hir water sea stone adamas draweth yron moone moueth draweth hir occean sea therefore rising moone sea swelleth increaseth floweth east ebbeth decreaseth west againward moone goeth sea floweth west ebbeth east moone hath lyght lesse sea stretcheth withdraweth flowing ebbing marcobius sayth lib ciceronis sea occean increasing moone holdeth maner first day moone full wont highest decreaseth waneth second daye withdraweth seuenth day againe increaseth springeth seuen dayes yt fourtéenth daye spring highest alway new moone spring sea highest also full moone also moone gathereth deawe aire printeth vertue hir moysture aire chaungeth ayre manner vnséene breedeth gendereth deaw vtter part thereof sée ye cléere moone summer time plentie deaw séene vpon grasse hearbs also among planet moone ful endeth hir course short time hir circle short therefore space seauen twentie day eight houres passeth signes circle called zodiacus ptholomeus sayth therefore ptholomeus speaketh manner moone sayth vnder moone cancer hir house raigueth cancer passing hir raigne libra cold planet passing moyst female night planet abideth euery signe two dayes sixe houres halfe full endeth course seuen twentie dayes viii houres among starres called erratice moone passeth vncertaine vnstedfast mouing shortnes course passeth walketh vnder sun behinde sunne sunne passeth south lowest circle moone passeth north lower circle moone vpright boate hath horne vpwarde vnder sun hath horne boowing toward earth wayneth areared beda sayeth also moone betwéene v sun ofte eclypse default ye sun default may neuer fall kind coniunction sunne moone moone chaungeth coniunction lyne called linea eclyptica middle lyne circle called zodiacus eclipse falleth alway ye sunne head dragon moone tayle againward héereof speaketh albumasar libro de motibus planetarum saith moone méeteth sunne passeth euen betweene v sunne maketh v haue default sunne beames capite cauda draconis head tayle dragon caput cauda draconis shalbe sayd héereafter also earth betwéene sun moone moone lacketh lyght eclipsed heereof speaketh marcianus lib de astro saith manner moone going vpward downward falleth sun line hir xxx dayes olde vnder sunne darkneth taketh away light sunne maketh darknesse earth maketh default euery moneth alway line euen straight lyne betwéene sunne earth default falleth moone moone sunne fifteene dayes olde sunne vnder earth maketh shadow greatnesse earth stretcheth lyne straight afore sunne moone commeth line hir light taken away shadow earth euen set betwéene sunne moone moone clipsed euery month full line clipse shadowe euen betwéene sunne therfore light euery month taken away also somtime moone containeth selfe manner darknesse dimnes commeth qualytie owne body kindly darke hath lyght himselfe sunne men meane darknesse commeth shadow earth rebounded maner dimme spleke body moone dimmeth deale lyght nigh earth moone taketh manner hoare filth marcianus sayth passeth vp higher circle bright cleane seemeth wemmed speckle smotching marcianus saith also moone signifieth betokeneth chaunging time weather beda saith moone redde golde beginning betokeneth windes ther black speck ouer corner luemmes betokeneth raine beginning month red middle betokeneth faire wether cléere full moone night rowing moone lyght spranckleth care tempest shall come short time beda sayth also ye harmonie heauen moone maketh heauiest sowne deepest bace marciano sayth circle moone heauie sowne sharp sowne sphere heauen yt commeth ordinate sowne sherking mouing circle roundnesse heauen saith thereof commeth swéete melody accord also moone giueth plenteousnesse séedes earth ra • yng ouer séedeth profiteth deaw falleth body moone saith therfore fable called proserpina procerpipina vvife pluto daughter iupiter takē sometim • moone nation call moone goddesse séedes throwen earth company men hir cha • life also taken moone therefore painted goddesse bowe hir hande hunter vse bowes also though moone bée colde moyst yet taketh heate nighnesse circle sunne heate drinesse sunne passing coldnesse moysture tempered shoulde comming downe toward earth make winter euery month macrobius saith also albumasar saith moone cleanseth aire continuall mouing maketh ayre cléere thinne mouing sphere moone ayre corrupt thicknesse infection come outdrawing night vapour moysture great corruption shoulde •• e thereof also astronomer tell among planet moone • ulyng hath power ouer disposition man body ptholemeus sayth libro de iudicijs astrorum moone contained sicknes losse feare dread bomage therefore chaunging man body vertue moone worketh principally falleth swiftnesse phisition perfectly wise ware hippocrates learning shall behold first moone full light humour increase men marowe also increasing sea worldly thing sicke man falleth bedde néedeth sée knowe moone commeth anye signe taile sun head signe euen afore shall eclipse moone againewerd sun taile signe moone head signe euen afore shall ye eclipse ye moone commeth degrée eclipse shall gneral must come ye head taile yt degrée nigh 12 degree thence within eclipse shall fall coniunction sunne moone must signe degrée minute degrée héereof followeth though moone ioyned sunne chaungeth euery moneth maketh eclispe alway come alwaie togethers vnder line eclipse yt moone chaungeth neither hath coniunction alway yt degrée neither head taile méet alway yt coniunction oppsition sunne moone • starre cometa chap 32 cometa starre beclipped burning gleames beda doth say sodeinly bred betokeneth changing king token pestilence war wind great heate sometime séemeth yt star beset blasing beames moue mouing planet somtime séemeth pight moueable alwaye beda saith séene certaine place heauen passe diuerse part yt zodiac planet séemeth yt yt circle called laclens galaxia spread beames toward north neuer towarde west therefore seene west side séene short space time seauen day sometime séene space 8 day beda telleth whereof yt star called cometa commeth gendered whether bée planettes starres bée pight alway séene firmament north side saith héereof foloweth starre séene birth christ cometa passed moued east south toward west moue starres called stella comete chrisostomus saith ¶of fixed starres cap 33 stellae called starres haue name stando standing though moue alwaye yet alway séemeth stande isido sayth called sidera haue name considerando taking héede astonomers take héede giue iudgements dontes knowe shall befall also hée called astra haue name austros anastros opposition body starres pight firmament nayles roundnesse whéele troth namely great isido sayth alphraganus saith star lyght gathred roūdnesse sphere therefore gathering lyght substaunce body starre quantitie fairenesse cléerenesse also might vertue also calleth starres lyght bright bodyes giue men beastes night dark comfort lyght ornate hight ouer parte worlde farre foorth may stéed sunne whome receiue lyght continuall sending beames cleanse pourge aire vertue corruption pestilence taken away neather worlde also vertue star element contrary conciled accorded lightened euerlasting shining starres heate thing nourished saued plato beda sayeth starres firie kinde manye men olde time sayd heauen lyght ornament thereof fierie kinde aristotle philosopher meane vnderstand heuen fift element distinguished foure element kinde propertie saye starres hée colde hot substaunce heauen hot working effect heauen continuall euerlasting • uing heateth thing vpon moueth heauen starres heate coole nether thing mouing rebounding beames heate bréede vertue heate vtter parte body afore whereof starres made certaine pure simple kinde corrupt lenthing shape bright also round figure sad sound hollowe hoaly vtter part plaine rough corued place highest mouing swifte quantitie great huge though lyttle farnesse place number tale onelye knoweth many numbreth telleth starres might working star vertueus among body starres grauer change saue nether thing starres sending theyr beames lyghten darkenesse night full ende theyr course sphere circle moue one swifenesse tune swiftlye hide theyr lyght presence sunne receiue lyght theyr comming rising chaunge ayre many maner wise make tempest faire weather cléere beda sayth also chaunging coulour sprincklyng beames betoken nowe good happes nowe euill astronomer tell also gracious shipmen shewe waye middle sea starres coniunct nigh togethes giue lyght bee fayre bright fareth seuen starres stare circle called galaxia watlingstrete though shew greate fairenesse company gathering togethers also bright cléere coniunct else yet take héede himselfe séeme faire cause thereof marcianus saith passing brightnesse one shining taketh away default another one lacketh faileth another cleere amendeth fulfilloth also fairnesse place starres séene men vnlyke greate séeme lesse albumasar saith euen starres straight ouer head lesse soeme quantitie little sight againeward farther bée place arising downe going greate séeme generally sight also séeme great quantitie downe going rising beda sayth point called ceneta capitis nostri point aboue heauen ouer head sayd thing ceneth head hée aboue streight ouer head ceneth called straight setting oūer head reason therof cause hée saith vapour come vp earth suffer beames come straight euen eien therefore eie deceiued sight eie wéeneth taketh himselfe beset aire lightened sun beame algazel sayth fight deceiued sight candle séene without let eie whole bleare eie séene without likenesse shape manner rainebowe eie deceiued wéeneth alway sée another thing light séeth wéeneth another thing rather eie auicen saith capitulo de obscuriefare • isus seeke sight also marcianus sayth starres passe circle harmony tune accord musike found among starres wright neather body make discord melodye ouer bodyes neither kindlye cléere bright heauen goe starres haue lyght theyr owne moone though starres haue lyght owne yet perfection light receiue supplyment helpe sunne starres communicate part theyr lyght one maketh place starre place stroedes boundes starres circle heauen knowen therefore astronomer beholde starre starre described short circle hée farre place wée bée hée hideth hugenesse quantitye vnmoueablenesse place doth certifie men certeinly yt behold take héede thereof therefore hée called stella mari starre sea leadeth sea men saile haue shippe men craft place tho middle heauen knowen going aboute certeine starres hee called arcthurus starre called pelus distinguished star arcthurus like therto commonlye called charlemaynes waine starre hath name polus articus arcthurus nigh thereto beda sayth arcthurus chap 35 arcthurus signe made seuen starres set line called axis goeth himselfe isidore sayth circle seuen starres goeth waine called among latines septentrio septentriones also commonlye called english charlemaines waine septentriones seue starres vvhich seene charles waine vrsa maior goeth downe seauen star full night pole highest starre circle called artophilax called visa maior beare therefore constellation arcthurus hath name starre isidore saith hath worthely name arcthurus artando binding knitting first part thereof cold ariseth reason farre heate sun cold hole pore earth bee constrained bound stopped seauen starres appeare beames light bright forme shape foure first bée ordeined quadrangle foure side thrée followe bée disposed halfe circle bée set vnder pole line called axis therefore alwaye winde rounde pole middle point gregorie saith always starres winde tourne round lyne called axis beare doth stake therefore circle called beare macrobius saith alway circle windeth round goeth neuer sight gregorye sayth thrée starres goe vpwarde foure goe downewarde againeward foure goe vpwarde three goe downewarde gregorie sayth among high circle begin fiftéenth balends august end ye nonis septembris euen fiftie sayd light chap 40 lumenas basilius saith light kinde partes lyke authours speake diuerslye lyght bée deede whether bée substaunce accident aristotle sayth lyght bodye streaming bodye damascenus saith light hath substaunce owne austen sayth super genesim ad litteram lyght bodylye substaunce simple kinde bodyes multiplied increased diuerse matter working moueable passinglye thirling pearcing least letting breeding highlye accordeth reconcileth thing bée diuerse contrarye conuertible grounde beginning highest naturall motion perfectible gladde communicatiue therfore bodyes nothing profitable light nothing conuenient conenable nothing sayre nothing swifte nothing subtill nothing inpassible wemlesse nothing vertuous found light also lux lumen light english latine difference betweene two nounes lumen flowing streaming floweth substance light lux sustantiall well vpon lumen grounded light selfe accident need self wer accident thing accident selfe hath cause beeing forme obiect light aire wers accident shuld haue cause forme aire may bée also light chaungeth subiect knowne light first east afterward west east light gendereth light nexte thereto forth euen west accident chaungeth subiecte worketh without subiect ther héereby séemeth light accident also light accident ayre aire sodeinly moue ye wind east west mouing light sodein aire moueth sodeinly anye element also nothing worthy noble light accident lesse worthy substance séemeth yt light accident aire much lesse worthy lesse noble light light body hard know vnderstand manner light aire cléere bodie christall two bodyes maye place neuerthelesse inconuenient impossible set lyght bodylye substaunce one another body see water ash ioyned meddeled togethers sauing bodie place conteining either distinguished part eyther conteined within owne vtter parte manner wise euer meddeled togethers ash water water abideth corporalnesse ioyning continuing togethers partes ash body also meddeling ioyning togethers bée two body place water hath owne place ash owne place light may bée aire euerye body sauing corporalitie either contuniaunce theyr substantial part light entering inner partes ayre christalline hath owne place beclipping aboute vtter partes place distinguisheth light substaunce bodie whome ioyned though may simplicitie substaunce bee felt seene yet wonder many lyghtes bée brought one place lyghtes meddeled together though bée ioyned vnited yet neuerthelesse substantiall forme light saued forme euery diuerse though none materiall cause formall dionisius teacheth openly li de diuinis nominibas saith manner lightes saith hée lampes bée house bée one whole lyght gathered togethers bée common yet haue prime distinction betweene themselues distinguished sunder one distinction distinguished vnity wee see manye lampes light one light one claerenesse commeth theyr lightes shineth without knowing distinction man thinke sequester light one lyght another ayre bee together 〈…〉 sight one another bee altogether shining lyght seemeth one without distinction one lampe bee withdrawen taketh awaye anye thing others light leaueth owne light sayd perfect • rutie vniuersallye meddeled confusion anye parte vnitie much bodylye ayre materiall light l • ue vsque diomsius wordes denis seacheth openlye light bee ioyned togethers substantiall propertie saued accident property taketh comming going also denis sayth light called lux latine substance selfe thereof commeth beaming manner shining body alwaye lux light shineth selfe neverthelesse shineth alway sindeth body matter disposed able lightned austen saith substance heuen light hath first place body neuertheles heuen lightneth darknesse night alway light shineth inuisibly darknesse shineth alwaye sightlye therefore euery creature feeleth vertue light vertue lyght worketh vnséeingly feeling moouing beast sayde libro fontis vitae also libro de ludicijs astrorum albumasar saith hippocras taught yt life star tempered thicknes ayre night bodyes soules destroied neuerthelesse certain ye light star séene night impression working light knowen toe sea ebbeth floweth respect moone part thereof whether moone lighten aire also though thinkes hole den earth bée lightned yet vertue light worketh séene care mettall thing gendred bred déepe within ye earth shortly speak presence light néedfull euery body yt medled contrary elementes ioyned also light sheddeth self highest heauen yt called coelum imperium euen ye middle world one substance simple roote yet variable diuersitie body receiue whether sun ouer bodyes neather wherein one substaunce vertue working light though vertue lightening therein first gendering light made first daye basilius saith aboue sun lightes starres made fourth daythe light • luneth darknesse iohn 15 therfore sun starres bearer first light taking bodylesse lyght bee suffisaunt euerlasting lightening without losse owne substaunce therefore light stretcheth euery place persecteth dispoleth bodyes lesse moare roo • e fundament shining one substaunce none lower bodyes conteyned accidentallye conteineth bodyes formall comparison though materiall selfe place steede therefore light materiall maye haue diuerse partes diuerse place forntall hath indeede diuerse partes diuerse place matter may haue power forme hath effect déed heereof followeth openly lyght kinde bodyes hath least matter forme lyght néere kinde fourme matter therefore matter least stéede point forme euery place stéede euerye thing mooneth owne forme aristotle sayeth therefore nobler extendeth hiss matter algazel sayth wherefore forme light noble bodilye formes stretcheth spreadeth matter therfore onepoint light shining suffisaunt selfe lighten worlde noblenesse matter adualnesse forme algazel saith light one simple vniforme essence though body light bée diuerse distinguished sonder though séeme one act gathered lyke yet one lightening commeth substaunce another though séeme sight ioyned one lyghtening light inconuenient set two bodyes together one place one bée subtile formall wer complement perfection • teri • •••• isidore saith lyght hath manye propertyes worthy praysed substance vertue working nothing sound cleere pure substance thereof therefore though passe vilenesse filth defiled nothing actuall deede cholerum summer sun course highest straight ouer head printethful strong working bodyes lyke doth neather thinges therefore dissolueth wasteth superfluityes hee gathered winter summer passe temperatenesse wether ofte gendereth hot sicknesse drye constantine saith sunne maketh dayes long nightes short ripeth fruite flower great heate maketh digestion humour fruite tourneth good digestion incorporeth ioyneth fruite fordrieth wasteth superfluity full maketh caues pit earth heate wasteth dryeth moyst part drynesse wringeth ioyneth togethers carthie partes openeth chinketh earth watrie part cause ioyning togethers part wasted dryed néedeth onepart departed another made clifts chin part earth summer drieth marreises moore wasteth moysture maketh rough hard clinkerie full pit hoales working summer subtiltie heate commeth hollow part beast dryeth wasteth humour betwéene skinne flesh sheddeth maketh beast swifte destroyeth wasteth superfluitie also opening pore spirites passe exhalation substantiall moysture vapour therfore vertues féebled also made faint either quality commeth exciting beginning cholera therefore bréedeth hot feauers summer féedeth bee gather hony flower also night bréedeth deawe moysture springeth ther grasse hearbes fordrye heate daye summer time fowles sing make melodie bréede birdes namelye wilde fowles comforted shadow thing shorte middle summer ¶of haruest cap 7 haruest called autumnus hath name augendo increasing time namely corne fruit augmented plenteously gathered barnes trauayle ye yeare corne fruites bée gathered brought barnes therefore comparison betwéene haruest nourished iunos fable plenteousnesse isidore saith additiō cere kindred iuno daughter saturne ops called also isi wife osiris king aegypt gréekes suppose first inuent sowing wheate barley growe wilde among hearbes also first make lawes whereby iustice shuld equally ministred men violence wrong feare taken awaye herodotus writeth aegyptians affirms cere bacchus heare chiefe rule hell plentie riot forgetfulnesse diet abuseth benefit surfetteth body damneth soule cere betokeneth encrease graine called dea frugum • frugalitie commeth earth séede saturne sayd deuourer child per antethesis earth yéeldeth increase doth receiue hir againe bacchus first greece found manner planting wine secrete pressing wine called liber pater adage father libertie vino veritas men dronk disclose wine wit superfluous bankets riotous excesse called conuiuia bacchanalia dronken feast haruest maketh men busely occupied gathering corne fruite spoyleth fieldes corne spoyleth trées fruit drinesse coldnes slayeth burgenings leaues trées maketh fall earth barren bare draweth vertue budding springing also haruest colde dry bréedeth humour melancholike colde drie haruest beginneth sunne entereth commeth first part signe called libra sunne right line called linea equinoctialis like farre north ye south haruest time hath thrée month serue constant saith first beginneth sunne libra lasteth xvii daye september xviii daye october sunne beginneth withdrawe middaye second month sunne scorpione lasteth seuenteenth daye october xviii daye nouember third month whē sunne sagittario lasteth xvii daye nouember xviii daye december constant sayth haruest qualitie contrarie springing time therefore time bréedeth many euill sickness thereof speaketh hippocras apho sayth haruest falleth sharp sicknesse deadly upon place galen sayth haruest pestilenciall time euill manye thing first chaunging time hot cold also commeth summer findeth many hot humour full hot heat summer colde haruest smiteth againe humor inner part suffer passe body humor rot bréede full euill sickness quartanes feuers vnneth curable haruest cold dry inordinat therfore haruest great drines doth consume wast substanciall moysture maketh body féeble faint diuersitie chaunging aire pore hole body sodainly opened sodainly shut hot fumosities withheld vertue maye put multitude sharpenesse matter commeth deadly sicknes euills also haruest time noyfull grieuous haue tisike coldnes drines therof fordrieth renteth ye lung wer pampin floure vine therfore grieueth sore haue tisike ¶of winter cap 8 winter called hierns hath name eundo going either passing winter time sunne goeth passeth shorter circle summer time therfore maketh shorter dayes longer night isidore saith constantine saith winter beginneth sunne signe called capricornus end descention lowing sunne middaye beginneth little little passe vpward north also winter hath thrée month yt serue first beginneth capricorno lasteth eightéenth daye december vnto seauenteenth day ianuarie second ye sun aquario lasteth seauentéenth daye januarie xvi day februarie third moneth sunne signe called pisces lasteth xvi daye februarie eightéenth day march winter colde moist nourisheth steame winter coldnesse hath masterie moysture great binding fréesing aire water great farnesse sunne farnesse commeth great coldnesse winter time winter contrary summer therfore thing liueth springeth benefite summer fadeth dyeth hard cruelnesse winter foores signes summer gone destroyed brought nought winter time winter time snow greatnesse water multiplied winter time pathes wayes made slipperie fennie pore earth chin constrained frore made hard cold frost ice winter al body haue longer shadowes sumer pore earth closed therefore vtter partes body colde within hot part flye coldnesse haue mastrie gathered ioyned togethers therefore water déepe pit well felt hot winter summer kinde heate slyeth coldnesse hath mastrie gathered ioyned togethers therefore water déepe pit well felt hot winter summer kinde heate flyeth coldnesse contrary thereto draweth inner partes earth closeth selfe veynes deepe pittes welles therefore reason presence heate water fréeseth also sharpnes winter maketh men sluggard slowe working coldnesse constrayneth sinewes shrink deale wherefore member stretch work easely doe summer also coldnesse winter pore cloased kinde heate draweth inward comforteth vertues feelyng wherefore appetite awaked meat drinke néedeth time therefore hippocras sayth aphor winter time kinde bellyes hot longer sléepe time therefore time winter men shall take meate heate great strong néede nourishing also winter passeth owne quality diuers sickness euills bréed bodyes reson poores closed many humor gathered hollownes bodyes humor find waye passe wexe hot rot thereof néedes commeth diuers sickness euills ¶of monthes cap 9 ianuarie month called mensis mensis nowne gréeke drawen name moone language subtile highe matter kinde able receiue forme shape thicke earthlye féeble heauenlye kinde féeble receiue impression printing forme shape sayde libro de quinque iubstontiis sayde matter hath propertye taketh forme shape bée taken helde helde matter principall beginning distinction diuersitie multyplyeng thinges hée gendered said septimo metaphisice thing gendereth thing yt gendered diuerse touching matter therefore thing gendered without matter thing gendereth thing gendered one substaunce kinde fareth person trinitie matter caused two dealing departing twaine singular thing aristotle sayth 4 metaphisice departing dealing speciall singular thing matter forme sayde 10 metaphisice substaunce vnder one fourme one matter vnder manye bée manye matter also proper matter proprieth owne fourme called endlesse vertue endlesse limited certein neither constrained vertue god therfore plato sayth matter floweth without streightning • fourme stint fléeting therefore bodyes haue much matter little fourme waxe growe hugely fareth trées therefore bone haue title féeling haue much earthy matter auice saith matter hid manner actiue might manner vnperfect forme might commō two contrary therfore might brought déedes hath taken shape anone hath appetite vnder contrary shape might indifferēt heat cold hath indéede receiued heate anone hath appetite receiue contrarye formes thing corruptible genderable may sufficiently full haue actiue might matter alwaye hath appetite fulfilled another shape fourme fullye maye bée brought matter corruption sonne therein vertue thing worketh commeth matter corrupteth destroyeth forme therein exciteth actiue forme contrarie forme giueth thereto perfect till vnder perfect forme property many matter hath long recken al row looke li de bonitate mundi therewith perfection thing forma bad thing hath béeing forma destroied nothing substaunce thing found therfore philosophie said forma matter cause accidentalls forma accidentalis perfection thing shortly sayde ¶of fire cap 4 fire simple body hot dry const saith hath kinde appetite aboue aire fire violently holden aire earth passeth little little softe aire vanisheth isid saith denis hierarchia angelica cap 12 teacheth property fire saieth manner fire sensible bodye excellent subtill bodely thing next spirituall kinde thereby shewed vnlike thing fire thing custometh giue self al thing remoued thinges yet priuy hid vnknowen vnmeasured vnseene somedeale bodilesse mightie working moueable giuing selfe deale thing commeth nigh moueth thing partner reneweth thing warden kinde brightneth wrapped brightnesse cléere distinguishing sprankling leaping feeding moouing vpwarde passing downewarde sharply high taking shame decreasing alway moueable taking chaunging comming againe selfe working mightely word holye man denis darke mistike descriueth fire touching substaunce vertue working declaration foresayd word shall shortly reherse word commentour vppon place among element fire hath highest place hath light kinde therefore called high wāting weight séeketh desireth high place aboue element except fire bodelye kindlye vnder fire among element fire hath pure subtill kinde therefore called deale bodilesse reason subtilnesse substance séene without subiect matter therefore séemeth fire nigh spirituall kinde deale séemeth fire middle meane betwéene séene thing vnséene inasmuch nigheth nether thinges bodilesse inasmuch nigheth ouer part bodelye also hath kinde actual strong working element therefore called vnmesured vertue working increaseth without ende matter fire worketh endlesse long matter sufficeth fire faileth worketh alway also hath full priuie kinde therefore called hid sensibly séene hée called vnséene vnknowen fire perceiued without matter subiect matter fire worketh also fire beginning substaunce vnneth wit maye know also hath vertue kind mouable element therefore called mouable mightie thing fire head vertue mouing moueth himselfe moued thinges lower also hath kind cléere neather thing therefore sayd brightneth brighteneth thing cléerenesse wrapped brightnesse bright beames fire shine without wrapped foume againe priuye bosome owne substaunce bée hidde sight féelyng also subtiltie substaunce fire hath vertue sharpe thirlyng elementes therefore called sharplye passing mouing owne vertue entreth thirleth thing without resistaunce let fire hath vertue make himselfe thing knowen séene make difference distinction shewing himselfe sheweth thing present presenteth colour figure shape eyen therefore called cléere openly discréete distinguished also fire hath vertue drawe nether thing matter fire worketh fire maketh stretch maketh thin departeth draweth vpward vyolence heate therfore called feeding beneath drawing vpward also fire hath vertue renewing thing aged olde fayle kept saued vertue fire fareth old men whome kinde heate fayleth called renewer thing warden kinde without vertue fire may vertue bodely kinde endure abide also hath vertue chaunging hée ouercommeth thing worketh chaungeth tourneth owne kinde therefore hée called receiuing taking chaunging matter worketh hée receiueth taketh forfaiteth wasteth tourneth owne lykenesse fire receiueth taketh receiued taken thing worketh spent wasted withdraweth leapeth turneth againe therefore called leaping tourning againe also hath vertue kinde commune spred himselfe without dimunition decreasing therfore said taketh neither receiueth despite villany minishing decreasing fire increaseth burneth outward receiued minisheth • oot • taketh worship séemeth increaseth wareth ••• alanie séemeth lesse decreaseth also fire hath vertue kinde purging cleansing fire purgeth cleanseth sinder rushe amendeth mettall yt may wast • also hath vertue chaunge sauours brain hoyling stomach head euaporation saith also smoke cese hardene commeth meate drinke 〈…〉 strength heat commeth vp ye braine stoppeth sinewes séelyng bréedeth sléepe bindeth vtter wit séelyng smoake sufficient time ¶of cole cap 7 cole • incorporate indéede ioyned earthie matter gregory saith incorporation ioyning greater thicker part earthy matter medled therewith held beneth certaine violence kinde fire flame moueth vpward cole falleth moueth downward heauinesse matter also cole set fire turneth rednesse quenched wrapped blacknesse léeseth first fairnesse lykenes fire fairer first ioyning fire vnséemelye séemeth vnlyke quenching fire cole substanciall moysture wasted therfore soone broken brused humour hath cause ioyning •• part wasted violence fire therefore coale quenched one part soone broken another substaunce nothing founde moysture part cleaue held together gregory saith onely earthly part leuen abide mastry drinesse oft soone set fire yt kinled soone quēched sooner therin nothing found séene fire blacknesse blacknesse coale defileth smotcheth berayeth thing toucheth also fire cole hath sharpe fire mightie working thirling percing therefore sharpnesse coale soudreth yron desolueth slaketh part thereof maketh soft also sharpnesse coale grieueth head coale raked ash holdeth kéepeth aire cole vncouered set colde aire falleth multitude ash sodainly vanisheth awaye selfe gregory sayth • ire cole burneth grieueth soales féete tread thereon cole quēched grieue burning treadeth thereon maketh crushing great noyle ¶of sparkle cap 8 sparkle lyttle particular fire broke fierie matter vertue réese fire departeth therefore mouing sparckles sodaine mouing sodainly departed dealed moued vpward heauines earthie matter falleth ye middle downward last also ye mouing thereof cléere bright starre shedding fire sparcklyng earth séemeth gréene beames light therfore mouing therof mouing fire worketh vertuous lyttle sparckle heape towe tinder commeth sodainly great fire chaunging aire sparkle vanish sodainly quenched abideth nothing ash temperate blast wind sparkle kindled quenched strong blast thirleth ayre putting thirling ye aire changeth soindeale altereth stronger fire mouing sparkle swiftnesse yt gréene matter moist commeth great sparckles strong thirling pearcing toing working fewe right many number ¶of ash called fauilla chap 9 ash called fauilla haue name fouendo nourishing kéeping kéepe fire couer cinis little ash left quenching sparkling matter isid saith fauilla small ash pale dry light vtter part firie coale cleauing therto dimmeth shining therof slaketh abateth strength feruentnesse coale sparkled little puffe blast wind sparkled dreth euer gathered gregory saith soone set fire flame default féeding sodainly quenched isidore saith clowdes chap 4 clowd animpression made ayre middle many vapour gathered bread one body middle region ayre thickened togethers coldnesse place cloud commonly matter snow raine hatle clowde gendered manner heat heauen owne vertue draweth right subtile vapourable part water earth wasteth subtill partes thereof maketh deale thick • ourneth clowde ayre thereof speaketh isidore sayth clowd thicknesse ayre gathered together drawing vapour fumosityes earth sea also lyghtnesse ayre putting shouing windes substance clowd moueth hither thither cloud kindly hollow many hole spoung therfore receiueth soone impression ener body therfore entring incomming sunne beames cloude representeth sheweth diuerse formes shape coulours doth rainbowe else certaine dewe clowde substaunce diuersly shapen colour gendered sun beames clowde hollow within figuration shape sphere heauen nigh clowde rounde without aside clowde hath certeine form shape propried clowde commeth aside halfe nigh another eyther confirmeth himselfe figure shape beda sayth also lightnesse owne substaunce clowde moneth vpward moneth swiftly slowly lesse putte winde also subtile pure vapoures bée clowde compownded may paint neither feigne coulours rainbow aristotle sayth cause rainbowe smiting againe rebounding beames lyght turne againe contrary vapour clowde brightnesse shining water shineth ouer parte tourneth againe himselfe rainebow séene sun beame day moone beame night sight thereof lette troubling ayre féeblenesse sight darknesse thicknesse clowde withstandeth letteth shyning beames rainbowe séene rainy time resolued superfluitie vapour straighted clowdes thereof commeth lyttle dewing shineth beame afore rainebowe shapen taketh thereof diuerse coulours diuerse vapour beame shineth aristotle saith touching vertue thereof working bow set afore sunne tempereth swageth strong heat thereof resolution thereof departing tourning raine dewe rainebow quickeneth despringeth neather thinges maketh plenteous shape thereof figure many diuerse coulours highteth ouer thinges maketh fayre seemelye betokeneth greate moysture ayre therefore beda sayth maister storyes fortye yéere dome rainebowe shall bee seene shall token drieng default element sayththat rainbovve shall seene 40 yeares ye dome rainebow betokeneth peace accord betwéene god world sheweth informeth bringeth minde god dome water passed also certifieth v sunne presence rainebowe sheweth side sun heauen rainebow neuer side heauen sun alway sunne east rainebow séene west againeward sunne south rainebow seene north rainebowe neuer seene south high middaye beda saith philosopher telleth cause thereof high middaye sunne euen middle world beame thereof shineth like therefore shineth one side another therefore point middaye rainebowe séene side aristotle sayth full seldome séene night ye full moone beda sayth falleth twice fiftye yeares aristotle sayth dew chap 6 dew impression gendered colde vapour moist gathered bodye clowde neather parte middle space ayre méeting lyttle colde aristotle saith dew southerne winde bloweth dewe lyttle raine raine much dew southerne wind moisture gendreth nourisheth dewe northerne winde drynesse licketh vp dewe thrusteth togethers bindeth strong cold also moone imprinteth moisture earth cause gendring dew therein ambrose sayth calleth moone mother dew therefore night vertue yt moone aire dew ariseth vp priuelye commeth downe last séene sheddeth falleth lostly ouermost part grasse hearbs rising downe comming dew giueth vertue strength trées hearbes grasse thing yt heat day dryed wasted bowed downewardes night dew apparaileth restoreth maketh stand vpward also top hearbs grasse dew gathereth selfe drop though would vpward generation alway ascendeth hangeth selfe ouermost part leaues grasse also dew susteineth ye strength sun dissolued falleth anon working ye sun beames vanisheth away forsaketh vertue yt printed aire presence shedding yt aire leaueth openly effect vertue grasse hearbes séedes though dew bée manner airy substance subtil outward neuerthelesse wonderful manner strong working vertue moistureth earth maketh plē tious maketh floure pith marrowe increase corne grainessappe increase fatteth bringeth forth broad oyster shell fish sea mamely dew springing time night springing time oyster open themselues dew receiue dew commeth betwéene two shels holdeth kéepeth dewe holden kept féedeth flesh maketh fat incorporation inner part fish bréedeth full precious gemme stone called margarita noble margarite iscommon pearles white quality maketh temperatly sad thick albumasar sayth also dew withstandeth beareth strength venim venimous beast venim may shed night much day therefore adder serpent lurking among grasse hurt men passe little flowres grasse hearbes dewed also though dew séeme selfe sauoured water werish neuerthelesse might effect dooing sweete cause honny manna hearbs flowres coū try gréece hony gendred flowres commeth ver 4 bruc • broode long flyes destroy corne grasse hieronimus saith rubigo tender corne smitten burnt noifull dew care stalkes turned red foule blacke coulour mischiefe wasteth destroieth altogether therof wasting fumosities resolued fallen turne reine shower saith raine called pluuia hath ye name pluralitate pluralitie drop isi saith falleth commeth downe dropmeale also rain called imber hath name imbuendo springeth tempereth earth maketh beare fruite land earth besprong raine barren farther dow • raine gendred ye earth neerer heuen ye softly raine commeth downe ye small drop ye nigher clowd earth raine falleth swiftlyer commonlye greater drop also wind blowe vp sea gather much humour outer partes water bearing vp aire last •• rne thē matter raine ther much matter watry clowd clowd thick impression beames strong vpon clowd great gathering beames rebounding therof cō meth strong heat last vertue yt heat clowd dissolued falleth turneth strong raine oft • yt strong heat cōmeth substaunce hath airinesse lightnesse ayre water therefore seene chaungeable turneth soone contrary quality therfore taketh corruption rotteth soone constant saith fresh swéet water abideth cléernes vertue raine temperate quality quantity agréeable ye time profitable infinit thing raine maketh lande beare fruit ioyneth together many chinnes therin aswageth tempereth strength heat cléereth aire ceaseth stinteth windes fatteth fish helpeth comforteth drye complection constantine sayth raine bée euill distemperate quality discording place time gréeuous noyfull many thing maketh déepnesse vncleannesse slippernesse way path bringeth forth much vnprofitable hearbes grasse corrupteth destroyeth fruites sade quencheth seed natu • heat maketh darknesse thicknes aire taketh v sunne beames greate dayes bée hotte partes clowdes bée departed gathered colde aristotle sayth heat ayre colde come thereto fréesing water vapour strong therefore libro animalum aristotle saith fisher cast hotte water instrument takles may sooner frore sinke sooner néerer drop earth great againward littlenesse thereof ye roundnesse caused long bideth aire farre earth aristotle saith moist soft cléere bright doth moyst seedes grasse hearbes slaketh heate burning aire cleanseth purgeth ayre though droppe bée soft substaunce yet thirleth stone oft falling séeke within libro 12 hoare frost chap 9 hoare frost aristotle sayth vapour frosen else impression gendered colde vapour moyst gathered bodye clowde frore middle space aire coldnesse place time part heate aristotle sayth therefore hoare frost hardnes commeth coldnesse place time gendered coldnesse draweth gathereth together part vapour maketh substaunce hoare frost harde full great coldnesse hoare frost white maketh hearbes flower vppon falleth wyther burneth vanisheth awaye • lyttle beame sunne tourneth againe dewe hoare frost nought else dew frosen beda sayth dewe commeth downe earth taketh colde night white kinde hard colde turneth selfe vtter part substaunce ye hoare frost saith haile chap 10 haile fréesing drop raine strength coldnesse wind aire aristotle saith impression gendered cold vapour moyst chased driuen colde inner part smalnesse roundnesse tarrieng abiding aire long time long trendeling commeth roundnesse littlenesse commeth heat aire wasteth resolueth watrye partes thereof haile gendered place nighe earth contrary falleth contrary cause haile hoist ousnesse winde violently shoneth putteth heate dissolueth falleth downe swiftly earth spreadeth vpon earth salt haile gréeueth much corne fruites flower falleth snowe impression gendered colde vapour moyste lowest parte middle space ayre frore bodye clowde meane coldenesse comparison hoare frost meddeling heate parte heate béeing closed substaunce thereof splentes shelles féeblenesse vertue breaketh aristotle sayth snow gendred cold clowd colde haile gendered witnesseth softnesse snowe heate meddeled clowdes letteth partes therof may made thick stronglye gathered together snow harde dry water coldnesse constraining binding softer haile meddeling heate wombe clowde white mastrye coldnesse vtter parte thereof little heate snowe melteth water chaungeth soone hardnesse whitenesse abiding snowe vppon lande lande fatted coldnesse closeth pore earth heate gathered inward more rootes hearbs séedes inner humour drawen moore rootes gathered togethers glewe therby land fatted snow slayeth destroyeth wade superfluitie thereof nourisheth feedeth good hearbes maketh ranke also snow presence couereth hideth stinking place doung hilles way path letteth spreading wayfaring men tarryeth high sea snowe falleth seldome beda sayth cause thereof fumosities exalations thereof continually shuft sparkled wind blow therein mowe thicked turned snow resolued tourned raine mist also snow noyfull wilde beastes hideth couereth lees pasture sheweth discouereth theyr hauntes steppe snow time soone taken hu •• e • snow oft high place mountaines abideth endureth longer time mountaines hilles valleyes low place hilles cold wind fréely strong valeyes also valleyes low place hot hill high place gendering rebounding sunne beames therefore snow mountaines valleyes also snow melted strength heate moisteth • ltneth earth maketh hard constraineth constraining coldnesse molt gregory saith also snow softnesse lightnesse substance maketh sound noyse falling earth falleth priuely softly priuy place ye aire setteth himselfe vpon earth spreadeth like snow swiftnesse fairenesse comforteth eyen behold therin ••• men behold long dispearpleth appaireth spirit sight also snow water potentiall actual coldnesse refraineth bindeth fluxe wombe smiteth shrinketh stoppeth sinewes drinke snow water continually breedeth mestrual superfluitye great botch vnder chinne maketh member aston • ed though sleepe soone gendereth stone ye bladder feedeth forth cold dropsie constantine sayth mist chap 12 mist impression made resolution falling clowds double vapour first thunder impression gendered watry substaunce clowde moouing shaking hether thether hotte vapour drye flyeth contrary beset constrained euery side smitte himselfe thereby sette fire flame quencheth himselfe last clowd breaketh cloud aristotle sayth thunder gendered beating smiting together clowdes sayth clowdes bee mooued shuft contrarye windes clowdes smite togethers theyr violent breaking commeth greate stroke noise aire called thunder among olde men thunder called tonitruus tonitruum hath name dread feare noise feareth men heare isidore sayth tonus sonus one sometime smiteth thing hard séemeth renteth cleueth heauen storme ful strong wind commeth clowdes whirling winde storme increaseth séeketh passage cleaueth breaketh clowde falleth greate réefe strong breaketh part clowde commeth eares men beastes horrible dreadfull breaking noyse wonder though bladder light yet maketh greate noise sound strongly blowen afterwarde violentlye broken thunder commeth lightning sightening sooner séene cléere bright thunder commeth later eares ye wit sight subtil perseuerance hearing therefore first sheweth light brightnesse shining yt commeth ere heare noise sound yt commeth afterward man séeth sooner ye stroke man heweth trée heareth noise stroke huc vsque isid reason isid maketh cause thunder accordeth somwhat philosopher yt saith thunder spirit windes receiued bosome clowds breaketh vertue moouing renteth partes clowde maketh great quaking noise sound thunder therefore héereto hée sayth thunder sound space aire runneth therewith libro meth aristotle saith thunder coruscatio manner lightning séene aire sodainelye appearing shewing subtill vapour set fire shewing passeth vanisheth awaye ayre without comming downe earth another manner lyghtening called fulgur additiōlightening doth also melte yron burneth lawne silke scorcheth steshe swelleth bodyes beast men among trées laurell least blasted fulmine chap 15 lightening called fulmen vapour sette fire fast sadde falleth downe great swiftnesse strength lightening called fulgur lyghtening smiteth thirleth burneth thing toucheth multiplyeth cleaueth breaketh bodilye thing withstandeth isidore sayeth fulgurare ferire smite one saith manner lyghtening fulgur compownded subtill part element hath therof might strength pearcing thirling therefore isidore calleth manner lyghtening stroke darte heauen gendered bread greate vapoure compownded diuerse contrarie thing vapour arreared drawen vp set fire flame great strength fire shuft putte beating shoouing putting clowdes commeth downe greate violence hollownesse clowds wer firye stone lyghtening beaten together stone séene bright running ayre force strength burning flame though bée firye kinde yet violence moouing kinde fire hee compelled come mooue downeward beda saith comming downe hée setteth fire burneth hath name fulgur therefore isidore sayth also hée peareceth thirleth cleaueth renteth hée called fulmen hée sayth also burneth fire thinnesse mouing one earth wit bluntnesse contrariwise ye water taketh two earth darknesse thicknesse one fire wit moouing fire twice thinner aire thrice moouing foure time sharpe ye aire twice away sad clowds shake sea ouerthrow currey dakes harden clowdes driue downe hayle vnto earth selfe haue gotten brother open aire fielde striue struggle great indeuour middle aire doth ring shaking sixe leapeth ye hollow clowdes euen haue entered round hole ye earth haue fiercely set back vnder chinkes stir vp spirites make ye diuell stir set whole world shaking zephyrus ye west winde also called fauonius verye light bloweth ye west brething pleasantly cold moist thawing frost snow bringing forth grasse flower contrary eurus also termed subsolanus apeliotes breeder caterpillers c nutritiue doth change meate hearbs plant doth turne sensible flesh wherfore thing excesse qualitie propertie heat cold votonesse feare sorrow anger loue hatred passion vertue whether nature sometimes also act chance boldnesse harlot doe mooue prouoke qualitie passion vertue fire mooueth fire water moueth water bold person mooueth boldnesse knowen among phisitions yt braine helpeth braine lung lung fowles eagle liberall frée heart plinius saith pray taketh except great hunger shée eateth alone putteth forth common fowles follow first taketh owne portion parte therfore oft fowles follow eagle hope trust haue part hir pray pray taken sufficient self king taketh heed comint hée taketh bird next giueth among serueth therewith setteth neast two precious stone hée called achates one male female sayde maye bring foorth birdes without stone layeth neast precious stone called achates kéepe birdes venimous biting créeping worm plinius saith ye eagle called aquila hath name sharpnesse eien isidor wing little flesh therfore flight hée may well awaye trauaile comparison greatnesse bodie hath little flesh therefore hée hath much strength vertue also hée hath many feather therfore conteineth much lightnesse among fowles eagle vertue sight mightye strong eagle spirit sight temperate sharpe act deede séeing beholding sunne roundnesse circle without anye blemishing eyen sharpenesse sight except one manner kinde eagle aristotle calleth athat thinke long time bird bird flye flyeth giueth meate flyeth sometime taketh heede ready withstand foules come grieue noy hir bird aristotle toucheth li 6 gregory toucheth super iob said eagle hir young bird newly hatcht vnmightie take receiue defie great meat ye mother sucketh bloud fleeting humour pray holdeth mouth putteth bloud humour mouthes birdes féedeth lyght meat till bée strong able receiue take stronger meate héereto austen saith plinie also age eagle hath darknesse dimnesse eien heauinesse wing disaduantage taught kinde séeke well springing water flyeth vp asre farre may till full hot heat aire trauaile flight heate pore opened feather chased falleth sodeinlye well feather bee chaunged dimnesse eien wiped away purged taketh againe might strength also sayth eagle ageth bill wareth hard crooked vnneth may take meate disaduantage findeth remedy seeketh stone smiteth beateth stronglye bill cutteth charge bill receiueth meate might strength becommeth young againe plinius saith eagle fitteth rock trée setteth sight eyen cléernesse sunne casteth eien looketh hether thether espie pray else beholdeth owne clawes alway gall full medicinable done collirijs sharpeth sight helpeth dimnesse disease eien dioscorides saith constantine also hath propertyes lesse worthy praysed birde passing heate drynesse therefore bolde hardie wrathfull strong wrath body great drinesse arist sayth libro decimo sexto eagle enimy innocent bird foules pursueth clawes taketh birde smiteth head bell hath lowing voyce generally fearing fowles sight hering eagle foules kinde dreade also foules pray therefore plinius saith gentle fawlcon foules vnneth take prayes yt day heare eagle perchance commeth great dreade generally foules haue dread eagle taketh pray onely aire dread lesse ye eagle taketh praye ground least eagle yt taketh praye water foules dread ye eagle foules yt haue liuing conuersation water alonely eagle goeth much kind noblenesse eagle take pray aire earth eagle dreadeth vultur aristot li 15 saith eagle amachel dwelleth abideth nigh sea fast beside greate lake pond fedde birdes bée nigh sea come water happen sée vulture comming afearde flye water vulture hath rightsharpe sight flyeth alwaye place flush water ayre land vulture taketh anone eagle long water stifled ye eagle hath one foote close whole foote gander therwith ruleth selfe water commeth praye foote cloue foote full sharpe clawes taketh hir pray ye eagle fethers haue priuie fretting vertue plinius saith sayth yt eagle feather done set among feather wing bird corumpteth fretteth thema vvōderfull true secret approuedly tryed string made wolues guttes done put lute harpe among string made shéepes gut destroy fret corrumpe string made shéepes guttes bée set among lute harp saith also eagle loueth company voideth flyeth companie aristotle saith libro primo possible foules crooked clawes shoulde abide fellowes also eagle hath claw steed sworde therfore sitteth stone closeth clawes hideth within fleshe hée hurt neither smite stone aristotle saith li 13 foule crooked clawes bideth long vppon trées vpon stone kinde clawes contrary two thinges also right cruell owne bird theyr eien closed sun supposeth owne bird theyr eyen closed sunne also teach compell take praye birdes beateth woundeth hir bill plinius comforteth exciteth bée bolde hardye take pray least bee full age shoulde dull idle accustome themselues séeking meate bolde hardye courage beda sayth ambrose also hawkes bee théeues aire onelye earth onely eagle bee diuerse aristotle sayth sixt booke first manner hawkes take onelye flyeng birdes seconde manner hawkes smite réese birdes sit earth doues know knowe diuersitye eagle sayde accipiter hot fowle dry poore charge flesh addressed diuersitie penne feather fairenesse fethers like • stridge pere thereto boldnesse heart shée flyeth nowe vp aire swiftly high man see falleth sodeinly downe vpon pray breast sharpe couered little flesh thereof aristotle speaketh sayth lib 14 sharpe breast better shée flight full broad breast moue much aire shoulde slowe flight breast fleshie sharpe feeble couered much flesh said strength ye breast clawes hir bil ye soone taketh braine praie gall medicinable profitable medled colbrijs medicine eien sharpeth sight eien destroieth wasteth white speekles eien doth dirt also gosehauke hath propertie gregory saith age shée feeleth selfe grieued heauines waight feather spreadeth winges beames sun winde south sodeine weather resoluing heate pore opened pore opened smiteth flappeth winges dooing olde feather leape newe growe new fethers maketh better state able flight two kindes fowles tame wild tame taketh wilde fowles taketh owne lorde wild taketh tame foules accipiter disdaynous kinde shee fayle anye happe praye ryseth daye vnneth come lord hande must haue ordinate diet neyther scarse full much meate waxeth fat waxeth ramayous slowe disdayneth come reclaime meat scarce fayleth seeble vnmightye take praye also eyen birdes shoulde ofte siled closed hidde shee bate oft hand beareth seeth birde desireth take also legges must fastened ge shall flye freely euery birde borne lefte hand maye take righte hand fed therewith accipitres fame hawkes kepte mewes may discharged olde fethers hard renewed fairnesse youth also men giue meate manner flesh deale venemous may sooner change feather smoake grieueth hawkes doeth harme beda saith therfore mewes must far smoakie place body grieued bitternesse smoake fethers infect blacknesse smoake fed fresh flesh bloudye men vse giue eate ye hart foules take aliue strong mightie take pray beloued theyr lord borne handes set pearches stroken breast tayle made plaine smoothe norished great businesse diligence dead men holde vnprofitable nothing worth eaten rather throwen dounghills alieto cap 3 hali • etusas glose saith super deutro 14 alietus fawcon one bird coueteth praye right bolde hardie assaileth birdes foules much greater réeseth smiteth breast féete men meane alietus little bird taketh small bird thereof speaketh auctour aurora saith sparrowe hauke hobbie merlin obtinet exiguas seemeth alietus little sparrow hawke one called musket french el called sperhawke bee cap 4 isidore saith bées called ape gendred without feature knit themselues together féete isidore sayeth bée
