water reatins hoofes cl •• beast made hard said lake called affaltides lake iurie nothing may sinke hath lyfe soule also euen pond nothing fleeteth sinketh drowned also concidie lake three daye bitter ofte fresh sweete isid telleth foresayd booke diuersitie pit water lake water commeth diuers qualitie veynes earth ground water passeth el kinde disposition ground water gathered ¶of lake asphalti ca 13 lake called lacus asphalti also called dead sea greatnesse deepnesse breedeth receiueth nothing hath lyfe therfore hath neither fish foules whensoeuer thou woldest haue drowned therin thing hath lyfe crast gin anone plungeth commeth vp though strongly thrust downward anone smitten vpward moueth winde glewe withstandeth winde stormes glew water • nt therin may ship row sayle thing hath life sinketh ground sustaineth kinde bée glewed lanterne without light sinketh therein telleth lanterne light fléeteth aboue place called lacus asphalti place glew called mare salinarum iurie betwéene iericho zachan length thereof stretcheth euen zoroas arabia vii c lxxx furlong length bredth thereof stretcheth c furlong v que vicina sodomorum huc v que isid lib 13 ca 3 de lacu stagnis master saith historijs 3 ca de subuersione sodomorū sine lake casteth vp blacke clot glewe therefore called lacus asphaltides brim thereof trées grow apple wherof gréene till ripe ye cut ripe ye shall finde ash within thereof iosephus saith fabula terrae sodomorum fidem c sayd glosa super 2 pe ca super locum illum ciuitates sodomorum cinerem redigens seruare voluit dominus regionem contra positam speciem pressione pene growe faire apple make men sée thē haue liking eate one take fade fall ash smoke though burning additiō asphaltites asphaltum lake syria called mare mortuum therein lime mixt wt brimstone called bitumen asphaltum wherein liuely thing drowne suppose place stood city sodoma gomorrha ¶of lake tiberiadis ca 14 lake called tiberiadis lacus hath name towne called tiberiadis somtime herod builded worship tiberius emperour lake pond greatest healthful wholsome lake iury spéedfull cause health stretcheth lx furlong isidore saith lib 13 additiō tiberias citie galilee iesus passed ouer sea gallilee sea tiberias fed 5000 foules 5 barly loaues 2 fish iohn 6 ¶of pond genesar cap 15 pond called genesar said greatest lake iudea stretcheth c lx furlong length lx bredth crispe water calme strong winde crispe themselues genesar word gréeke gendering calme wether selfe lake yt stretch great space long moued ofte blowing winde wether therefore ye water therof ye fresh swéete able dronke huc v que isid lake greatnesse oft called sea gospell sea séemeth great water commeth iordan glose saith super io ca 6 hebrues vse call gathering water sea therefore oft called sea additiō genezareth great mere pond ye land promission called also mare tyberiadis whereon christ walked dry land called peter comforting disciple thought bene spirite math 14 mar 6 pond cap 16 pond called piscina water gathered féeding fish though oft gathering water without fish called piscina contrary meaning isi saith goodnesse pond néedeth sadnes ground also néedeth cleannes water runneth commeth therto continuall running comming wheras ground fennie mirie ther well sauored fish may norished wher fresh water runneth cōmeth standing water soone corrupt therfore renew refresh pond fresh water led brought gutter conduit pipe head pondes strengthned wt bank wall water shuld passe soone also pondes haue streames water moyst garden orchard also néere pond trées hearbes fruitfull ¶of riuus lake cap 17 lake called riuus hath name rigando wetting moisting isidore saith well lake stremes led wet moyst garden lake hath kind effect welspring head well running lake come riuers lake anselme sayth lake washeth cleanseth oft vncleannesse maketh earth plenteous giueth drinke beast foules nourisheth saueth gréennesse vertues hearbes flower draweth small stone grauell ¶of fluctu wallowing cap 18 sea vvaueswallowing sea called fluctus hath name flutu blowing blast putting shouing windes water moued shuft ouer part therof mooueth alway called vnda waue hath name vnda eundo going passing continually moueth resteth neuer isi sayth li 13 wallowings sea smiteth together shoueth putteth vpward downwarde oft smiting together gendreth himselfe medleth himselfe grauell diuers particle ground bereth vpward putteth shoueth fish amendeth maketh better swiftnes mouing comming windie aire wallowing sea ariseth swelleth moueth vpward downward swift putting shouing wind moueth shoueth aire smiting together bréedeth winde beareth vp ship putteth cliffes brim beareth holdeth straight maketh sound noise alway mouing may rest eyther faileth ful moueth sheddeth himselfe whoorlepits cap 19 whoorlpit called gurgis déep place riuer hath name gutture throat isid saith swalloweth water yt come thereto throweth vp againe déepenesse moueth rounde whirling rebounding therfore swimmer oft perished also fish hide themselues whoorlepooles vnneth taken come whoorlepoole ¶of streames chap 20 streame taketh ye first course straight continuall water riuer commeth well head leaueth chanell way beginneth run well head runneth continually within boundes chanel til come sea diggeth wasteth owne ground couenable row saile feedeth nourisheth great fish cōmonly streame hath fresh water cleane ground runneth swiftlye part ye riuer therfore draweth beareth forth ship boates full swiftly bundels trées wood therefore hath name trames traho trahis transmitto transmittis bring send hée draweth swiftly thing set therin bringeth ouer fresh streame owne course swift swift beareth forth draweth thing alluuione cap 21 manner running water hath two name latine one alluuio ni name alluuies priuie still rising water hath name abluendo drawing washing washeth earth passeth breaketh thereof wasteth therefore vnderhoaling vndercréeping wasting vnder brimmes bée hoaled hollow water called alluuio iob 14 said vndercréeping priuy running water earth wasted lyttle little strong running course passeth priuie hollownes brim cliffes perillouslye destroyeth wasteth sadnesse thereof part brim outward séemeth sure sad without destroying wasting thereof séene within therefore foote slideth sooner treadeth therein inward sadnesse wasted priuie hollownesse hid vnknowen seneca saith deepnesse cap 22 abyssus déepnesse water vnséene thereof come spring well riuers déepnes come water turne againe thereto priuy way mother water isidore saith li 13 therefore abyssus said abuisus vnséene sight déepnesse thereof may séene abyssus sayd sine abisso without cléerenesse farnesse well lyght without hightinesse fairnesse lyght iohn damascene sayth abissus nought el much water ende deepnesse thereof vnséene shining light stretcheth reacheth ende therof el abissus said wer sine base bottomlesse ground thereof séene eye therefore primordiall first matter beginning world ye beginning distinguished certaine forme called abyssus austen would meane therfore li confessionum 12 saith abyssus bodely thing god made bée matter bodely thing matter forme shape without order without light abyssus thing materia prima first matter austen saith li de symbolis saith name abissus holye writ called approued matter made nought first taker receiuer shape ordinate gift god therof thing hath shape forme shoulde bée shaped formed matter named water fleeting running mouing also taketh receiueth manner formes shape likewise called earth kindly stedfastnes sadnesse subiect generation corruption called abyssus vnshapefulnesse distinguished forme shape called water ablenesse take vpon forme shape ablenesse might take manner forme shape qualitie aust saith also abissus yt déepnesse water hath selfe dimnesse déepnesse receiueth water lycour runneth thereto hath neuer inough taketh neuer much water may take maye neuer stopped laued emptied cōmunicable sea cap 23 sea called mare gathering water fresh salt isid saith lib 13 hath properly name mare water therof bitter sayd innermore sayd sea called eqoor hath ye name equalitie euennes euen plaine though wallowing waues sea wallowe arise mountaines hils yet ye tempest ceaseth sea plaine againe saith psa 89 thou rulest raging sea addition thou stillest waues therof arise ver 10 also sea called pelagus pellens vndas putting water waues sea continuall moouing putting waues stormes also saith though ye sea receiueth water wels riuers yet great comming water sea neuer ye sea great water run therto séene el bitter water destroyeth wasteth running water clowdes draw much water winde beareth thereof away sunne dryeth swéetnes water dryed clensed turneth priuie hole commeth oft head wels riuers huc vsque isidorus li 13 ambrose sayth basilius exameron sea gathering water multiplyed diuers place name continuation one sea alway mouing sounding foming followeth kinde moone flowing reflowing whose vertue influence led sea head receipt riuers fountaine shower thing whereby people farre sunder may come together sea helpeth néede succour perills spéedeth passenger shortnesse wayes furthereth profite winning traffike trauaylyng men also libro metheororum aristotle sayth sea head wel water dispersed sea cause sea bitter salt two vapour one moyst drye subtill watrie vapour moist thin subtill partes wasted mouing sunne thicker part abideth made hot salt bitter heate sun sweate vrine burning thing made bitter earthy part abide watry moystie partes consumed wasted bitternesse strength burning commeth saltnesse doth ash water soaketh ash salte cod li arist saith salte water sea heauie thicke fresh water sea water grose fresh water subtill thinne token thereof know egge fléeteth salte water sinketh downe fresh water ship falling fresh water sinketh déeper salte water therfore dead sea sinketh beast gendred therein drinesse hath masterie also li de animalibus saith sea water saltnesse may drawen thereof man take vessell earth new rawe closeth mouth thereof throweth emptie sea leaueth ther day night fresh water shall come therein also li metheorum sayth fresh water riseth vpward freshnesse lightnesse salt water falleth downward heauines salt abideth earth swéet thereof woseth also li de elementis sayth sea working followeth kinde moone knowen alway moone ariseth anye time daye night sea country wher moone ariseth stretcheth selfe withstandeth course riuers runne thereto shoueth beareth againe ye riuer water toward place commeth shouing violence moone lower course water beginneth wane ebbe ye moone ariseth water beginneth wexe flow yron followeth adamant stone sea foloweth course kinde moone séeke li 8 ca 29 also rising starre called canicula sea wexeth thick changeth colour gréene blewe troublous cléere wexing moone occean holdeth order first day wexing moone copious time sea full high thereafter abateth lesseneth second day downeward day euen seuenth day sea last default ground ebbe beginneth againe spring euen till vii day moone xiiii day olde full agayne sea full highest spring beginneth breake wane vadeth vii dayes moone xxi day olde sea againe lowest ebbe yet springeth increseth vii dayes moone xxviii dayes olde sea againe highest spring alway euery month ye sea changeth foure time breaking springing twice increasing twice decreasing moone wexeth waneth alwaye sea highest strength moone full shining either toward heauen new moone el toward earth doth full moone moone profiteth falleth taking loosing hir light sea ariseth abateth ebbing flowing also li vegitabilium arist saith ground shore sea hard sad grauelly token saltnesse sea vpon grauell therin dry earthy part haue mastry salt existence water dealeth clay wose owne part therefore earth nigh sea grauellous among grauell sea oft diuers precious stone vertue bred gendred made faire clene froting grauel cast lande cliffes mouing waues ye sea yet beside property sea bee property knowen nigh men yet simple men thinke good recken heere arowe haue matter shewe hidden priuie thing simple men ensample likenes property sea cleanseth selfe throweth selfe carrens vncleane thing smiteth putteth vncleane dead strength mouing gregory saith also sea sheddeth selfe full priuie veynes déepnesse giueth alway water flowing well riuers ierome saith super eccl also ye sea bringeth forth wonderfull beastes fish wonderfullye shapen many manner formes shape ye sea bringeth forth wonderful beast wonderful thing doth ye land rabanus saith super eccl 43 said yt passing noble wonderfull workes diuers beast c additiō item psa 104 ver 20 lord manifold thy workes wisdome hast made ye earth full thy rich great wide sea also wherin thing créeping innumerable small great beast go ye ship leuiathan thou hast made take pastime therein waite vppon thée thou mayst giue meate due season thou giuest thē gather thou openest thy hand filled good thou hidest thy face troubled thou takest away breth dye turned againe dust thou lettest thy breach goe foorth shall made thou shalt renue face earth also though sea substanciallye soft running yet bringeth foorth hard thing lyfe without lyfe doth shell fish fish hard skin shell stone commonly precious sea casteth vp lande also though sea bee able neither lyking dronk touching sauor tast yet ful profitable effect saueth healeth many sickness heleth men dropsie botch pimple whelkes scabbes many euills constantine saith also though sea selfe salt bitter yet swéetnesse veynes earth passeth changeth sauour taketh freshnes swéetnes clensing drieng earth ye passeth macrobius saith aristotle also also sea neuer vnsaurryt bitter yet nourisheth féedeth full fresh fish sea hath priuye swéetnesse freshnesse sea fish sucketh taketh whereof commeth couenable feeding saueur ambrose sayth also sea mouable without rest owne mouing keepeth saueth owne substance perill corruption continuall • ro •• ing made cléere therein kept perill corruption rotteth also though bée running standing selfe neuerthelesse stinted held thing passeth easily ouer bond cliffes sayde prouerb 8 iere 5 iob 38 also bitternesse saltnes swalloweth withdraweth freshnesse well running water farther running water ye entering ye sea fresh helde also beating smiting together armes beclippeth lande breedeth gendreth contrary windes beda sayth also noifull vsed therin breedeth dread feare head ach spuing bolking withdraweth appetite meate drink also vaporation fumosities casteth vpwarde breedeth mist clowds maketh dimnesse darknesse aire taketh v ye beames sun bateth heat therof also though haue coulour owne chaungeth colour quality wind nowe whitish yeolowish white cleere black isidore saith l ••• 13 also sea conteineth selfe many perills little blast winde sea tempest stormes therfore sea called fretum isi saith hauing feruent strong mouing fareth sea yt called mare cicilium ye sea feruētnes mouing making noise criengscilla daungeion rock sea cicil vvhere came vvord decid 1 scylla cariens vita 〈…〉 scilla caribdis said scilla caribdis two perillous place sea many shippes bée soone perished scilla great high rocke sea hauing many rock head waues sea beate theron maketh horrible noise ship fall therin wise escape perill wrack caribdis called swalloweth shippes many priuy swallowes ther ye sea ful swalows wer flowing selfe whirling turning winding therfore draweth ship swalloweth drowneth thrice daye casteth vp great wallowing waues swalloweth thrice day swongeth water swalloweth casteth vpward may swallow isidore saith lib 13 capitulo de estibus mari et fretis also sea another notable peril vneuennesse ground water ful déep one place another thereby vnneth water wade perill called cutis grauell gathered heapes cutis greeke vnderstand draught papias saith yt sea aegypt many cutis bée meddeled therewith sooth passing sea perillous priuie rockes hidde vnder water also heapes grauell drawen gathered togethers p •• ce shippes hassely broke another peril called bithalassum shippe laded smiteth ground hath much glow slime wose may deliuer self neither passe therof toughnesse holding slime wose hugo saith bithalassum slime ouerhid print left slime wose glose saith bithalassum méeting two sea maister historia sayth bithalassum called ye tongue ye earth straight hether thether beclipped sea called bithalassum sea departed earth betweene two part sea thalassum greeke vnderstoode sea shippe smiteth bithalassum foreshippe abideth still mooueth hinder shippe broken behinde strong swiftnesse sea falleth thereon ouertaketh maister sayth ¶also generally men passe sea perill aire winde sea sea many stone rockes hidde bée set beclipped greate rock passed without perill ground vneuen areared high heapes grauell nowe déepe swallowe eft passage let sea aboue troubly high wind stormes waues beting smiting togethers stormes • wallowings wallowe vpward downeward perill sayle oft time ship broken drowned contrary stormes also perill commeth wether troubly dim misty ful perillous passe sea namelye shippe sodeinlye driuen perillous place perill knowen also huge great windes dread namely bée contrary windes arise perill dread breaking shippe ship moued put toward hauen blowing one wind driuen put toward peril strength another strong winde contrarye else helde long time daunger lost betwéene contrary wallowings waues also perill commeth féeblenesse shippe charged perill safe saile shippe boate lyttle féeble broke clouen shippe boate safe among stormes waues wilde sea lyttlenesse thereof ouerthrowne ouerturned stormes waues ye wilde sea féeblenesse broke strong blast windes sunke drowned water commeth chin hole namely ship commeth slowlye late ye hauen namely good marriners lacke ship perill sea shippe hath vnready gouernour vnaduised manner perills manye men saile ye sea middle earth occean isidore sayth gréekes latines call sea occean beclippeth ye roundnesse earth circle occean goeth sphéere wée dwell hath name oceanus swiftnesse passeth goeth swiftly ye earth shineth manner coulour red gréene called oceanus ceanus circle heauen isidore sayth lib 13 sea occean beclippeth hemmes land oft commeth goeth ebbing flowing blowing windes oceanus remooueth sea bloweth vp though one sea continuaunce thereof yet coast countryes taketh diuerse name landes countryes bée next thereto french sea french men british sea briton eaddish sea hath name gades entering great sea occean opened hercules came thether set pillar trowing supposing ende earth huc vsque isid li 13 additiō sea water doth make powdered flesh fresh fresh flesh sauourie mari magno meditaraneo chap 25 greate sea middle earth commeth west occean passeth towarde south goeth toward north called ye great sea sea little comparison thereof called ye sea middle earth passeth middle earth euen east departeth dealeth thrée partes earth called asia africa europa first coast called sinus iuspauicus hibericus balearicus coast passeth coast nerbon called gallicus followingly coast called ligusticus passeth ye citie geen next thereto coast called tirrenus stretcheth italy coast called siculus passeth cecilia lande crete stretcheth pamphilia aegypt coast helespontum passeth diuers turning bendeth northward last beside greece illiricum waxeth narrowe straightnesse seauen furlings passeth sea called ponticum waxeth straight maketh sea called propontides straightnesse 50 pace made called bothorus tratius place called propontides commeth ye sea yt called ponticum place called bophorus hath name straight passage narrow way rothexen isi saith li 13 frō thence passeth spreadeth greatest coast yt called ponticus hath behind marreis yt called paludes meotides cause many riuers fresh water come therto sea fresh mistie hath great fish fish yt called foca fish called delphinus earth though one hath diuers name bicause diuers place greate sea hath diuerse name diuers country land huc vsque isid li 13 great coast sea called sinus hath diuers name sea middle earth one coast called ionicus hath name io king greece men athens called iones therfore sea called ionicum stretcheth frō ionia cecilia euen sea occean greatest coast caspius indicus persicus arabicus called red sea sea called red sea coloured red water waues kinde dyed taketh coulour bank red grauel sand nigh therto earth nigh sea red coulour nigh bloud therin found sharp uermilion diuers colour serue painture earth hath kind sea made red beating water waues vpon ye cliffes therfore cliffes red precious stone found small stone ground wrapped among ye grauell sea ground kéepe still coulour sea departed two coast one called persicus east perses dwell west side called arabicus arabees dwell isidore saith li 13 pelago chap 26 pelagus bredth sea without cliffe without hauen isidore saith hath déepnesse vnstablenesse continuall moouing gendereth féedeth whale diuers wonderful fish bréedeth many vapor fumosities hath therof thicknesse mist taketh many diuersities coulours diuersities windes gathereth fome smiting beating waues crieth maketh great noise crieng sea vnpeaceable perillous sayd sea drop cap 27 drop right little part sea water raine departed violence whole called gutta standeth hangeth euesings trées wer beglewed isid saith drop falleth called stilla thereof commeth stillicidum falling drop drop whether called stilla gutta departed frō watry clowde vertue heat strength winde falleth downwarde owne heauinesse weight drop called stilla falleth gutta standeth hangeth drop hanging falling standing substaunce cléere round shape little quantity great vertue moisteth earth falleth vpon maketh plenteous fruitfull féedeth nourisheth root séeds maketh grow quickneth saueth gréenenesse tree hearbes grasse féedeth nourisheth fish sea maketh oyster fat bréedeth pearl precious stone isidore saith namely drop dewe though drop soft yet oft falling pearceth thing right hard verse sayth gutta cauit lapidem non vi sed sepe cadendo drop pearceth stone strength oft falling foame cap 28 foame called spuma hath name foamed skimmed isidore saith gendered corruption water therefore shoulde thing sod water bée skimmed purged foame foame commeth gendered winde closed ouer part water moued māner mouing therfore lightnesse aire closed therein water foamèth foame fléeteth aboue water foame soone gendered beating together water waues soone departed sparyled sometime foame sea gathered among stone feruent working heate sunne falleth thereon made hard turneth sometime pomise sometime spunge additiō pomise stone commonly blacke gray hollowe like hunny combe spunge soft hollowe much like lung beast serue diuerse purpose fish chap 29 fish called pisces hath name pascendo feeding isidore sath libro 12 cap 6 fish licketh earth watry beach get meate nourishing also bée called reptilia créeping swimming séeme créepe swimming créepe though sinke downe bottome wherof speaketh ambrose exameron sayth betwéene fish water greate nighnesse kinred without water may long liue liue long onelye breathing without drawing water haue manner lykenesse kinde créeping fish swimmeth shrinking drawing together bodye hée draweth gathereth himselfe lesse length anone stretcheth himselfe againe intendeth passe forth water dilligence hée putteth water backwarde passeth selfe forward therefore vseth fin swimming soule vseth fethers flieng wise swimming fish moueth fin ye hinder part downeward armes ore clippeth water holdeth stretcheth himselfe forward bird moueth fethers vpward gathereth aire compelleth passe backward large stretching windes violent putting aire backward body moueth forward kindes fish bée diuerse many manner wise diuersitie place bee gendered meate fedde coulour shape distinguished substaunce compounded vertue worke diuerslye place gendered greate diuersitie dwelling abiding builde onely water sometime dwelleth land somtime water manner fish isidore sayth called antiphidia dubia latine vseth goe land swim water holdeth office kinde fish called foce cocodrilli castores hippotami water horse fish haue name land beastes sea houndes wolues bite vnreasonable swallowing deuouring hurteth sore isidore saythas torteises crabbes among abide onely water abide onelye sea riuers pond fresh water meane betwéene two manner fisheslopsters creifishes turne come fresh water salt water get meatea • sturgeon salmon fish come salt water fresh haue liking freshnesse thereof fatted againe warde fish abideth seathe seal lampray tench carpe likevvise hadocke blinde ye fresh vvater cunger thertly die nowe fresh water many riuer fish may tast saltnesse sea catcheth salt water hée dyeth sodeinelye tourneth wombe fléeteth aboue water token death manner fish sea fresh water fish bred sea hath harde scale thicke drinesse salt water riuer fish haue subtill scale soft backe bone backe bone fish bee needfull restraine flesh thereof fleeting kinde softnesse thereof auicen teacheth choose good fish kinde place wherein nourished sedde liber 2 cap 7 sayth manner choice fish place dwelleth abide stony place bée best swéetest fresh running water corruption slime wose standing lake welles small pittes runne riuers well hée sayth sea fish bée good bée subtill bée best bée nourished deepe sea else fish abide water bee vnhéeled blastes winde bloweth water somtime frō better bée serued water strongly mooued continually laboured bee better bée standing water sea fish better riuer fish riuer fish better lake fish namely farre riuer sea haue rest rottennesse filth washed neither cleansed riuer cō meth therein sea therefore fish euill sauoured soone rotten also sea fish riuer fish better north sea east sea south sea strong blast winde water moued cleansed made subtill therefore fish water mooueth trauaileth cleansed superfluitie also kinde fish diuersity onely diuersitie place may dwell also diuerse place generation gendered layeng eggesrovv melt shedding pesen gendering together male female shedding sperme héereof aristotle speaketh li 5 sayth falleth kinde fish lay egges pesen female layeth egges pesen male commeth sheddeth milke vpon egges egges pesen bee touched milke male shall fish touched milke shall fish female layeth many egges pesen swalloweth part also many bée spilt slime wose none thereof bée saued bée layde place milke male shedde saued bée many fish gendred fish kéep saue euennesse make owne kinde aristotle sayth saith neuer fish founde made generation fish kinde also fish loue frye féede nourish long time aristotle sayth fish feede kéepe young except frogges also sayde riuer fish fish marrcis shedde theyr pesen ofter fish commonly parte cast shed pesen milke fiue moneths fish bring foorth fish one yeare small fish bring forth broode place wherein little water fast rootes tree cane reedes also saith part pesen lost female sheddeth pesen swimming male present séede pesen fish shapen also eat fish bird also saidfeles grovve devv may aire fish gendered without egges pesen without generation male female gendered slime wose grauell rottennesse yt vpon water also sayd time generation male female generation betwéene male femaleephemeron beast riuer hyppanis hath liued thrée houres day dieth fish called murena lampraythis likely fourtie •• th spaune like conceiueth adder hée calleth loue unneth dyeth though shée bee smit staffe smit rod dieth anone certaine soule fish ye taile say vnneth slain though smit head smit taile taile bée smitte dyeth anone sayde contrary serpent head bee broke brused cut ye serpent dieth anone taile smitten liueth long time also iorath sayth serpent doth awaye venim ere gender lampray deed generation done taketh venim againe therfore conceiuing lampraye taketh venim serpent gendereth serpent kinde onely owne kinde saith additiōthe adder venimous body spearme snake also fish conceiue dew onely without peson without milk oisters shell fish hée bloweth wombe maketh stare throweth fish wombe stretcheth mouth hath stomacke also fish diuersitie time place meate fish séeke theyr meate onelye water night vpon land hippotamus water horse hath sayth bée hunted sun rise fisher set theyr net time fish see full well sée light increaseth night seeke theyr meate smelling haue lyking thing good sauour therefore liber 4 sayd kindes fish smell heare therefore commeth ofter new tackle set olde commeth lightly olde tackle newe bee oft beguiled smell iorath sayth hée sayeth great fish sea called belua casteth water iawes vapour good smell fish feele smell follow enter come iawes following smel swalloweth sed also saith fish called faste ye water taketh mouth wareth swéete small fish follow go mouth taketh sodeinly swalloweth anone also hee saith dolphin know smel dead man yt sea eate euer dolphin kinde dead man hath eaten therof eateth anone hee kéepeth defendeth frō eating biting fish shoueth bringeth cliffe owne wroting aristotle anker least smitten away throwen waues sea saueth himselfe strength helpeth saue himselfe heauinesse weight owne made stedfast stable comming tempest storme ship men see beware ouer set vnwarilye tempest stormes ambrose saith beda also also li 4 aristotle saith female fish long male fish haue harde fish male harde also aboue female harde behinde beneath also lib 2 auicen sayth fish best haue full grease bodyes neither harde fish drye whome great fatnesse much griffle whome euill smell euill sauour sweete sauour conuenient couenable fat superfluitie fatnesse sowrenesse stinketh anon cōmeth water fish somewhat harde bée better bée salted among fish harde fish best least soft fish diuersitie knowen substaunce qualitye saith generally fish cold moist yet bée hotter comparison complection fish namely salte therefore fresh breede watrye fleame softe sinewes according right hot stomackes salted according stomacke also medicine head salte fish burnt healeth biting madde dogge stinging scorpion rooteth vp dead flesh botch helpeth rotted festured botch also iuyce euerye fish helpeth venim dronken venimous stinginges hath many effectes sayde sayde theyr qualitye substaunce shall suffice place ¶also fish bée diuerse sharpnesse feeling sleyght witte many warye wonderfully sleight wily scape ware gin fisher isidore saith lib 12 saith manner fish called mugil full nimble swist disposed swimme ware grin pearceth beset fisher turneth sodeinly backward ouerleapeth net swiftly seemeth present flieth bird mugil sea fish scaled fish swiftest coulour white hauing great belly gréedinesse vnsatiable full lyeth still one place béeing afrayde hideth head whole body also hidden desirous others kinde fisher hauing gotten male fish sort fastned line craft female resorte vnto taken lykewise doth male greekes called cestrei plotae cephali also lyke wise sayd fish called estaurus among fish onelye fish cheweth kudde sayd fish right wittye knoweth hee entered within daunger fisher ginne hée reeseth foorth headlong neyther putteth head betweene rowles gunne beateth fast tayle beginneth make away breaking renting roddes pasieth backwarde happen another fish kinde seeth trauaileth break busieth helpe taketh tayle mouth helpeth hée maye drawe deliuer ginne yet sayth cunger hath manye wile wittye wylye getting meate hee seeth meate hooke hee dreadeth hooke biteth baite holdeth hooke sinnes letteth passe till hée haue gnawen meate ¶also crabbe enimye oyster hee liueth fish thereof wonderfull witte hee may open harde shell oyster hée spyeth awayteth oyster openeth crabbe lyeth waite taketh little stone putteth betweene shelles oyster maye close himselfe closing let crabbe eateth gnaweth fish oyster oyster bee called oilica haue name shelles defend warde softe small tree bush grow thereon great fish séemeth ilande shippe men come vnwarily thereby vnneth scape without perill hée throweth much water mouth vpon shippe ouerturneth somtime drowneth also hée faste hée smit fisher dartes feeleth wounde passeth fatnesse inner fish wounded easily takē hée may suffer bitternesse salt water therefore draweth shoare warde also hée huge quantitie taken countrey better takingof whale flesh commeth train oile vvhich rich merchandise also loueth whelpes wonderfull loue leadeth sea long time hapneth whelpes bée let heapes grauell defaut water hée taketh much water mouth throweth vppon deliuereth wise perill bringeth againe déepe sea defende hée putteth al thing hée meeleth bée noyfull setteth alway betwéene himselfe sunne safer side strong tempest ariseth harping yrons hook fish reported ye best great fish yt flesh cut hardly discerned béefe colour raw tast soddē wil abide pondring salt béefe doth young fish eat like veale sweet delicate also ye xiii ¶incipit liber xiiii de terra et eivs partibvs help grace god ye treatise ful ended property ouermost shining body heauen middle shining cléere body fire aire water last speak property ye lowest body yt sad dim general speciall lowest body vttermost comparison heauen earth whose cōmon property somwhat shall say worke touching ye quality substance conteining ornamēt therof earth conteineth ornamēt within quarry dare al groweth vnder ground stone mettal wherfore without conteineth thing yt know sée beast trées hearbs grasse som shal set treatise séemeth holy writ maketh minde therof simple mē thinke yt inough set héere simple thing yt wel nigh men know therfore héereof shall somwhat rehearse giue greater thing greater men beginning worke make protestation yt set héere little right naught héere shall set rowe authoritie holye saint philosopher haue done bookes earth chap 1 éarth set middle space world like farre part heauen called terra latine betokeneth ye roundnesse earth ye singular number ye part therof plural number isi saith saith earth called terra hath ye name ouer part que teratur yt trode called humus also hath ye name sea moist ioyned thereto called tellus take fruit therof called ops heapeth fruit called arida able cared tilled distinguished frō water owne drines moist hath moisture water yt nigh therto isi saith basilius ex describeth ye property ye earth saith manner earth ye lowest body middle like far part heauen therfore wise men call ye middle heauen amōg al body earth corpulent hath least subtilty simplicitie foundation ye world colde drie kind least quantitie cō parison heauen though selfe qualitie obscure selfe darke round shape abiding together glew water whole earth resteth though part thereof moue often habitation body haue life called stoole god owne foote esa 66 saith lord heauen seate earth footstole mat 5 say vnto sweare neither heauen god seate yet earth footstoole fairenesse element least ye body ye world ye working ye might god least seene therein therfore said yt god toucheth ye earth lowest foot comparison greatnesse fairenesse heauen séemeth highnesse wisdome god sheweth least ye body earth though earth lowest cōmparison ye body heauen yet neuerthelesse taketh influence ye light heauen therfore plenteous mother al bringeth sorth many diuers contrary kind yt ye middle heauen taketh euery side influence effect heauen ye séemeth lacke therin nobility substāce recouerd effect vertue manner bringeth forth noble kind doth heauē yt high star sée high • ne earth conceiueth bringeth forth creature life féeling reason basi saith also heereto saith ye philosopher saith ye earth euen way owne weight euery part thereof busieth owne weight come middle ye earth busieng inclination partes ye whole earth hangeth euen weight aboue middle point euenly held vnmouable written psa 19 heauens declare glorie god firmament sheweth glorious worke psa 24 earth lord therin cōpasse world dwell therin hath sounded vpon sea established vpon flouds thou hast founded ye earth vpon stablenesse c therefore li 12 isi calleth ye earth solum sad element bereth vp ye elemēts euery body neuer heuie therfore heuy thing yt aboue earth without rest til come earth stedfast stable rest come earth worthy property noble effectes earth errour nation faineth earth god indéede therefore old time reuerence worship therto isidore toucheth li 8 tractat • de dijs gencium nominibus cap •• saith olde time men called earth cere mother god hath name fruites bringeth foorth defendeth nourisheth néedeth meate drink ye earth mother plentie nothing liue may grow rooted maured substaunce earth also called ops rich earth better rich also earth euerye creature liue hath rich meate liuelode also called vesta goddesse either standeth stedfast clothed wt trées hearbs grasse saith ye earth taketh colour séedes leaues grasse wither fade winter wether springing time summer clothed hid grasse hearbes floures spoyled thereof haruest winter signe token great plentie great female image made called alma mater ye high mother ye image crowned wt tower set chaire lion followed wer subiect hir hare key ye one hand taber timbrell hand hir charemen brandished swordes bare hande fayned cockes followed good wife sate chaire ye earth called mother bringeth forth many thing bréedeth meate foode thing el dye called mater alma high mother féedeth beast nourisher element isid saith said beareth hir head crowne wt tower ye earth adorned many great city borough bée builded therevpon borne chaire wheeles ye earth hangeth aire moueth sustained therein sitteth moouing chaire though thing moue sayd onely earth mooueth lyon mylde subiect image earth vnderstand euery kinde though neuer sie • ce cruell time • eath shall ouercome subiect earth beareth key hir hand betokeneth ye earth cloased winter opened springing time fruit may grow sp ••• g said ye cock serue ye earth sheweth birdes fod • le • éed seedes earth therefore fowles néede follow earth lyght downe finde therein séedes ••• sound noyse 〈…〉 betokeneth tillyng field noise instrument culture shar • e mattockes brasse olde time earth filled instrument brasse • yron found isidore saith hir seruaunts segned girt sword betokeneth ofte defende winne earth lande warre battaile swordes drawen therein maner many property earth described mystike meaning fable sayd rehearsed isidore though earth among element stable sayd rehearsed yet effect dooing passible element also though colde substance yet conteineth selfe firie vapour come therof doth hil named aetna vulcanus sayth also though earth bée blacke vnséemly without yet within containeth many precious thing imprinting influence heuen ye inner veynes ye earth gendred precious stone noble mettall vertue ye earth hid within likeness without also ye earth beclipped sea beset beate armes thereof priuy way thirled moisture sea least earth partes thereof fall powder masterie drinesse beda sayeth also though whole earth founde sad substaunce thereof yet euery part thereof moueth kindly towarde middle point meddeling firie airie part earth part thereof hollow dim spoungie smokie windie vapor commeth hollownesse thereof shaketh moueth part earth bréedeth earth quaking ari saith lib metheor colde winde saith moued wombe earth maketh mouing yt called earth quaking followeth noyse sound commeth diuers beating froting aire body together therein noise sound commeth diuers shaking mouing windes hid earth thereof token resteth till ye earth cleaue winde voyce issueth c aristotle saieth also place strong concourse running ye sea mouing waues place much thinnesse earth strong earth shaking fell hercules time ilandes earth began rise bene hill place cloue came great wind destroied great citie whereof remaineth remembraunce day also sayth eueth shaking commeth maner dimnesse hideth sunne clowdes earth shaking dureth reason darke vapor great earth quake commeth token sheweth comming long clowde straight line séene heauen going downe sun said somtime earth quake commeth eclipse moone ye heat sunne commeth ayre make cléere wast vapor cause earth shaking also li de vegitabitibus aristotle saith earth shaking grauely place place many dennes within hardnes without place hill mountaines place hard sad without vapour issueth passeth little little much vapour gathereth together yt strong inough mooue earth place hollow full dennes hole within sad hard without part vapour gathered together strong shaking sometime cleaneth • enteth earth place full hole falleth lightly earth shaking reason vapor passe continually neither place full harde sadde maye much vapour enter straightnesse place partes falleth place hollowe within harde sadde without huc vsque aristot also earth element whole earth lyke substaunce part therof qualitie ye earth diuersly disposed diuers part chaungeth complection kinde medlyng qualyties element one manner disposition chaungeth colour sauour diuersitie commeth many manner cause many manner wise sometime highnesse lownesse high place aboue low beneath ouer place hot neather macrobius saith printing sun beames strong low place thā high aire thicke valleyes mountaines therefore valleyes gathering sun beames hurtling smiting great aire thitke mountaines hill aire thin cléere therefore beames sparpled fast helde together lesse heate gendred also diuers taking sunne beames taketh strong sunne beames plenteous fruitfull land far sunne beames lesse able beare fruite corne also diuersitie kinde wind land eastern wind bloweth continually temperate hot meane betwéene moyst dry constant saith therefore land full plenteous bearing flower fruite corne couenable habitation mankinde therefore westerne winde longeth coldenes moysture maketh land lesse temperate therefore westerne winde lesse plenteous northern winde drieth cooleth land yet reson cleane aire maketh subtil pure north men high stature faire shape outward aire pore stopped kinde heate helde within vertue whereof stature great shape body faire seemelye sothern winde hot moyst maketh land bleweth continually troubly hot thicke sad therfore men south land contrary men north lande stature shape therefore men land bold hardy wrathfull angry neither great • angler boaster constantine sayth also quality property earth diuers nigh sea far thence land yt nigh south sea hot moyst land nigh north sea hot vapour moyst commeth south sea heateth land nigh thereto contrary north sea therfore sea called mare ponticum fresher lesse salt sea coldnesse hath masterie therein therfore cold vapour commeth therof cooleth land yt nigh therto also land changeth diuers working trauell men land delued eared ouerturned vertue therein medled part thereof laud amended made able beare manye manner corne fruite land lyeth long idle resteth pa • reth worse beare corne fruite also good lande bedewed rained fasteth amendeth grauelly land stony worse hard ¶ hill cap 2 hill high swellyng rearing earth land onely foote touching land el hill called mountaines passe vpwarde aboue deale lande aristotle saith also libro de proprietatibus elementorum aristotle saith men haue sayd earth first made round plaine mountaines vallyes therin shaped round ye euer body cause mountaines valleyes nought el mouing water dig weare soft part earth hard part maye digged made mountaines place wer digged deepe wer made sea riuers also libro metheororum arist saith somtime mountaines made strong earth shaking somtime earth lifted vp made mountaine great raine water commeth hallownes made valley also sayeth comming going sea weareth breaketh lande place maketh hill sometime sea healed lande bare alway softe part thereof let hard abide threw mud together wered drye sea passed tourned hilles also mountaines hard sad reared ward earth toward heauen grounded earth sometime full hollownesse dennes voydnesse draweth sucketh water hollownesse full water runneth springeth well head cause euerlasting springing running knowen mountaines hollownesse den draw sucke humor moisture send therof alway also mountaines containe noble mettal noble mettal mined veynes mountaines also mountaines • eare fruit swéete smelling thing cleannesse aire hath mastry top hill fruit groweth hils pure sweet fruit grow valleyes also hill receiue sooner sunne beames vallyes hold longer time also hilles gender exhalation smoke vapour gendring therof ye aire come clowdes vpon top high hill thereof commeth rayne seldome top mount olympius arist saith cléernesse aire scarciue vapour vapour spended wasted ere maye come toppe hill also hill set windes stormes valleyes cold hath mastry hill snow lyeth hils frosen colde winde therein therefore snow lyeth abideth longer hill valleyes doth mount caucasus libano high hilles alway white white snowe isidore saith also hill ofter smitten lightning valleyes isidor saith therefore hill called monte pirenei haue name fire lightning fire called pir greek also hill called ceraunci haue name oft smiting lightning lightening called ceraunos greeke isidore saith also hill high best place stand looke wait spie comming enemy men go vp top hill waite warne perills sée farre also hill sound sad strong kinde therefore able place buylde castle tower dwelling abiding hill sure valleyes namely may mined hardnesse sadnesse ground high hard take waye vpward also hill plentie hearbs grasse lease according pasture sheepe beast hearbs leese mountaines wholsome better defieng beast grasse hearbs grow valleyes though bée generally ranke fat humor feeding norisheth hearbs grasse subtill pure humour plaines valleyes therefore heate heuen defieth moysture turneth sooner changeth substaunce hearbes grasse subtilnesse humour cléernesse also aire also hill higher trées thicker bush valleyes therefore mountaines accord wilde beast fowles bréed dwell therein therfore wilde beast hunted hunter valleyes flye mountaines safe ¶of hill ararath cap 3 ararath highest hill armenia therein no ship rested floude isidore saieth yet day timber shippe séene mountaine hill hath many name iosephus speaketh hil sayeth manner place no ship armenian call egressorium yet men countrie shew timber left ye ship iosephus saieth berosus caldeus maketh minde shippe manner sayd ship came armenia yet part hill cardiens thereof falleth glew men vse cleanse also iosephus egypcius man • slus damescenus 96 hist libro write manner armenia great hil named bari sayd time great floud many fled saued therein one came ship top hill timber kept long time also mountaines armenia called ceraunei highnesse ofte beating riuers riuer named cerannus greeke isidore sayeth hill begin betwéene armenia hiberia isidore saith port caspis stretcheth well riuer tigris reg 21 mount carmelus side land toward sea either good pasture fruite hearbs grasse hill libano cap 24 mon lihani highest mount prouince called prouincia phenicis mountaine prophet make mention hath name libanus thus gathered ther isidore saith farther parte toward east called aurilibanus isid saith also libanus called whitenesse white snowe winter summer alway snow ther neuer clene molten alway summer diuers place therof snow found libanus head well spring riuers wels ierome sayth foote thereof springeth two wels ior dan come togethers make riuer iordane libanus mount much swéete smelling ther growen hearbs sweet odor smell also trées beare frankencense whose chosen gum ye phisitions call olibarum hieronimus saith also mount suffisance plentie plentie deaw raine commeth ther full oft ther commeth plentie beast léese pasture best fruite ripe therefore mount labars pasture therof beast fed norished offered temple also mount passing highnesse raba • u sayth super reg mon libanus passed mountaines land therefore shipmen came tirus ful farre sayling sea might see hill know highnes ther hauen drawe saith also mount influence fayleth continual springing euerlasting moysture though • drye without yet hath within noble veynes water doth pit springing water runne alway strength mount called libanus salomon meaneth cant 4 quasi puteus aquarum also mount trust suretie resteth mount libanus strong safe maner venimous beast serpent hearbs grasse tree growe driue thence odour smell cedar grow ther driue away manner venemous beast creeping wormes suffer liue ierome sayth also hil fairnesse nurth wonderfull highnes cedar gréene tree continuall gréennes hearbs grasse swéetnesse song bird plentie riuers wels make mount libanus merrye lyking also mount medicine health growe growe plentie best vine make men glad merry also mount worship dignitie among mountaines syria mount liban hath principate highnesse plentie mirth wholesome aire ierome saith additiō libanus growe therein therefore austen super iohn calleth mount lyght mount fatnesse feeding mount medicine curation helpe sayth great plentie olyues growe therein ye fruit vnctueus shining liking isidore sayth oyle oliues riseth bitternesse roote féeding lyght medicine wound refreshing feeding hungry foote mount oliuet runneth brooke called torrentem cedron betwéene drink thereof mount orthard lord oft time entered prayer rest first taken garden called gethseman sayd ioh 19 foote hill fast brooke torrentem cedron sometime lyttle towne called gethsemany yet time wer orchard towne austen sayth ofte lord vsed place orchard mount ye east side temple therefore beshined sun rising morew side light shining temple euen tide night therefore worthelye called mount light receiued light heauen temple also gaue plenty oyle matter lyght aust sayth mount litle stréet called bethphage longed priest side hill citie called bethania citie martha lazarus mary glose sayth super math 21 mount lord ascended olalampus vnderstand wer heuen mount departeth macedonia thracia high passeth stormes passion ye aire therfore philosopher went vp sée course place starres might line except spounges water make aire thick throwing sprinkling water master saith histori • additiō olympus mountaine hill greece betwéene • lalia macedonia aboue yt appereth clowde therefore among poet vsurped heauen plutarchus viti • alpes vnderstood mountaines toppes way high féete downes lower mountaines high mountaines snowe alway manye clowdes heades spring welles greate riuers beastes fierce wilde manye manner birdes fowles winges shine night isidore sayth high cragges cap 33 high cragges highest mountaines sadde strong passing high top mountaines receiue always rooses tempestes showres raine therefore earth full washed aboue harder partes mountaines made harde turned stone made endlesse many cragges though cragges bée neuer hard rough sharp without yet within • e somewhat spungeous hollowe therefore eft humour bee drawne •• hered therin breake spring 〈…〉 windes watere come hollownesse denues cragges hee sometime cause earth soo • ing sometime violence strength shaking cragges breake faile bird fowles egles uul • ar come toppes cragges also cliffes sea bee soone wasted cragges leaping strong réeses stormes waues smite harde cragges couenable place defence strength bee found cragges den neasts fowles beast bee made crag loppes cragges bée wrapped beclipped mistes clowdes sunne rising toppes cragges bée shined beames sunne cragges bée called rupes bée hard break without strength yron cragges bee mooued also deepe veines cragges precious stone diuerse kindes mettall oft digged drawne also high strouting partes cragges called scopuli haue name scopin spie maite cragges right farre place perceiued espied hill sephara cap 34 sephara mount ye east iurye ierome sayth nigh thereto dwelled child lethan sonne hember iosephus sayth came sephora place salomon shippe came merchaundise chaffer commonly hierome sayth mount citie builded saued ye prayer loth grow vine balme apple palmes token old plentie vpon dead sea therein afterward set succour defence romanes thereof speaketh esa 15 whereon glose sayth called heighfer held fast liking lechery twice smitten fell downe third time earth shaking shuld haue stood strong abid sinned deliuerance hill sinay cap 36 sinay mount oreb parte thereof arabia prouince madian mount speaketh iesephus li secundo ant quitatum saith sinay high mount noble worthy pasture beareth best hearbes grasse supposed ye god dwelled therfore durst man keepe shéepe shepheardes durst presume walke moses came towarde mount sawe wonderfull sight hée sawe fire burnt bush wasted neyther appaired gréenenesse neyther flowres thereof neyther spray bare fruite though flame swift full strong mighty fire lord spake moses also libro 3 sayth moses went vp sinay high hill country highnesse greatnesse high strouting crag onely harde men come thereto also maye bee seene without trauaile therefore saide lorde dwelled mount dreadful men man durst come thereto foote mount hebrewes pight tent worthy see god fire clowd heare speake personallye mount called mon sinay moūt dwelling lord oft conuning angel mount light burning flame moūt clowdes darknesse inourd raine dew mount pasture séeding mount wisdome lore mount lorde taught moses people gaue lawe mount forgiuenesse mercy foresayde mount gift hearde graunted people mount righteousnesse menassing threatening dreadfull saw mount lightening séeming blasing mount trumpes trumping mount friendship truice lawe lord ioyned knit people euerlasting truice mount purenesse cleannes mount gladnes solace nursh none might come moūt cleane body soule also cleane lorde eate dranke ioy mirth mount forgiuenesse mildnesse pitie mount sacrifice prayer sacrifice lorde heard lord pleased mercie prayer moses additiō sina sinai mountaine desart arabia called also oreb solinus called casies iustinus calleth fairenesse defence citie one side mount sion temple middle betweene towre lower citie strength towre shuld defend citie therfore oft holy writ calleth ierusalem daughter sion mother defendeth daughter super lere cap 36 mount wonderfull nurth highnesse distanteth ten mile diocesaria toward east march zabulon isacar neptalym among mountaines lande behest mount famous place plentie mirth strength stedfastnesse soile mount beareth vine oliues trées verye apt beare fruit ther aire wholsome ost deaw swéete raine well morning euening high trées léese leaues gréene coulour winter neither summer song many diuers bird soules voice liking hearer diuersitie coulour fethers pleasant sight sweetnesse liking tast many bird soules haunt place therefore manye fowler lie lay net spring grinnes hierome abode night somtime mount lorde fedde people bodily meate ghostly top mount lorde shewed himselfe bassefull chaunged figure passingly disciple gaue reuelation owne body blisse cleerenesse euer shall cormolites dwelled sometime came kinde calef ier sayth mount hath many woodes vushes trées without fruite manye laundes wilde beast roe wilde coates mount mount full deunes dry ditch hole therefore couenable place banished men théeues hide therin perillous straungers know way therin may lightly leese themselues downe chap 46 downe little swelling arearing earth passing plaine ground reaching highnesse hill downe lower hill higher plaine called tumulus swelling lande isidore sayeth ofte foot hill down oft goe vp high hill downes called colles haue name colendo tilling tilled lesse trauaile hill men dwell sooner hill receiue sooner good aire heate sun lower land therefore fruit ripeth sooner downes also downes bedewed berained valletes therefore fruit groweth downes swéete sauourie fruit groweth valley downes meane betwéene lowest plaines lande highest toppes hill therefore aire thicker greater downes hot hill small cléere valleyes downes receiue ouer body cleane noble impression influence valleyes therefore fruit hearbes grasse grow downes better wholsome grow valley place constantine saith also downes take sooner ye shining sunne beames swifter moisting clowdes valleyes also mountaines vpon down come downe brooke streames downes runne valley field valley chap 47 ualley lowe landes set betwéene mountaines isidore sayth valley receiueth beareth water commeth streames well valley moisted streames come mountaines shedding therof bée endowed flower hearbs fruit greene twigges branch shadowed rearing highnesse hill downes also vallies méeting gathering rebounding sunne beames therefore hotter impression gendered valley mountaines also snow melteth sooner valley mountaines shedding thereof place nigh wette moyst macrobius saith therefore valleyes bée déemed assaye hotte trowblye thicke vaporous men dwell valleyes bée oft time gréeued hot euills moyst constantine sayth house stande valleyes bée lesse gréeued weather house stand mountaines mountaines stande betwéene defend valley strong reefes weather stormes also men dwell valleyes seldome gréeued earth shaking cause valleyes partes grounde set thrust cleaue stronglye together therefore winde maye easilye thirle partes come grounde partes bée hollowe neyther full hoales therefore mooue wagge strength winde commeth therein aristotle sayth also filth vncleannesse commeth valleyes abideth long time aire valley sooner rising great smoakie vapour mist mountaines part valley déeper toward centre mountaines farther circumference heauen also valley great comming water • sen heaped together make great marreis mire hard passe reason thereof passage ouer found greate difficultie also plenty humour grasse hearbes growe valley willowes trées without fruite growen valleyes mountaines campus chap 48 one maner field called campus manner fielde plaine grounde lowe valleye reared high mountaines isidore saith called campus euen plaine footing therein hath name camis gréeke camis vnderstoode shorte euen playne campus plain place tilled eared plough dounged durt namelye ordeined walking playeng vse déedes knighthoode nigh citye common place ordeined sight men vse communaltye appropried man assigned profit men ager field cap 49 another fielde called ager hath name wrought therein isid sayth lib 15 varro saith euery fielde eyther lyeth standing place beareth trées able pasture lieth leese beast beareth flower necessarie bee therefore men olde time meaned lande tilled called ager land vntilled called ru woode layes wherein milke beast name ru vplandish mē haue name called rustici first idle felicitye vplandish men also fielde called pascuus men diuide departe fieldes leaue field neighbour pasture lees aluuius fielde made field little little drawing ouerturning riuers artihmus field conteined certaine measure line endes thereof stretcheth mountain towres riuers field first eared called noualis fielde lyeth voyde euerye yeare renewe vertue field called noualis beareth fruit resteth without fruit also sometime field called squalidus excolidus hath name passeth tilth exconsul leaueth office consull sometime fielde called vliginosus yt vnderstood alway moist sayd moist sometime drie vligo kinde humoure land neuer passeth neuer faileth huc vsque isid lib 15 cap 14 field place businesse trauell sweate fielde • ylled trauaile beaten digged ••• tockes dolue turned spade féede beastes called pratum latine olde romanes gaue thereto name place alway ready prest néedeth trauel tilling isidore sayth place called prata alwaye readie beare grasse hey prata méedes watred moysted riuers streames well plentie humour giueth alway feeding nourishing moares rootes hearbes meedes springed hearbes grasse flowres diuers kind therefore fairenesse gréene springing therein saide méedes laugh also méedes bée greene bée lyking sight swéete odour bée liking smell feeding tast sauour theyr hearbes theyr grasse hearbes flowres méedes giue honie bées bréed plentie milke beast flock heale woundes remedie diuerse sickness euills desart chap 52 desart space land called desart forsaken manye men dwell therein come therto therefore men labour dwell therein isidore saith happeneth sometime lande barren ayre temporate default well water destruction made enimies desart laboured full thornes pricking bush place creeping wormes venimous beast wilde beast lodge vanished men théeues land thirst drinesse land burning disease lande wasting horrour land misgoing erring desarte wayes bée vnknowen downes pathes worne troden growen full broome furres shrubbes bush without fruite plaines bée full grauell stone fenne cloddes let greeue trauailing men bée called desarts sowen isidore sayth place woodes mountaines bee sowen called desertes also place men dwelled sometime destroyed happe bee oft called desarts isidore saith heremo chap 52 heremus wayles wildernesse dwell fewe excepte wilde beast fierce therfore men desire dwell wildernesse men sight company called hermites heremus declined heremus heremi hath name contrary meaning hereo here say tarry abide fewe men tarry abide therein heremus said cleaning land commonly land called heremus solitudo hard fast sadde hermites place solitarye wilde beastes walke freely abide surely place thicknesse bush many wood wild foules birdes sing sweetly also make neasts manye wilde beast foules haunt place though bee solitarye yet sometime hunter come thereto also fowler hide otten grinnes nettes also men inhabite place liue much trauaile bée greeued frost burning heate falleth vppon dewe raine hoare frost nowe snowe bee selde ouerset haply theeues hunter therfore place hermit haue much greeuaunce trauaile neuerthelesse hath vauntage commoditie rest darke caue chap 53 darke caue called antrum hath name atro blacke therein blacke feareful darknesse isidore saith properly lurking hiding place beast dwell tennes hoales therfore place beastes lye espie waite pray antrū called specus place abide waite spie hath name speculando waiting espieng ther wait espie beastly spie pray isi saith place yt called antrum colde sū mer hot winter necessarily wild beast feed hide therin brood whelp stinketh sweat vapour beast ditch chap 55 ditch called fossa hath name fodiendo deluing place made déep strength craft wit deluers mooued lande arreared aboue brinke déeper ditch within high déepe ditch harde perillous passe ouer man may soone fall therin falling harde arise come ditch gregory saith therefore also ierome saith super ez 19 yt lion taken ditch bottome ditch sheep goat put smell thereof lyon commeth ditch pray therein helde may go thence also ditch one side place digged den therin set trap coffer ye closeth soone hard open lion seeth yt may passe ye first ditch dreadeth comming hunter goeth second ditch closed trap ordeined taken held prisoner hierome saith also ditch néedfull ditch city castle strengthned enimies also place land bound mansiōs departed ditch ditch full water therein fish nourished créeping wormes diuers kind therfore ditch called fouea féeding nourishing liuing water ditch water nourished kept running standing water nowe come brooke therein raine well head streames springing water spring rise therein oft ditch chiefe strength succour fortress walled townes castle ditch arayed good order bredth length highnesse deepnesse place strengthened comming men passe ye ditch filling stopping boate bridge hierome sayth spelunca chap 56 spelunca ditch hollownesse vnder earth hath name spelunca speculando waiting espieng widenesse thereof able place abide behold look hath wide mouth entring open toward light straightend within spelunca place vnder earth first shewing light entring darke troubly passing inwarde farther end hard straight rough ragged outgoing farther end going may found damascene saith namely place stone mettals digged mined hollowe ditch den vnder earth left hollow void stone mettalls voided taken thence ouer part vnderset poasts pillar may fal oft great heauines ye earth pillar ouercharged fal softnesse owne matter ground beneath moist falleth pillar fall therin destroied vtterly spilt therefore harde perillous abide mine vnder earth colde moist darke vnstable vnhelthy rough hard heauie aboue hollowe déepe beneath also place bée couenable hiding lurking wilde beast put therein filth vncleanenesse dwelling abiding serpentes beast cauerna chap 57 cauerna earth lande digged made hollowe hath name cauando digging making hollowe part earth digged made hollowe departed asunder créeping wormes beast thrusting part voydaunce casting cauerns mouse créeping wormes take theyr dennes neasts flye therto sée dread perill harme without also hollownesse trées stone sometime bird foules flie culuours turtle dread egle hawke comming aire also hedghoges connies hare hollowe stone heare houndes knowe hunter come also holow hole den earth trées bées make honny manner foules make ther neasts lurke therein also hollow den lie adder serpent hurt sting venimous biting man beast come nigh den moreouer earth hollowe full dennes shaketh oft mooueth wind come therein filleth den gendereth earth shaking therein aristotle saith finis libri xiiii ¶incipit libr xv de provintiis part earth diuers prouinces world generally departed somewhat helpe god shall bée shortlye added worke wée singularly intreate onely holy scripture maketh oft remembrance world cap 1 world wide departed thrée isidore saith li 15 one part called asia another europa thirde affrica thrée part world assigned like much old time mē asia stretcheth ye south east vnto north europa north vnto west affrica stretcheth west passeth ye south asia conteineth onely one part yt halfe part ye land men dwell two country contein halfe great sea cō meth occean stretcheth betwéene part departeth thē asunder therfore thou diuidest world two part east west one part asia affrica europa no sonnes departed diuided world floud among sem ofspring asiam iaphet europam cam affricam glose sayth super gene 10 super par 1 gregory sayeth plinius also asia chap 2 asia taken halfe part world name asia woman helde kingdome east olde time isidore saith liuing manner figure shape body wonderfully diuers heart thought theyr name place wee shall shortly set following order abc assiria chap 3 assiria country prouince asia hath name assur sonne sem first country desarte without water additiō greate mountaine sina called ptholome ••• ne olde lawe giuen moses bodye holye uirgin katherin buryed also another mountaine called casius greate pompeius buried arabia deserta strabo called senaetis hath south mountaine arabia soelix north mesopotamia west petrea people country haue certaine habitation dwell tent arabia soelix south lyeth betwéene two sea arabicum persicum plentifull bringeth forth corne fruites twice yeare haue plentie fruite cattell except horse mule swine fowles except géese cock hen groweth kinde spice swéete gummes townes vnwalled people doe liue alwaye peace cooper thesaurus armenia chap 5 armenia hath name armenus companion iason thessali ye whē left king iason gathered together folke yt sparpled abroad tooke armenia called owne name isi saith li 15 land ararath ye sennacherib son fled flame praiers ye temple god story telleth li p • epri ye mount vpon no ship rested floud called ararath armenie set betwéene mount taurus thing wōderfully shapen wher ye land armenie toucheth ye brink brime tigris eufrates fruitful wt herb corne wood fruit full diuers kind wild beast cruell serpent adder isidore sayeth plinius speaketh bull stay lion ouercome throw downe elephauts yt strongest huge beast plimus sheweth ensample hoūd albanie sent alexander ouercame furlong lion bore elephant saith li 8 cap de cambus albanie men haue thereof sometime called athens athens 〈…〉 famous vniuersity greece place eloquēce sometime nourisher philosopher mother liberall lecture greece nothing noble nothing worthy citye gaue businesse study loue wit wisdome plinius saith isidore li 15 plato athens doctor prouince attica yt grecia additiō athenae famous citie athens betweene macedoma achaia sea coast called actae attica hyginus sayeth first builded cecropt called cecropia afterward mopsus mopsopia last athens minerua whome gréekes call athenam reporte neptune minerua contended name agréed betwéene shoulde haue name gaue vnto mankinde worthyest profitablest giffe wherevppon neptune brought foorth horse minerua oliue tree matter beeing put voyces ye profitable neptune cast one voice gaue place vnto minerua uniuersitie inuentour diuisour liberall artes science mother nurse auncient philosopher oratoures poet therefore called mart towne good learing whether resorted studye partes worlde cooper thesaurus demosthenes noble speaking made citye haue great name passing long time salustius sayeth passing ariopagita saint paules disciple commendeth maketh famous citie greate wit profounde wisedome hee lighted partes worlde sayeth epiphanius commendation denis ariopagite isidore sayth achaia chap 9 achaia prouince grecia europe named king called acheus old time prouince almost iland inuironed sea except north ther ioyneth macedonia hée hath east side sea cirenen north east ye gréekish sea ye south sea ionium south west ilands called cassodie onely ye north side ioineth macedonia achaia grecia chiefe citie prouince corinthus place strong isidore sayeth libro 15 vnneth anye waye come thereto highnesse place much solke highnesse sea also strength walles corinthus sonne hotestes builded citie among gréekes citye called corinthia vnderstande seruice common weale isidore sayeth li 16 additiō achaia parte greece contayning country attica floetia megaris aetholia phosis hath west epire east sea aegrum north macedonia south sea creticum another achaia peloponesus called morea citie patras saint andrew apostle martyred additiō conrinthus famous rich great city achaia scituate narrow straight entring peloponesus nowe called morea reason commodious scituation resorte merchaundise countryes greatest mart towne worlde thereby rose great wealth power romanes beganne suspecte feare wherefore time proude woordes abused ye romane ambassadours stra writeth cast vrine head passed citie romanes taking therwith great displeasure sent captayne mummius besieged citie within short space destroyed scantly anye token noble citie yéeres remained burning many rich costly image sundrye sortes mettall melted thereof founde kinde precious brasse called aes corinthum long time great estimation nigh albania hath name amazonia woman yt wiues men called goth yt men went nether scithia isidore saith li 9 cruelly slaine wiues tooke husband armour weapon téesed enimies manly heart tooke wreake death husband dent woord flew young meles olde men child saued female departed prayes purposed liue euer without companye male ensample theyr husbandes alway two king ouer woman ordeyned two quéenes one called marsephia lampeta one shoulde trauaile hoast fight enimyes ye meane time gouerne rule communalties made fierce warriours short time great parte asia vnder theyr lordshippe nigh hundred yeares among suffred male liue neither abide manner wise nation yt nigh chose hus bandes child went time ordeined conceiued child time done ordeined office conception would compell theyr louers go get great alexander 〈…〉 story alexander sayth • sayd alexander demaunded tribute quéene amazon wrote againe messenger manner thy wit wonder thou purposest fight woman fortune side happen thou ouercome art thou shamed euermore thou art ouercome woman god wroth v thou ouercommest v shall turne thée little worship thou hast mastrie woman noble king wondred hir answere said séemely ouercome woman sword condition priuately called albion saye happie richer coniecture approcheth nigh ye true similitude mention except auncient historie time gefferie monmoth beda may probably consute haue declared hath name well hallowed apollo sometime isidore sayeth libro 15 lande lake madnesse drinketh thereof shall burne woodnesse lecherie sayeth libro 14 chap 3 de aquia ¶looke welles additiō boetia countrey gréece wherein citie thebe called vandalia sometime called annia mesapia ogigia cadmeis hyantis boemia chap 30 boeme part messis towarde east side west germanie europe cloased greate mountaynes thicke high woodes departed germany pannonia nation mountaines wood riuers full straunge many place high mountaines full faire plaines fieldes meedes wholesome aspect euery blessed land beare corne fruite hath plentie wiues uineyardes corne fruite rich golde siluer tinne mettalls moyst welles riuers riuer watereth moysteth lande called albia noble riuer riseth mountaines boemia also many riuers runne together praga royall citie mountaines thereof plentie trées pine fyrre bée hearbes without number pasture onelye léese also swéete spicery medicinable hearbes many beast diuers kinde beares harte capreole tragollaphi bubali bisontes among wilde beast ther one much oxe beast strong fierce hath great horne large defendeth himselfe hath vnder thinne great bag gathereth water therein heateth water bagge wonderfullye running throweth water vpon hunter houndes come nigh water scaldeth haire burneth horribly thing toucheth beast called bom language boeme lande compassed morauia panonia ye east side polonia north austrich south compassed bauaria germanica matche misseneme west additiō boemia realme called beme inclosed boundes germany hauing east side hungarie south vnderstande orosius sayth babylon libro 2 first king sayth among assyries might passe ninus ninus slayne wife semiramie quéene asia made citie babylon nembroth begunne shée restored citie ordeyned destroyed vnneth men might thinke strong citie might taken citie disposed castle wall lyke long square greatnesse strength wals may vnneth supposed walles fiftie cubites thicke much height citie foure hundered foure score furlong wall burnt tile tempered glewe without abroad ditch large séene farre thence ditch ran riuer citie front walles hundred gate wall dwelling place shoulde defende citie troglodites plinius speaketh li 5 ca 10 men ethiopia haue name blacke riuer riuer kind nilus bréed réedes bull rush rise ware one time wildernesse many men wonderfully shapē oft curse ye sun vtterly woman without law bée called garamanis goe naked occupied trauaile bée called graphasants called • enn • j said haue head haue eye fired theyr weasts satyres haue onely shape men haue manner mankinde also ethiopia bée many wonder saith lib 6 cap 11 ethiops saith among foure footed beast bée brought forth without eares also elephant also haue hounde king diuine moouing doe haue three eyen forehead said kinde feigned vse principall looking sight arrowes also hunt lion panther liue flesh king hath onely one cie forehead men ethiopia liue onely honny suckles dried smoake sun liue past fortie palme gumme thereof lyke glasse maketh precious stone called ceramina isid saith li 15 land maketh many country world rich fruite spicerie namely country west additiō gades two iles part spaine beyonde granate worthinesse men time haue excelled one time rome 500 men countrey citizen order state gentleman lesse two ilands reported grasse battling milke beast doth cast whaye haue chéese made stretch south hesperie occean men goe straye desarte name gelon came iland gaulon beside aethiopia serpent bred may liue therein sayeth also ende affrica beastiall men called garamantes haue name greatest rich mightie full people therefore plinius li 6 ca 19 telleth wonder might multitude indes saith inde many king hath vnder foure hundred thousand men armes sixe hundred cuneos horseman 9 thousande elephant take wage euery daye land full rich one hath sixtie thousand foote men thousand horse men seauen hundred elephant alwaye men arayed warre battell land strong mightie rich sayd indie till earth vse chiualry vse merchaundise lead chafferthe commōvveale vvell gouerned rule gouerne comminte best king iustices dome men giue principally religion learning wit wisedome among country landes inde greatest rich among landes inde wonderfull plinius saith li 7 chap 3 inde aboundeth wonder long space toward aethiopia inde many huge beast bred greater bound land also high trées men may shoote top arrowe sayd maketh plenty fatnesse earth temperatenesse weather aire water figge trées spred broade manye great company knight may sit meate vnder shadowe one trée also great réedes long euery péece betwéene two knottes beareth sometime thrée men ouer ye water also men great stature passing fiue cubites height neuer spet haue neuer head ach tooth ach sore eyen bée grieued passing heate sun rather made harde sadde therewith also philosopher call gimnosophistae stande hot grauell morning till euen behold sunne without blemishing eyen also mountain men sol feete turned backward foote also eight toe one foote also ther houndes heades cloathed skinnes wilde beast barke hound speake none otherwise liue hunting fowling armed theyr nayles féeth full many aboue sixe score thousand sayth also among nation inde woman beare neuer childe child white haired anone borne satire men wonderfully shapen spoken treatise monstrous beast also ende inde rising ganges men without mouth cicile reigned therein length thereof breadth stretcheth north north west east north east closed south sea terrenum north sea adriaticum endeth west great mountain called alpes land fayrest thing kind people strong wals ditch araye warre plentie golde siluer lib 2 plinius sayth therein twelue famous mightie perticular countryes besides ilands treateth largely lande cloased east north west full high
