magna grecia inhabited gréekes mirsilius writeth solinus resembleth figure thereof oaken leafe extending length breadth toward end diuided two horne whereof one lyeth towarde sea ionicum looketh narrowe sicilie called fretum siculum narrowest place passeth breadthe twentye myles italica citie italy another name called confinium another spaine siliue italicus borne ¶of hispania chap 79 countrey spaine first called hiberia name riuer hiberus afterwarde called hispania hadde name riuer hispalus sayd lande called hispera name olde time west euening starre land betwéene affrica europa cloased north side ye mountaines pyreneis closed sea side aire healthy ther abundance corne fruite rich precious stone mettall noble riuers runne land betis minius hiberus tagus pactolus draweth golde therein sixe prouinces terraconis cartaginensis lusitania gallicia betica side arme sea countrey affrica trangitania two spaines hether farther huc v que isido li 15 orosius sayth spayne thrée corner roundnesse landes beclypped nigh sea occean tirreni welnéere made iland next corner thereof eastward right side thereof prouince guyan lefte side strained sea balearicum nigheth border narbon second corner thereof toward ye north northwest bernagicia citie gallia reareth toward sight britaine thirde corner thereof toward ye ilands gades afore mount athlant affrica side arme occean huc vsque orosius also plinius prayseth spaine manye thing namelye mettall sayeth nigh spayne plentie golde siluer brasse copper yron tinne lead white blacke therein men nation great warriours strong sayd descended greekes said also descended successours wysigothes saith isido therein many speciall prouinces know galitia men countrey tell came greekes isidore saith lib 9 ther asturis hath name closed mountain afore riuer asturius ther celtiberia hath name gallis gelcicis bwelled vpon riuer hiberius hispania countrey west part europe called spaine somtime called iberia hesperia muyroned south part sea mare meditaraneum diuideth europe affrike ye north part sea mare cantabricum west great occean sea east moun • ines pyrenael parte realme fraunce called aquitania narbonensis countrey diuided ptholome three region bethica wherin granado syuil cordubia c lucitania wherein portugall galletia c tarrhaconensis wherein castyle lyon arragon time containeth slue realmes granado south part toward affrike portugall west gallecia biskaye north arragon east castile lyon middle much west parte reason yorkes forrests lacke water fertill well inhabited north part reson much cold plenteous south parte wonderfull fruitfull length strabo writeth 6000 furlong 850 mile bredth 5000 furlong 625 mile plinius next vnto italy extolleth fertilite aboue countreyes plentie graine wine oyle siluer golde yron statius claudius doe lesse commend touching golde siluer spaine beholding indie whence commeth yearely infinite masse treasure slouth distrust bene pilate england fin • o past indie serued england spaine part plainly appeareth booke tituled decade ye west east indie andrew theuer ¶of hibernia cap 80 irelande called hibernia additiō ilande occean europe nigh lande britayne narrow straight britaine plenteous place iland stretcheth south north isidore sayth libro 15 first partes thereof toward sea called hyberum cantabricum occeanum also iland hath name hibernia sea called hyberum occeanum lande much plentie corne fieldes well riuers fair meade wood mettall precious stone gendred sixe cornered stone say iris maketh raine bowe aire set sunne also sound stone called gagates iet sound white margarites concerning wholsome aire irelande good temperate countrye litle none passing heat cold ther wonderfull lake pondes well lake staffe pole trée pight tarieth long time therein part earth turneth yron part water tourneth stone part aboue water abideth still kinde trée another lake thou throwest roddes hasill turneth roddes ashe againe ward ye cast ashe roddes therin tourne hasill therein place dead carrion neuer rot hut abide alway vncorrupt also ireland little iland men dye • ouercome age borne ilande dye withoutalthogh land free vermine men free louse vvhich cō meth sluttish filthy vse ireland serpent fragges vencuious spider land contrary venemous beast earth lande brought another lande sprong ground slayeth serpenies toades also venemous beast flieth irish wooll skinnes fell serpent toades brought ireland shipping dye anone manye wonder land solinus speaketh ireland saieth irelande nigh asmuch britaine inhabitant thereof fierce lead vnhumaine life adder séene except bée seldome people vse harbour guest warriours andthey ciuill novv drinke men bloud slay wash first face therewith right vnright take one bées men throwe power stone brought irelande hiues swarmes forsake hony combes sea hybernicum toward britaine full waues vnquiet yeare vnneth able sayle except fewe dayes hundred thirtie thousande pace broad c huc v que solinus de mirab mundi irish men lyue long helthy body stranger molested vvith flixe deadly disease abide ther men ireland singularly cloathed vnseemely arayed scarcely fed cruell heart fierte chéere angry speach sharpe neuerthelesse frée hearted faire speach goodly owne nation namely men dwell woodes marreyses mountaines men plesed flesh apple fruite meate milk drinke giue playes hunting worke trauell name prouince inde hath name one ophir man came child heber lande olde time called terra aurea golden lande therein golden mountaines bée lyon cruell beast dare man come manner shippe standeth nigh aire cleere alway full plant flourishing leaues good smell full light bright shining fairenesse ioye blisse oes • er passing wit vnderstanding sensible creature kingdome god worthy image nore moone conuenient place innocent man faire wether temperate neuer passing colde passing heate euerlasting faire weather temporate isidore saith also plentie good austen de ci • tate dei 14 ca 10 saith might dread might sorry great plentie much good ther nothing greeued good desired offend grieue flesh soule man yt loued blisse also mirth ye place • eller sairnesse damascene saith witnesseth ye beautifulnesse light cléerenesse light proportioned purenes aire beda saith also noble grounde plenteous witnesseth multitude springing well sayde genesis 2 wel sprong moisted paradise well diuided passing forth rising exhalation vapour listened body moone alexander expoundeth paradise reacheth fully circle moone sayde toucheth circle moone manner figuratiue speaking yt called hiperboli loqoutio yt might knowne highnesse paradise passeth yt neather earth without comparison also continuall without corruptiō witnesseth long life therein ther elia enok yet aliue without corruptiō master saith plin saith speaketh ilands fortune isi speaketh also li 15 among ilands one yt beareth good grounde beareth al manner fruit without tilling down trées alway clothed faire gréene twig spray swéete thereof gold found iob toucheth saieng place saphire stone thereof soyle thereof golde iob 28 afterward countrie turned dead sea called dead sea gendreth nothing aliue receiueth nothing aliue therin mountaines ther depart betwéene fraunce italy looke de montibus pireneis litera p land hath another name called prouintia ¶of sardinia cap 138 sardinia iland sea middle earth beside sicilia hath name one sardus begotten hercules came lybia great multitude occupied sardinia gaue thereto owne name lande seene sea affrica likenes print man foote towarde east toward west broad euen side toward south toward north therefore shipmen gréece first called ithos lande séene length seauen score mile bredth fortie therein bréedeth serpent neyther woolfe onely little beast called solifuga solifuga noyfull wicked men therein bréedeth venyme hearbe named apium risus apium risus draweth shrinketh together ye iawes men slayeth laughing hot welles heale sicke men blindeth théeues sweare vppon water touche eyen isidore sayeth libro 15 additiō sardinia ile sea called ligusticum gean passing seauen mile corsica ¶of sarmata cap 139 sarmata land strange men called sarmate haue name studie businesse armour marish meotis vnder many countreyes contayned polonia rhussia frussia lituania linonia moscouia c greater parte countrie vnder king pole ¶of samo chap 140 samo iland sea aegeum iuno borne thereof sybel samia pythagoras samius first founde name philosopher isidore saith libro 15 said earthen vessells first made iland therefore called vas samea vessells samo knowen claye ilande tough glewe therefore able make vessells isidore saith additiō samos name two iles sea called aegeum one thracia therefore called samothracia lyeth ephesus ¶of saxonia chap 141 saxonia prouince germania sayde nien prouince came gréekes dwell part arriued ship expulsed droue thuringes dwelled occupied vnto cleue occean saxon gate wannē place many battailes strong dwell prouince daye men alwaye gretest warrior séemely shape stature high strong bodye hardie bolde heart saxonie land plenteous corne beareth well corne manner fruite full woodes mountaines full fruite léese fieldes rich beastes flockes siluer copper mettall solempne mountaines stone digged stronglye resolued fire turne substance brasse ther noble riuers famous wesera limia albia sala odera many runne thereby ouer beyond albina salt well many place best salt white sodde made therein many strong city castle townes plaines mountaines beside mountaine copper digged great hill stone thereof smell vyolets mountaines fairest marble digged namely beside riuer danubius stone called saint michael stone mountaines plentie venison wilde beast beares boares harte therefore mountaines full woodes manye manner hunting vsed many noble thing founde countrey saxon looke de germania littera g litera de alemania saxonia hath boemia polonsa east side westualia west side frisons toward occean men thuringe north frenchman south men noble strong ouercome daye herodutus sayeth additiōafter time arthur king britaine ye saxon greatly molested briton helds subiection long time ¶of sclauia chap 142 sclauia parte mesia containeth many region boemes paloni metani wandali ruttheni dalmate charinthi sclaues vnderstand accorde many thing touching language manner yet diuers rite vsage holde yet faith panims vsage gréekes vsage latines region noble grounde beareth well corne also wine many place nation yt part haue bush cut round excepte ruthens meddeled dutchman latines sclauia double called selauonia containeth dalmatia saruia carinthia many region men sclauia dwell vpon sea high mountaines thicke woodes care till field plaines men fierce sharp vnseemly without deuotion god seruice lead life robbing sea vse take praies sea land namely dwell vpon sea lesse sclauia ye border saxony stretcheth pruse wandales boemes sclauia departed pruse diuers riuers water gothes dane arme sea occean sea departed lesse sclauia endeth cliffe thereof region beareth well corne fruite moyst riuers pond therin much wood pasture milke hony men strong body earth tiller fisher deuout god peaceable neighbor dwell sclauia medling company haue daye germaines herodotus saith sclauonia ¶of sparta chap 143 sparta region besides grecia called lacedemonia another name one lacedemon sonne semele looke de lacedemonia litera l men called lacedemones spartian also isidore sayeth libro 9 ¶of seres chap 144 seret prouince east hath name town called seres cotton gathered trées silke made cotton poet syenketh men land saith ignoti facie sed vellere seres additiō seres people asia hauing great plentie silke first increased silke worme called bombax also much cotten wooll called bombazi olde copie ignoti facie voce fere mille seres ¶of selandia chap 145 seland land sea side compassed riuers armes sea iland hath holland east side flaunders south occean west britaine north manye ilands departed sunder armes sea ilands compassed strong heapes grauell quarry warded defended waues strength sea soile land beare wel corne bare trées saltnesse sea trées may haue déepe more rootes therefore set planted faile drye anone seland full men people rich men great stature strong body bolde heart denout god seruice easie softe among themselues beneficiall many greuous men must néedes withstand wrongfull riser enemy additiō zeland next adioyning england ouer ipswich brill dort midelbrough chiefest hold strongly fenced sea ¶of semigallia chap 146 semigallia lyttle prouince beyond sea balticum beside cilica liuonia low asta hath name • vasconia chap 170 vasconia gascoine prouince beside mountaines perenei sometime accounted vnder gyan hath name towne wastea isidore saith lib 9 hath mountaines pirenei one side sea occean another nigh peito third side land many wood trées land mountaines many partes thereof many viniards many much sendeth plentie wine country land nigh also ilands ye sea riuer girunde departeth land tholose italia yt lordship many land city ye sea land olde time day might therof lordship stretcheth right far sea euen vnto grecia reacheth frō country germania subdueth theft tiranny skimmours sea théeues dalmacia sclauia represseth gouerneth ruleth rightfully ilandes hauens coast sea vnder lordshippe thereof defendeth mightely subiects enimies hold common profit ciuill vnder rightfull lawes suffereth somewhat wilde fierce occupie themselues witchcrafte men faile coastes also men abide default winde profer winde saylingthe samoyes bordring ye russe vse like inchātment sell winde vse make clewe thrid make diuers knot knit therin commaunde drawe clewe vnto thrée knottes moe lesse haue winde softs strong theyr missebeléefe seendes • oue ayre arise stronge tempest softe hée draweth clewe lesse knottes sometime moue winde stronglye wretch beléeue drowned rightfull dome god vitria cap 175 vitria little ilande british sea departed britaine little arme sea ground thereof best lande wheat therein many woodes groaues many beast wilde wels riuers moist lande ilande temperate wholesome countrie plenteous fruite sayd english men dwell therein day trevisa héere lacketh mention made whether ward land beareth britaine side britaine land men would thinke ilande wight wight commonly called insula vecca ile héere called vitria additiō whether ile bée parte uitrie canuas linnen cloth made time past else béeing consumed sea nowe ile whether making glasse hadde anye originall yselondia chap 176 yseland last region europa north deyond norwaye vttermost partes thereof alway ise srosen stretcheth vppon cliffe occean towarde north sea frore greate strong colde iseland hash ouet scithin east side norwaye south irish occean west sea farre north called irelande lande ise glasse sayed mountaines snowe frore harde ise glasse thristall found also region white beares greate right fierce breake ise glasse clawes make manye hole therein diue sea take fish vnder ise glasse drawe hoales bring cliffe liue thereby land barraine except place valley place vitheth grow oat place men dwell onelye groweth hearbes grasse trées place bréede beastes wilde part men lande liue fish hunting flesh sheepe may liue • old therefore men lande weare colde felles skinnes beares wilde beast looke hunting clothing maye haue come landes men full grose body strong full white giue fishing hunting additiōthose goe thether fishing meruailously troubled kinde flie like gnat stinketh foule additiōisland interpreted lande ise called olde writer thyle extended betwéene south north almost 200 schones longitude schone 60 furlong parte full mountaines vntilled plaines verye fruitfull inhabitant faine driue castell féeding least shoulde ouermuch fatnesse strangle die thrée mountaines meruailous height top wherof reuered continuallye snowe lowēt partes lyke operation mount etna flaming forth fire brimstone drie called helga mon crosis third hecla whose flame consumeth flaxe towe yet quenched water fire breaketh forth hydeous casteling lyke thunder casteth forth pomisse stone meruailous height néere vnto mountaines riuers chinkes lyke déepe raues especially foote mount hecla déepe eie canne perceiue bottome abisme appeareth shape men though drownes yet breathing foorth sound saieng must depart thence mount hecla touching fearefull noyse ise read r eden r well zeugia chap 177 zeogia called zeugis also prouince thore carthage •• ituate lesse africa betwéene bisantium numidis isidore sayth lib 14 prouince stretcheth north sea siculum sayth stretcheth south country getules hither part thereof beareth well corne full serpent beast wilde wild ass wilde beastes bée found wonder beast wonderfully shapen saith additiō zeugma also name citye dacia additiō zygantes secreate mysterye imperfect1 cor13 idem 15 iohn 8 • showeth value minde bée noble bodye creator farre excellent thinges created worlde father worlde made created iustified saued wée liue together loue together cause discorde betwixt errour ueritye herein appeareth loue god among whome hée abideth euer called mundus signifieth cleanenesse also worlde worlde made yet knewe hée came among owne receiued hée sent seruauntes intreated shamefully slewe héerein appeareth nature discorde powre errour tyrtannye simple interteinement ueritye appearth among seuerall kindes birdes beastes fish wormes flyes flower hearbes plantes tree fruites seedes manye thing increase man god hath made cleane bodied chéerefull countenaunced swifte heare prompt speake apte learne poure beléeue hauing angelicall vertues shoulde stirre minde whilest hée taking materiall nourishment abideth vnto singular consideration vertuous exercise whereby soule tasting bodye might faith good workes féele endlesse nourishment prepared child god whilest studie subdue kingdomes ouercome theyr neighbour robbe fatherlesse widdowes rauish virginnes gouerne bée gouerned spirit terrestriall ferryes doe bréede shape sinne hatch forth manye abhominable euills theyr whole race yeares spent vaine glorious beasting filthye liuing whose endes dampnation whose vellye theyr god glorye theyr shame worldlye minded earth lordes therein round worlde dwell therein man made robbe kill destroye giue continuall praising vnto god learne god bée bountifull mercifull liberall bée contented hath regardeth verye simplest creature theyr kindes shall bée onelye accuser fleshlye violence god without remission consider ioyes worlde disturbed affliction frayle weare awaye ioye fayth onely disquieted extremityes crosse persecution made perfect stormes daungerous faith effect godlye béeing fenced strength faith patience doe containe whole world tirrannie thereof nolli intelligere vt credas sed crede vt intelligas thousande foure hundred germaine milesa germaine mile supposed p english mile 21000 600 italian mile later age affirmeth manye portion earth plinie sayeth seconde booke nature nare rather many haue written point worlde neyther worlde anye thing else vniuersallye matter glorye seate héere wée beare honour héere wée exercise empire héere wée desire rich héere mankinde falleth together eares vproare héere renewe warres euen ciuill killing one another wée make earth wider passe ouer publike furye nation wherein driue awaye borderer stealth digge vp neighbour stuffe put grounde proper good belong vnto example many region yéelde lande owner lewe purchaise rent bowelles earth bée founde anye mettalles value purchaiser shall lorde thereof much equitye maye bée taken stéede thifties painfull trauaile • lling sayde grounde bring foorth good corne therfore nowe good corne thiftles lorde maye take corne yet replyeth contrarye sayeth mettalles therefore right lorde tenaunt dd neuer imploye charge thing readye prouided let reason stand lawe yet sayeth guide lawe kingdome heauen math 13 lyke vnto treasure hidde field man findeth concealeth ioye thereof goeth selleth hee hath treasure boughte substaunce fielde therefore inheritaunce inheritance denyed treasure whye difference eyther mine shine referre equitye question vnto prudent wise worlde thinges maye bée considered glorye god hath lymited countryes farre abroade hath driuen dweller beyonde boundes small part earth taketh pleasure measure couetousnesse shee hath inlarged portion length therfore maye dead man haue sea istmus betwéene sea pontus eurinus second shall bée obayeth great cham emperour tartar whose limit south mare caspium riuer iaxartes mountaine imaus east north occean west kingdome duke moscouia wayfaring men thus much foorth ottelius india well néere writer one consent doe teach india noblest part whole globe ye earth greater countrey comprehended vnder one name called riuer indus space india according strabo pliny closed west riuer indus north hill taurus east east season west owne sea wit indian sea diuided two countryes riuer ganges running betwéene one westerly called within ganges lyeth east surnamed without ganges holye scripture read one called euila seria niger testifieth marcus paulus uenice séemeth deuide thrée lesse middlemost saith called abasia india onely happie great store people townes almost innumerable also abundaunce thing copper lead onely excepted giue credite plinie riuers many great whose watry ouerflowing commeth passe moyst grounde force sunne approaching ingendreth bringeth foorth thing great quantitie seemeth almost fill whole worlde spice precious stoanes aboundeth countreyes worlde manye ilandes ioyning vnto héere scattered hir occean ¶ncipit liber xvi de lapidibvs preciosis property earth party thereof described generall helpe god purpose plant héere somwhat ye beautie ornament therof special thing yt beautifie ye earth clene without soule without feeling thing groweth vnder grounde gendered veines earth stone coulours mettall shall first speake order lyfe soule rootes hearbes tree soule féeling men beast whome shall last speake shall shewe first order abc thing gendered earth veines thereof arena chap 1 grauell called arena hath name drinesse thrust brused together man hande rattle make noise drinesse hardnes grauell throwne white cloth defileth isi saith li 15 ca 4 also grauell sea washed manner slime wose gleamie fenne aristotle saith liber de proprietatibus elementorum therefore great drinesse runneth turneth perfectly stone also li 4 mcth saith pure earth turneth perfectly stone cō tinueth breaketh therefore drines euercōming moisture suffreth earth turne sadnesse stone therefore ye grauell sand harde substaunce common earth soft stone may departed many part grauel sand colde dry small heauie weight thrust togethers though selfe small baraine defalt heat moisture mastry cold drines whē showre falleth theron breaketh sennye thing washed away wasted grauell sand pressed togethers pure sad part cleaue together also waues sea letted multitude grauel sand withstood heap thereof constrained passeth meares boundes yt god hath ordeined thereto hierome saith super le cap 5 set grauel sand mark meare sea c also hath vniuersally kind cleansing water runneth grauell clene fresh constantine saith also hath vertue cleanse mettal cleanse alwaye rustinesse mettall gold brasse yron made bright froting grauell sand also hath vertue coole smite inward stop swage swelling fareth thimalia grauell sande shauen brused smithes stone good foresayde thing constantine saieth plainly hath vertue like oare mettall among grauell sand riuers sea founde golden grauell oft time also bright polished stone precious stone found sea cliues among grauell also grauell riuers sea bée gathered heapes contrary wind reaseth part thereof hetherwarde thetherward stoppeth taryeth oft water riuers course running sea iero saieth super amos 8 ibi destuct sicut riuus aegypti c openly sayde water nilus lot heap grauell gathered together month riuer suffereth water nilus runne ye sea constraineth openly maketh turne againe ouerflowe plaines egipt water letted compelled turne againe heapes grauell course might runneth falleth sea said falleth déepe sea heapes departed auoyded ier saith also hard perill fall smile heapes grauell hid sea vnder water rehearsed shewed perills sea ¶of claye chap 2 argilla potter clayclay called argilla tough earth glewie gleymie apte meete diuers workes potter hath name argilla arges isidore saith lib 16 cap primo among first earthen vessells made claye said ther working heate consumeth wasteth moystie partes dryeth hardeneth earthie part claye turneth • ile also ofte happeneth colde fréeseth water fennie earth earth turneth stone also changing vnctuous sen stone falleth ofte heate running hardning matter saide 4 lib metheorer unctuous fenne able chaunging turning stone burning hardning heate vnctuous thing meane betwéene gleymie vaporatiue thing passeth thing breathing smoking thing vnctuous hath moisture selfe partie vaporatiue may congeale made hard heate partie gleymie may passe vapour thrusted together made thicke harde tourned stone commentour saith claye coldnesse stauncheth bloud nosea remedy stoppe bleeding clay tempred strong vineger laid temple ¶of alabastro chap 3 isidore saith li 15 ca 5 alabaster white stonealabastrites strake diuers coulours stone oyntment boxe gospell speaketh ofluke 7 made stone oyntment vessell made best without corruption stone bréedeth thebe aegypt damascus white best commeth inde dioscucides calleth stone intomar said stone helpeth win victory mastrie also saith gendreth kéepeth friendship ¶of golde chap 4 golde called aurum hath name aura still wether isidor saith lib 26 shineth aire bright kindlye shining mettall blase shined light therfore thing make shining blassing called aurarij golde blasing called obrisum shineth bright beames best coulour hebrewes call ophar gréekes name chrusos thin plate golden threds cut called brathea huc v que isi cap de mettallis li metheororum parum ante fine aristotle saith golde mettall hath matter subtill brimstone red quicke siluer subtill white composition thereof sadnesse brimstone aire moysture quicke siluer therefore gold sad heauie siluer composition siluer commonly quicke siluer white brimstone saith among mettall nothing sad substaunce better compact golde therefore though bée put fire wasteth smoaking vapour neither lesseth waight wasted fire melted strong heate filth therein cleansed thereof maketh golde pure shining mettall stretcheth hammer worke golde stretcheth betwéene anfield hammer without breaking renting péeces stretcheth lease golde among mettall none fayrer sight golde therefore among painter golde chiefe fairest sight darkeneth shape coulour mettall also among mettall nothing effectuall vertue golde plato describeth vertue thereof saith temperate pure mettall hath vertue comfort cleause superfluity gathered body therefore helpeth leprosie meselrio filing gold taken meate drinke medicine preserueth letteth bréeding leprosie namely hideth maketh vnknowen ofte vse golde letteth tarieth bréeding lepra maketh vnknowen auicen saith also filing powder iuyce borage bone heart hartea medicu •• helpeth sownding cardiaele passion also thin plate gold fire hot quenched wine maketh wine profitable ye euill splene many euils passion melancholike also burning made instrument gold better maner mettall kéepeth ye place burnt without stinking also powder offall golde healeth spot eyen therin also golde comforteth sore lymmes though corporate therein though norisheth yet doth away sharpnesse thereof superfluity growe member cleanseth wise plat saith also hot gold doth away haire member burnt froted therewith groweth consta saith also gold smitten foundeth brasse doth siluer creketh cleaueth strecheth euen abroad except strong mettall medled therewith wise long brasse latton medled substance gold cleaueth alway vnder hammer inobedient take shape beating hammer therfore néedeth superfluitie put awaye golde clensed melting made pure may able shapen wt hammer make thereof vessell couenable shape gregory saith plate golde shall medled plate siluer ioyned therto néedeth beware namely thrée thingsthree speciall property obserued melting gold siluer powder winde moysture héreof come betweene golde siluer may ioyned together one therfore néedeth meddle two mettals together full cleane place quiet ioyned due maner ioyning inseperable yt may afterward departed asunder golde maketh wise men glad spendthrift mad gold vpholdeth kingdomes golde preferred manye common wealth justice therefore put delyght therin called auri sacrum fame ye misvse thereof reported late writer golden mountaines cibana aud wonderfull rich gold king spaine hath yéerly west east indie gathered multitude slaues ordained purpose notwithstanding vsurers yt inhabit britaine doe make moe slaues frée borne raising rente ingrossing landes hindring tillage quantitie ground one yeare subiect among indie thrée yeares vtter ouerthrowe landes good wife child ¶of laton chap 5 laton called auricalcum hath name though brasse copper yet shineth gold without isid saith brasse calco gréeke also laton hard brasse copper medling copper tinne auripigment mettall brought fire colour golde isid saith also hath coulour likenesse gold value also laton composed diner manner vessells faire séeme gold new first brightnesse dimmeth becommeth rustie colour smell copper first matter thereof knowen meate wine kept vessell taketh horrible sauour smell vice brasse colliria medicine eyen profitably kept vessell made sharp strength brasse plat saith ¶of auripigmento cap 6 avripigmentum veine ye earth manner frée stone cleaueth breaketh like golde colour called lapis arcenicus another name double redde citrine dioscorides saith hath kinde brimstone burning drieng laid brasse maketh brasse white burneth wasteth bodyes mettall except golde diosc saith plat saith auripigmentum hot drye fourth degrée veine earth thereof double kinde red citrine citrine helpeth medicine hath vertue dissoluing tempering drawing cleansing helpeth tisike etike haue euill breth commeth moysture gaue thereon take smoke thereof auripigment made pisilo cracium oyntment yt doth away haire maketh fall fodde hot lime also helpeth tetars scabes place softly anoynted sope auripigment place must washt anone oyntment lye long therto fret good flesh well euill stay away shinne hath kinde slitting taruing fretting maketh soule vnséemly nailes fall better nailes may grow platea saith auripigmentum coulour called orement orpine arsenike daungerous poyson red ftretting mercury like operation ¶of siluer chap 7 siluer called argentum hath name isi saith speach gréeke siluer called argiron gréeke wonderfully fareth though siluer white yet maketh black line streakes body scored therwith ruled therewith isi saith composition thereof quick siluer white brimstone therfore heauy gold richardus rufus sayeth two manner siluers simple compounded simple fléeting called quick siluer siluer compounded massie sad compounded quicke siluer pure cleane white brimstone burning aristotle saith ¶of quicke siluer chap 8 quicke siluer watrye substaunce medled strongly subtill earthy thing maye dissolued great drines earth melteth plaine thing therfore cleaueth thing yt toucheth doth ye thing yt watry substance therof white clée • ne cléere water whitnes subtil earth yt well digested also hath whitenes medling aire ye foresaid thing also quicke siluer hath propertie cruddeth selfe kindly without brimstone brimstone substaunce lead congealed fastened togethers therefore sayd quicke siluer brimstone element wit matter melting mettall made sayd openly lib metheororum also richardus rufus expoundeth openlye manner quicke siluer matter mettall therefore respect simple element vertue kinde thereof diuers men speake diuerslye meaning phisitions thereof maye knowen word quicke siluer plato sayeth hot moyst fourth degrée though men déeme colde degrée hot knowen effect working dissolueth pearceth carueth séemeth full colde touch men déeme amisse meane colde men meane quicke siluer made great heate veyne earth knowen false heate fire soone wasted away smoke earth gendred kept fléeting water full long kept cold vessell sound cleaueth together strong yt may nothing meddeled first quenched quenched spettle froted therewith namely powder medled spettle specially powder bone henne meddeled therewith quicke siluer passeth euaporation séething smoking smoke thereof grieuous men thereby bréedeth walste quaking shaking softening sinewes taken mouth ye care thirleth slayeth member perill goates milke best dronke great quantitie continuall mouing oof patient speciallye wine good wormwood isop sod huc vsque plat called quicke siluer coniealeth matter done isi saith li 15 also ther saith saith fléeting runnenth specialy found siluer forge drop siluer molten oft found olde dirte sinkes slime pit also made mini put cauernes yron patent shell done vnder vessell noynted therewith shall compassed burning coales quicke siluer shall drop without siluer golde latton copper may ouergilte great vertue strength though thou put stone hundred pound weight vpon quicke siluer waight two pound quicke siluer anone withstandeth weight thou doest thereon scruple gold consumeth selfe lightnesse thereof appeareth wayght nature obeyeth taken drinke slayeth weight best kepte glasse vessells pearceth boreth fretteth matter huc vique isidorus lib 16 chap de metallis siluer white cléere sounding pure may well wrought hammer well golde kéepeth saueth well balme helpeth vertue stone iaspis yt hath vertue siluer gold said lappidario melt molt fire hath colour fire neuertheles colde againe white harde though great boistous matter gold yet among mettall beareth price golde worthinesse value medicinable helpeth many euills thereof healeth wound fulfilleth place fretteth away superfluitie dead flesh letteth grow bringeth whole flesh cleanseth filth hoare body marking instrument siluer kepeth stinking comforteth féeble member layeth maketh stedfast rusteth toucheth earth taketh colour againe scoured grauell sande salt adamant chap 9 adamas little stone inde coloured yron shineth christall passeth neuer quantitie walnut nothing ouercommeth neither yron fire also heateth neuer gréekes called vertue may daunted though maye ouercome though despise fire yron yet broke new hot bloud grauers vse péeces thereof signe rule hollow precious stone stone contrary magnes adamas set yron suffereth yron come magnes draweth manner vyolence magnes though magnes draweth yron selfe adamas draweth away magnes sayd stone warneth venime electrum doth putteth diuers dread feares withstandeth bréed without stone therfore ye eagle kéepeth stone neast male thereof hard like gum called galle male somewhat blasing female soft stone bound woman trauaileth child maketh soone deliuered maketh sometime beare dead child bée long somewhat passeth priuy choice woman except stone soone taken trauaileth childe isi saith li 16 cap 4 also stone echites conteineth bréedeth another stone within like woman child dioscorides saith lapidano said stone conteineth another stone woman childe vertue stone echites maketh man sober augmenteth increaseth rich doth loue helpeth greatly obteine conquere victory fauour letteth withstandeth falling haue falling euill man suspect fraude poisoning guiltie stoud put vnder meat suffer swalow meate stone withdrawen shall tarry swallow meat emachite chap 40 emachites red stone reddie rustie sonne affrica iuda arabia hath name broken bloud tourveth anone colour bloud isido saith god fluxe bladder sore eien venim biting adder stancheth fluxe womb▪ restraineth bléeding namelye bloud woman gum dioscorid saith plat sayd cold drie complection hath vertue stanch bloud hath name emachites emach bloud chites stint helpeth emoptoces men spue cast bloud speciall remedie bloudie flixe eliotropia chap 41 eliotropia precious stone gréene sprong red droppes veines coulour bloud hath name effect dooing put water sunne beames maketh water séeth vesell resolueth mist soone resolued rainy drop also séemeth stone may doe wonder put basen clére water changeth sunne beames rebounding aire seemeth shaddowe bréedeth aire red sanguine coulour though sunne eclipse darked moone set betwéene v sun darkned seemeth maye chaunge cléernesse sun called elitropia turning away sun isidore saith expresly dioscorides also lapidario meaning said manner ex nomen habens est elitropia gemma quae solis radijs aqua subiecta vacillo sanguineum reddit mutato lumine solem eclipsimque nouam terris effundere cogit isidore saith stone discouereth soily inchauntenes witch haue liking pride theyr owne wonder begnile men sight thinges worke foresayde stone doth hée setteth ensample thereof sayeth hearbe name certaine inchauntmentes beguile sight men looke thereon maketh man heareth bée séene many thing thie stone good commendable stauncheth bloud putteth awaye venimme hée beareth stone maye beguiled enidros chap 42 enidros little stone droppeth alway melteth neuer lesse wise sayde lapidario enidros stone weepeth alwaye springing full well dropping teares welleth alway sayd hard tell cause doings drop substance ye stone stone lesse melteth awaye thing entereth stone thing entereth putteth againe thing yt goeth séemeth maye vertue stone maketh aire thicke nigh thereto turneth water seemeth commeth substaunce stone neuerthelesse commeth substance aire stone additionperpetui fletus lacrimis distillat enidros qui velut ex pleni fontis scaturigine manat dissoluing drop teares full oft enidros stone doth drop fountaine full doth alwaies runne neuer stop episte chap 43 epistes litle stone bright reddie maketh man safe beareth hart side ceaseth guile decrites putteth long flyes barren foules mist haile fruit earth set sunne firie beames thereof thou doest stone seething water seething thereof ceaseth water cooleth soone isidore sayth dioscorides also excoliceros chap 44 excoliceros little stone named distinguished diuersed fortie colour full little maketh men euen looke thereon quake found libia among treglodites yron chap 45 yron called ferrum hath name isidore saith ferrendum smiting beateth smiteth hardnesse thereof ouer commeth kinde mettall though yron come earth yet hard sadde therefore beating smiting suppresseth dilateth mettal maketh stretch length breadth isidore saith hath name lande digged therefore diuers reason therof found harde soft ye minde aristotle yron gendered quicke siluer thicke cleane full earthie hoales brimstone great boistous pure composition yron foresayd brimstone quick siluer mastrie colde dry earthy matter yron dry cold ful well harde compact togethers part yron hath lesse airy watry moisture mettall therefore hard resolue make againe soft fire ric rufus saith manner temper yron ware oile least coldnesse water much hardned isid saith yron taketh soone rust touching bloud entreth substance thereof vnneth clensed isi saith rust vice fretting yron commeth therto either vncleannes substance touching earth nigh lieng therto else touching blood qualitie infected saith also yron man bloud spilt man bloud taketh wreake yron yron taketh rust nothing soone man bloud •• ointeb therewith yron hath agreement stone adamas stone adamas draweth yron selfe yron drawen meane siluer vessel brasse followeth ye stone subiect obedient therto yron well furnished annointed alam vinegre shall like brasse yron furbushed shall rust anointed sewet marrowe heart isidore saith firie hotte yron bée oft quenched wine milke maketh wine milke medicinable haue euill splene also sicke men constantine sayth also isidore sayth yron made firie hot corrupted hardned stroke yron redde fire profitable carue cutte till beginne waxe white use yron néedfull men many thing vse golde though couetous men loue gold yron without yron comminaltie sure enimies without dread yron ye common right gouerned yron innocent men defended full hardinesse wicked men chastised dread yron well nigh handiworke wrought without yron field cared without yron neither tilling crafte vsed building builded without yron therefore isidore saith ye yron hath name ferrum therby farra corne seede tilled sowen without yron • read wonne earth bread departed readye without yron couenably man vse also yron whet yron salomon sayth coge yron dulled blunted great froting oft made thinne sharpe couenable cut thing easily sinder called scoria saith yron cleansed therfrom fire hath name scotia see smitten departed yron violence fire isidore sayth ferrugine chap 46 ferrugo pouder falleth yron filing squama thing leapeth away ye fire heating hath vertue make dry thin therefore good stopping splene neuerthelesse exciteth casting spuing dronken insomuch sometime bringeth death violence therof ceased pouder adamas stone water stone lyeth night also sayd pouder therof best remedy emoroides also stancheth flixe wombe said platea also filing pouder yrō called rubigo also corrosio hath name corrudendo fretting gnawing properly called erugo hath ye name erodendo filing eramento isidore saith infecteth defileth hand • toucheth maketh soule pure polished yron rather defiled rust worst clensed rust soone done awaye thrée manner burning fire fretting salue file froting hard stone scouring grauell sand pullishing rust hath propertie infection thereof commeth againe light occasion place first mored rooted gleba chap 47 clot gathering together pouder clustre isidore sayeth libro 15 capit primo earth bounde clonged togethers clotte broken departed powder earth hardned clot receiueth séed neither suffereth seed ther sowen growe spring clotte broken couereth nourisheth séed tempered raine gendereth manner fatnesse therof séede taketh nourishment féeding root groweth springeth gregory sayth also sometime clot conteineth selfe manner kind oare therfore diuerse kindes thing gendred come clot gregory saith super illum locum 24 iob saphire stone place thereof clottes thereof gold gemma chap 48 precious stone called gemma hath name shineth gum isidore saith precious stone adorne well gold make well fayre diuers coulours therefore isidore saith bée precious deare scarce scarce seldome called great precious written word god precious saye scarce isidore saith man shall wene doubtfull false god hath set vertue precious stone sayd lapidario ingens est herbis virtu sed maximum gemmis saye greate vertue hearbs precious stone precious stone found veines ye earth digged mettalls cast bottome sea place generation unknowen alway precious stone found cliffes sea sand grauell riuers bréed body soules créeping beast frō whence euer precious stone come found endued ye grace god passing great vertue noble isidore ca de gemmis • urens saith kinde precious stone harde greate difficultie know betwéene ye precious stone false oft false guilful séeme like true vnneth men may know betwéene true guilfull sayth sometime men craft aray stone called vitrū put forth stéede smaragdos beguile men eyen false likenesse true smaragdus life men without guile isido saith vse cal al manner precious stone bée precious shining blinde dimmed owne thicknesse boistousnesse isidore saith déeme bée oft beguiled oft vertue hid little adamant coulour yron darke sardio bright berall gagite chap 49 ieat called gagates boistous stone neuerthelesse precious first found cicilia riuer called gagas throwen vp brinke course water therfore hath ye name therof though plenty best britaine isi saith double say yeolow blacke blacke plaine light burneth soone fire driueth away adder smell therof kindled right thus insence gineth monition yt haue séendes within helde contrary séen • giueth knowledge maydenhoode maide drinke water thereof pisseth maide drinketh therof shée pisseth anon also dioscorides saith stone maiden anone proued diuerse author affirme moreouer stone black also yeolow made hot rubbing ye finger draweth light strawe leaues selfe bée put thereto drinke thereof helpeth yt haue dropsie wasteth euil • apours sayd comforteth liuer perchance drynesse therof also priuy vertue qualitie also pouder thereof good féeble téeth wagging strēgthneth fastneth also sayd stone helpeth fantasy veration féends night also fumositie thereof exciteth menstruum withdrawn day also said swageth womb ach stomack misturned way also helpeth witchcraft fordoth hard inchantments said lapidario spéedeth fast birth helpeth trauaileth child said lapidario boistous stone doth great wonder none despised soule colour without vertue hid within vnknowen isidore speaketh stone saith stone kindled water quenched oile wonder galactile chap 50 galactiles stone coulour ash hath swéete tast sauour bee smit manner white milke commeth thereof isidore saith stone closed mouth distroubleth wit borne necke maketh breast full milke bée bound thighes maketh easie birth medled water salt sprong aboute field shéepe full milke cleanseth scab dioscorides saith gelacia chap 51 gelacia white precious stone shapen haile stone cold neuer heateth fire isidore saith dioscorides also geraticen cap 52 geraticen blacke stone passeth ye colour vertue man wash cleane owne mouth beareth stone therein hethey cā tell hee thinketh may anone tel men thinke said lapid maketh man beareth well beloued vertue prooued manner man nointed hony set among many fly stone present fly grieue stone away ye fly grieue bite sucke hurt body iaspis chap 53 iaspis precious stone gréene like smaragdus dim coulour seuentéene kindes thereof isidore saith iaspis yt greene called gemma pinnasin though chiefe coulour thereof gréene yet hath many colour meddeled among vertue thereof destroyeth feaners dropsie beare chastlye helpeth trauailing childe driueth awaye fantasy maketh man sure perill abateth heate within stauncheth bléeding sweat withstandeth lecherye letteth conception stauncheth menstruall bloud emoroides pouder tooke milke helpeth healeth olde torch viles cleanseth eyen foulenesse filth sharpeth suppose hath many vertues diuerse coulours veines dioscorides saith ye best iaspis found mountaines scithia griphons kéepe stone doe smaragdus isidore saith iacincto chap 54 iacinctus bliew stone deale nigh coulour saphire hath name owne coulour isido saith stone iacinctus found ethiopia best cléere neither dim meane temperate betwéene twaine shining isidore saith stone shineth alwaye like cléere wether cléere eien darke weather dim darke isidore saith mouth séemeth colde therein hard graue neuerthelesse maye grauen written marked stone ad • nae isid saith dioscorides sayeth stone iacinctus bliew nowe reddish nowe purple bright bliew thereof bée thrée manner kind citrine bliewe among manner stone bliew best stone wonderfull consumeth aire dimme weather dim dright weather bright stone hath singular vertue authours write giueth gladnesse contrarye melancholy quality hath vertue comfort isidore saith kind thereof iacirctus hath vertue comfort doth away eleignesse sorrowe also vaine suspition withstandeth diuers pestilence come ofte corrupt aire giueth strength vertue member life sinewes giueth good sauor swéete wholsome lyke saphire dioscorides saith men treate precious stone meane lyke iacinct saphire colour substaunce vertuous iacinctus withstandeth venim contrary poyson dioscorides saith also hearbe ye name like therto colour equall therto manie thing though alike tell shall knowen héereafter knowen property stone generally stone colde drye sad fast hard heuie moueth downward heauinesse waight lyeth heauie earth ioyneth mineth together part earth shuld breake lead double kinde black lead commeth alone veyne gendred siluer medled veynes blowen blowing first commeth tinne siluer remaineth blowen turned blacke lead isi saith inde neither brasse lead found inde rewarded margarites precious stone isido saith blacke lead best trauellous workes pipe plate spaniard briton haue prooued huc v que isid quarto li metheo arist saith brimstone boistous swiftly pured troubly thicke quicke siluer substaunce lead gendred gendered minerall place vncleannesse vnpure brimstone lead hath manner softnesse smoocheth hand toucheth wiping cleansing vncleannesse lead may taken away time neuer alway man may wipe vncleannesse alwaye lead though séeme siluer strange quality haue mastry therin beguile men maketh erre therein men take sal armoniacum aristotle saith assigneth cause vncleannesse saith voystous lead euill quicke siluer heanie sennye also brimstone thereof euill vapour stinking therefore fréeseth well full li 5 alchimie hermes saith thou hang lead ouer vineger hurteth vineger shall pearce substaunce thereof turne pouder white colour floure lead thou powrest vineger thervpon commeth white destroieth might vineger burnt lead bréedeth red colour dim fire strong turneth citrine thereafter stirring dryeng tempring vineger tourneth white colour floure lead makest strong fire tourneth first matter lead made earth said also lead medled mettall gathereth togethers kinde part mettall departeth cleanseth away part therefore lead put siluer furnaice siluer may sooner cleansed lead saueth siluer part wasting lead wasted burnt cleanseth siluer ier saith glosa super 6 ca fere ibi consumptum est plumbum c also hermes saith lead boyling vndoeth hardnesse sadde hard body also stone adamant li meth arist speaketh lead saith lead without doubt molten quick siluer melteth without heate molten séemeth red wonder though lead pale brown yet burning resudation vineger ofte gendreth séemly colour faire tawnie red therewith woman paint themselues séeme faire coulour lead good medicine leade colde moyst second degrée constant saith helpeth wonderfully agaynst burning fire hot postumes stauncheth bleeding wound stauncheth abateth running eyen puluere chap 82 pouder called puluis hath name puf • e winde isi saith lightnesse therof ye winde taketh vp bloweth abroad contrary windes commeth pouder beareth maketh ye whirle winde beda sayth powder beaten sheweth kinde thing commeth sauour colour odour smell therefore pouder made spicerie inner vertue thereof may shew selfe medlyng oning partes maye receiue larger vertue may giue foorth fragrant smell cause swéeter taste may effectually dry clense putrified wound eate fret awaye dead flesh grow pouder burnt lead dryeth cleanseth away superfluitie wound gendreth saueth quicke flesh const saith therefore pouder plaisters made confection called thimiamata diuers medicine oyntments pouder made thus mirrhe burning pouder beast offred lord god also pouder made noble electuaries helpeth healeth body aliue also pouder oyntment made kéepeth saueth dead body rot fall pouder also sen made medling pouder moisture turneth clot working drinesse isid saith also pouder defileth face therein saphire stone thick passing bright isi saith stone praised lapid noble excellent called gemma gemmarum chiefe precious stone lighteneth bodie kéepeth saueth lims whole sound hath bright starre brightnesse starre vertue knowen another manner saphire called sirtites found fast place called sirtes among ye grauel sea libicum diosc saith also found veines mine lasurium also found veynes saphire middle wombe certaine kinde carbuncle found therefore manye men déeme saphire carbuncle mother manye men meane carbuncle gendred ye saphires veynes many men meane carbuncle deale beshadowed certaine blewe sparcle kinde saphire diosc saith diosc saith yt saphire hath vertue rule accord yt strife helpeth much make peace accord also hath vertue abate vnkind heat therfore lapid said ye saphire cooleth heate ye body within saphire cooleth much heat burning feuers hanged nigh pulse veines heart therefore hee saith y• helpeth much feauers y• haue time chāging accesse time also hath vertue cōfort glad y• hart therfore said yt helpeth cardiacle melancholik passion therfore stancheth running sweat yt cōmeth anguish sweat also said lap stauncheth sweat runneth swift c diosc saith hath vertue staunch bloud saphire east stancheth bleeding ye nose laid ye temple also hath singular vertue swage blowing certeine yt saphire abateth swageth swelling postumes soone laid therto beginning noiful drawing also ye saphire helpeth euill postume yt called antrax putteth might ventosity mallice postume ouercommeth putteth woodnesse thereof suffereth smoak therof come heart malice therof infect spirit dioscri saith vertue contrary venim quencheth euerye deale thou put spider boxe hold saphire inde ye mouth ye bore vertue thereof spider ouercome dieth sodeinly diosc saith haue séene proued oft many diuers place vertue keepeth saueth sight cleanseth eien filth without greefe therfore written lapid taketh away filth eien ach forhead also vertue healeth bile botch dioscor saith stone beaten pouder medled milk healeth wound also hath ben proued wound experience also stone great authoritie olde time men held worthy stone god singularly hallowed apollo natiōs asked coūsel appollo time sacrifice hoped certified haue aunswere sooner saphire stone present dioscorides saith touched lapidario vse nigromancie meane yt haue answere god therby precious stone also witch loue well stone wéen yt may work certain wonder vertue stone also touched lapid sayd stone bringeth men prison bond vndoeth gate bond toucheth authours write doings many singular vertue saphire al author accord point say yt saphire precious stone loueth chastity therfore least ye effect thereof let wise vncleannesse yt beareth néedeth beareth liue chast story meaneth beareth commaunded chast also lapidario said stone doth alwaye enuy putteth dread feare maketh man bold hardy master victor maketh heart stedfast goodnesse maketh méeke mild goodly wéene saide disposition effect sufficeth time additiōin iland zeylam found best true saphires hard fine coulour azure bliew ther diuers sort saphires found calicut smaragdo cap 88 smaragdus al gréene precious stone chiefe isidore sayth men olde time gaue thereto thirde dignitye margarites vnions smaragdus hath name gréene colour said sayde gréene thing bitter hearbes precious stone gréennesse stone smaragdus passeth hearbes grasse twig braunches infecteth aire passing gréene colour gréene coulour abateth sunne manner wise nothing comforteth eien grauers stane bodie thereof straight cleansed polished image bée séene therein mirrour cesar nero vsed see fighting sword player stone isidore saith therof 12 manner kindes noble found scithia bactria holdeth second place smaragdis found among vnder stone chinnes thereof northerne winde bloweth earth vncouered smaragdis shineth among stone winde grauell sand moued aegyptians haue third found metall oare brasse gleyming haue speckle like brasse lead salt though smaragdus gréene kinde yet medled wine oyle gréene colour increaseth maner smaragdus goeth kinde though gréene somewhat vnseemly beines brasse called calcesmaragdus hue v que isid li ca de viridibus gemmis stone taken griphons plentie smaragdus may found great griphons let comming men way goeth thereto isid saith li 13 cap 3 stone multiplieth gréene colour commeth beame dieth aire maketh gréene body thereof cléere glassie kinde sheweth figure image shape thing nigh thereto hath gifte kinde goodnesse vertue heale diuers sickness euills dioscorides saith increaseth rich maketh men haue good word faire euidence caose plea stone hanged necke helpeth falling euill saueth comforteth féeble sight represseth wanton motion lechery maketh good minde helpeth also al fantasy iapes fiend ceaseth tempest stauncheth bloud saide helpeth vse diuine gesse shall befall sayd lapid additiō smaragdes grow ye countrey babylon indian call ye sea diegn • n grow also part india stone faire gréene coulour light tender stone many counterfaite looking warily toward ye light counterfaits shew certaine burble • doth glasse true seene ¶of sardio cap 89 sardius precious stone red colour red earth hath name first found sardis property may shewe déede presence stone sardius dioscorides saith ouer vertue sardius hath many vertues sardius fiue manner kindes best commeth sardis good increaseth ioyes putteth away dread maketh waneth moone doth isi sayth diosco also vertue reconcileth loue accord supposed helpeth tisike sicke men ¶of stanno chap 93 tinne called stannum mettall hath name etimologic gréeke isid saith tin departeth fire departeth mettalls diuers kinde departeth lead brasse gold siluer defendeth mettall hot fire though brasse yron hard kinde yet strong fire without tin burne wast awaye brasen vessells tinned tinne abateth venim rust amendeth fauour also mirrours tempred tinne white colour cerusa made tinne made lead huc vsque isidorus li 16 cap de metallis lib metheororum aristotle sayeth tinne compouned good quicke siluer euill brimstone twaine well medled small part compounded therefore tinne hath colour siluer sadnes thereof li alchemie hermes saith tin breaketh mettalls body medled greate drinesse tin destroieth mettall kinde obedient hammer worke thou medlest quicke siluer therwith withstandeth crashing thereof maketh white afterwarde maketh blacke defileth also said burnt tin gendereth redde coulour lead doth fire bée strong first matter tinne commeth soone againe also though tin soft siluer hard lead yet lead may soone soudred lead brasse yron without tin neither may soudered without greace talow rosen sulphure cap 94 brimstone veine earth hath much aire fire composition therefore called sulphure solum vrens burning grounde fire called vr firye vertue brimstone known feruent water water runneth passeth vein brimstone taketh whitenesse heate thereof fauorinesse effect smell héereof commeth hot wels springing ye earth bring therewith ye quality veines brimstone nothing soone set fire brimstone bréedeth hotte iland eloijs betweene cicilia italy men meane ilands burne brimstone found digged place isidorus sayth brimstone foure kindes one called viuum digged shineth flourisheth onely among kindes thereof phisitions vse isidore saith another called gleba serueth fuller third called liquor good profitable cast sparple wooll therewith make soft white fourth serueth light lanternes isidor saith sayth thereto ye vertue brimstone great ye certaine sickness perceiued brightnes thereof flame therof cō meth straight mās face bréedeth foule euill palenesse sight looke theron likenesse dead men isid saith li 16 cap 1 auicen pla meane brimstone hot drye fourth degrée turned kind brimstone part water earth fire brimstone sometime great boistous full drosse somtime pure white cléere subtill sometime meane betwéene diuers disposition diuerse mettall gendered brimstone quicke siluer saide 4 metheororum shewed brimstone quicke siluer matter mettalls brimstone called quicke brimstone taken earth dead brimstone quenched made craft put pottes vessells medicine best quick heat bright shining white gréene without stone maketh gréene colour bée put fire hath vertue tempering departing consuming wasting making subtill thin restoring therefore letteth cough helpeth yt haue falling euil cleanseth scab withstandeth venim awaketh men haue sléeping euill helpeth gowtes podagre palsie remedie thereof vsed due manner medicinable auicen dioscorides platearius author say sale chap 95 salt called sal hath name saliendo leaping leapeth fire flieth fire though firie kinde isidore sayeth men meane hath name sal sale sole sea ye sun gendered sea water working sunne sea abideth cliffes dried sunne sometime drawne salt pit sodde till water turne hardnesse salt fléeting made hard thicke heat somtime gathered among grauell sande waring moone night oft cerenia salt founde vnder grauell sand also place rockes salt therof stone hewen yron turneth afterwarde kinde salt fareth arabia pannonia also stone harde make house common salt craketh sparketh fire leapeth thereof sal agrigentinum cicilia suffereth fire melteth fire kind starteth leapeth water salt diuers colour sal memphiticum red coūtry cicllia wher mout etna pure salt ye cicilia pathmos bright cléere salt ye image séene therein capado yeolow salt digged mined isidore saith also salt varieth diuers sauour sayth place swéete sauour place salte bitter bitter salt hot hotter déemed auicen saith salt néedfull without salt nigh meate wearish vnsauory salt maketh potage meate sauorie exciteth good appetite meate salt al meat made sauory liking men wéene hath name salt sun nothing profitable sunne salt sée diuerse beast come pasture liking salt also milke théese abundant goodnesse salte also salte hardneth drieth thing kéepeth saueth dead body rotting huc vsque isidorus libr 16 cap 3 also plat auicen tell salt hath generally vertue vndoe cleanse wast rotted humour also depart destroy ventositie namely powder salt sod layd hot bagge mouth stomacke also vertue ioyneth saueth kinde moisture body wasteth destroyeth vnkinde moysture therein water salt well dissolueth wasteth swelling boyling also dropsie sayth also salt fretteth awaye dead flesh namely salt burnt withstandeth best rotting dryeth cleanseth thirieth inner part saith also salt softneth wombe bringeth supersluitie namely salt called gemma hath name cléere precious stone worketh wonderfully ordeining gut softneth harde putieth superfluitie doth armoniacum common salt also also salt medled honie bread wine healeth postume carbunculus antrax auicen sayth also salt doth away speckle face tempered water camphora face bée washed therewith also salte cleanseth bodie scabbes traters trée called arbor hath name arui fieldes cleaueth earth root fast therein hearbe doth isidor sayth li 16 ca 5 tree hearb commeth foorth one manner one way one commeth thou sowest séede tree first sheweth wringeth forth hearbe confect riseth tourneth kinde trée space short time ye seemed hearb turneth tender young trée called arbusta shafte tree place wherein trées grow called arbustum willowes hidden beastes openly knowne perfect complete trées mooue place place beastes doe chaunge appetite liking seeieth sorrowe though philosopher meane trise • aagoras aristotle reprooueth plant life vegitatiue thereby humour drawne saue • ad trée plant therin soule féeling sorroweth bewen cut hath seeling nourished fed waketh sleepeth breedeth hath condition belong soule feeling tree gendereth gendered medling male female tree hath vertue selfe seeding maye thereby bring forth another like selfe kinde might vertue worketh deede outward help help time ye yere winter needeth gather together ye seminal humour springing time needeth bring humour great colde freesing thrusting outward neither strong heat burning ye seed corrupting also sun needeth resolue temper part therof congealed cold heat cōmeth departeth ye humour seminal ye humour yt nourisheth scedeth also earth needfull tree hearbs thing ye gender yt well feeding tree earth sun well generation therof cause worketh therfore li de plantis aristotle sayth earth mother sun father tree hearbes earth fredeth mother sunne worketh father tree plantes men take beede generation feeding nourishing increasing rootes yearelye renouation séene purgation vrine dirt suppose therefore trées bée perfect beast aristotle reprooueth saith trée bound earth hath moouing selfe whole partes thereof neither hath determinate shape partes thereof partes thereof diuerse ordeined diuerse office dooing diuerse formes shape eie beast see care heare hath perfect soule part parte soule soule vegitatiue beast hath mo working noble plant trée diuers substance vertue working aristotle saith lib de vegitabilibus cap 2 trées haue gum rosen cause passing much humour defied heate neither tou • neth féeding trée put outwarde cooled cold aire thereabout also trées haue knot meanes partes gendered bound togethers also haue veines chinkes kinde moisture kepte passeth thereby earth partes haue also pith humour sodde defiaed passe substaunce leaues fruite boughes twigges saith hath rindes without defend trées within skinne doth body beast rinde doth body trée isidore saith also generally aristotle saith trée taketh soone fire light hath name lignum isid saith taketh soone fire light called lychius wéeke giueth light present also shafte trée stretcheth roote vp toppe properly called lignum hath somewhat within pith thereof kinde hath succone moysture féeding nourishing fayleth without fareth feeding beast féeding nourishing faileth member kinde hath succour bloud veines sayth expresly auicen isidore also also trée hath somewhat belongeth thereto outwarde rinde boughes leaues twigges blossomes flowres fruite toppe aboue aristotle sayth trée hath rinde saue kéepe within boughes twig spread vp leaues saue defend fruite tender harme griefes hath fruite saue multiplye kinde hath round toppe complement thereof hath figure shape piller commonly rounde albumasar saith euen spreading humour partes euen working heate maketh digestion partes yet euery trée plant hath roote root many manner knot string roote stéede mouth roote humour drawen féed trée knot string stéede sinewes binde together part conteined also trée hath super fluitie part kinde partes office néedfull trée partes trée haire nayles body therefore leaues fruit tall trées reason withdrawing humour haire falleth beast humour féeding scarce kinde withdraweth ye part néedfull faile partes bée néedfull therefore generally leaues fall trées winter time yet neuerthelesse abide trées bore eyther plenty humour gleaminesse humour sadnesse soundnes trée trées thinne substaunce harde full hoales pore loose liues namely humour féeding thinne scarce also trées diuers multitude part greatnesse smalnesse strength féeblenesse cause great trées humour milkie fareth figge trées humour able spread himselfe length breadth trées humour gleamie may spread himselfe partes cleene together fareth pech trées cause witnesse scarcitie part trées hearbes grasse gleaming cause féeblenesse tree hearbes grasse ye humour scarce heate vnsufficient vnperfect also trées humour sharpe hot drye complection yt 〈…〉 strength might hot thing lyght subtill chirleth therefore humour spredeth trée •••• th great quantity also partes trées men take hée • coutinesse quantity lykenesse qualitie 〈…〉 lykenesse shape commeth plein •• matter euennesse heare ye worketh ye ware fruit aboue ye leaues yt strength fruite néedeth heat sunne make digestion ye humour therof beare fruit vnder leaues féeblenesse fruite least fruite bée corrupt greate heate colde fruite hangeth stalke cause thereof reason vnmightye humour •• lmightie heate yt maye holde fruit outwarde generally euerye trée hath moyst roote yt meane betwéene trée earth earth trée hath féeding nourishing therefore gréekes call roote life trée bringeth lyfe thereto hath stocke shafte yt stretcheth vpwarde helpe roote yt needfull albumasar sayth susteine body thereof therefore lykened stature bodie beast beareth limmes member stocke steadfast foundament trée holdeth vp boughes fruites thereof also harde tree softe pith aristotle sayeth men call pith mother tree therein seminall humour tree fed childe mother men cast gut tree saw therein pured féeding departed vnpure gut beast men call heart tree thereof commeth moouing life life feeling commeth heart euery beast also euery trée hath rind make steadfast sad rind beareth small humour drawen outwarde dried heate aire teée within breedeth great humour drie essencially moist accidentally aristotle saith albumasar also tree hearbes growe croftes gardeines bee • ame tree hearbs grow elsewhere called wilde trées hearbs trées hearbes gardeins wild kept hared shred aristotle saith trées beare doth fruite oyles vrictuous human • • yrle sufficient beare none default humour tree ye leaues fall soone reason thin humour farlye ye brieth soone contrarye cause contrary also tree hearbes diuerse quantitye fairnesse soulenesse fayre euennesse matter faire ordeining setting partes sufficient heate yt worketh stretcheth right due disposition kind foulenesse commeth contrary trées hearbs also diuerse fruit good euill yt lesse sweetnesse kinde humour heate yt worketh hath lesse due proportion matter humour materiall also aristotle sayth wilde trées plant beare fruit tree hearbes gardeins albumasar saith plentye humour little fattye gleamie soone diuided departed springeth tourneth kinde fruit fruit gardeins better fruit wild trées arist sayeth albumasar saith cause plenty humour fattie airie swéet yt perfect matter fruit gardeins also trées hearbes diue • diuersitie place growe growe drye place losse quantity defeit humour moist place amōg riuers pond sea side ofte great quantitye trées yt grow strond salt water growe fast much sand grauell drynesse ye humour drawne beside red sea sayleth aristotle sayth great trées reason much humour greate heate albumasar sayeth also diuers leaues variation flowres haue sharpe leaues yt reason mastry earth drines haue smooth leaues euennesse moisture water due proportion heat haue clouen ragged leaues broad vine yt mastry earth priuation gleamye matter vneuennes heat yt stretcheth matter euenlye plant fatty humour gleamye passeth matter fruit watrye humour earthie matter leaues albumasar saith also trées hearbs diuerse figure shape vttermost partes vttermost partes shapen toppewise prickewise sharpe sareth thornes therein heate draweth thinne humour swiftly vttermost part drieth maketh sharpe ioyneth stock roote albumasar sayth contrary shape commeth contrary cause séene fruit trées arist sayth fruite diuerse shape cornered neither straight straight line fruit round euennesse matter humour euen working vertue yt worketh heate working partes matter euen stretched spread ye middle roundnesse cornered shape commeth contrarye cause also diuers coulour fruit flower bough twigges diuerse trées • aristotle saith cold humour earthie melancholike cōmeth blacknesse fruit foule coulour hot humour commeth red colour albumasar sayth foresayde dooing diuersitie sauour gendred diuersitie humour hath mastry heat worketh digestion disposition substaunce also trées hearbes diuerse riping fruit trées hearbes fruite ripeth soone aristotle saith • mulberies cheries heate strong mightie woorke moysture make fruit ripe swiftly soone ye humour obedient letteth working heat maketh digestion fruit ripeth late groseness humour watrie vnobedienth • unmight heate worketh digestion falleth wilde tree ye cause trée burgen soone saie leaues spring soone reason much watrye humour vndigested fattie breaketh soone vtter part trées hearbes contrary cause commeth contrarie arbore aromatica chap 2 trée good sauour hath sometime good smell rinde sometime flowre sometime fruite saueth sinamom rinde mare flowre nutmeg fruite albumasar sayeth cause good smell dry earthie subtill medled subtill watrye matter yt mastrie hath lesse one part trée parte smelleth better another trée smelleth well euerye part thereof foreth trée balsamus partes thereof hath good sauour shall shewed héereafter among trées hearbes good sauour growe haue themselues matter seminall come forth • ouenable medling element bée multiplied planting rootes stocke séedes haue multiplication grafting stockes albumasar sayth among graffing trées best graffe stocke lyke aristotle saith hath double vnderstanding eyther plantes one • ile kinde figge graffe grafted figge trée wine wine stocke else trées haue humious proportionall according eyther humour one according nourish féde peare graffed apple trée againe warde wit graffe grassed stocke tourneth chaungeth vertue qualitie stocke •• whe vertue qualitie oliue graffed stocke bete vertue oliue commeth downe stocke bete maketh hard maketh dure certeine time last draweth humour himselfe tourneth chaungeth stocke owne likenesse kinde albumasar saith super finem primo lib saith yt lightlye good trées come euill séede good séede good root euill trées though contrary oft séene among beastes albumasar sayth trée fast earth taketh nourishing earth one wise beast doe diuerse complection contrary appetite teast passing heat drinesse turneth fruite bitternesse good put thereto fresh water temper mastry heat drinesse also nailes pight almond tree graines gum come thereof long time superfluity water tree blometh first tree beareth fruite tree hue vsque isidorus libr de plantis aristotle sayeth almond tree need much tilling namely olde beared nailes cum commeth humour pured pith yt ye matter fruit therefore well tilled almond tree beare fruit old young almonde tree beareth double fruite sweete bitter said plat swéete almond good meate bitter almond medicine bee hot dryhot drye dioscorides saith foxe ofte ye thing wholesome good men poyson beast againward also saith nigh trée beareth bitter almond medicinable roote thereof sod brayed cleanseth face doth awaye speckle abateth head ach layd forhead cleanseth helpeth rotted wound medled honie also barke leaues cleanseth healeth oyle almond slaieth long wormes wombe exciteth purgeth menstruall bloud helpeth effectually deafenesse cleanseth thing made trée called abiegna maketh thing thereof called abietarius isi saith arist saith firre trée yt stretcheth length vpward hath much rarenesse substaunce small thin moysture therefore kind heate thereof helpe heate sun reareth beareth vpwarde moysture turneth substaunce tree maketh trée growe full high trée wonderfull high little nought crooked vertue heate euennesse humor obedient working heat therefore stretcheth vpright without crookednesse though trée gendered commeth lyght humour subtill yet kinde dryueth superfluitie humour outwarde bringeth betwéene tree rinde heate sunne aloa chap 5 aloe trée good sauour bréedeth inde papias sayeth trée swéete smell sometime parte thereof set fire alter stéed insence hath name therefore supposed trée aloe sayde platearius hot tree drye founde greate riuer babylon ioyneth riuer paradise therfore many men suppose foresaide trée groweth among tree paradise commeth paradise hap drifte riuer inde men dwell riuer take trée water net kéepe vse medicine good medicinall trée three manner kind trée aloe const saith lib gradioni first full heauie knot good smell deale bitter sauour browne red coulor letteth chewing saith chewed anone good sauour goeth braine filleth somedeale second lesse heauie smelleth well neither bitter third kinde deale white full light hath sauour smell little except arayed thing trée aloe fained trée like thereto waight knot deale smell men account trée aloe siluestris wilde trée trée froted lead chaunge ye colour eare waxe put thereto make deale bitter red put licour best aloe sod muste make haue good smell made vnneth knowen best yet knowen full hard maye wise chewed while men champ thereon bitter sauour within felt trée aloe comforteth stomacke maketh good digestion helpeth féeblenesse heart braine sownding namely cardiacle passion aloe sod wine helpeth euills passion heart féeblenesse heart yt commeth colde maketh wine bitter doe little therin delicate men temper wine rose water wine may
