vsque platea three sortes tree aloe forth 20 chapt l vertomannus nauigations shall vnderstandaddition great plentie true aloe luserpitium brought vnto v brought higher farthest partes world understand furthermore thrée kindes sort aloe greatly differing goodnesse first call calampat growes ile sumatra brought citie sarnau another kind aloe named iuba luba third kinde named bochor prouided none aloe calampat brought vnto v commeth kingdomes cathay chini macyni sarnau granay countreyes much richer haue much greater abundance golde king greater power rich also said king take great pleasure kinde swéete sauours vse much prince doe meanes true kinde aloe worth citie sarnau ten crownes pound waight ¶of aloe chap 6 aloe fruite certaine hearb called aloe addition aloe lowe tree whose gum seldome commeth anye part world hearbe found india persia many place iuyce thereof wrong sod fire afterward dried sun platea sayth also aloe thrée kindes citrinum epaticum caballinum plat sayth thrée maner kindes diuers goodnesse caballinum good epaticum better citrinum best knowen citrine colour deale reddish namely broken pouder thereof séemeth pouder saffron substaunce thereof cléere broken little péeces broken little péeces lesse stinking lesse bitter aloe yt called epaticum like lyuer colour browne reddish lyuer hath hole mouthes veynes dimme cléere bitter citrinum aloe called caballinū blacke dimme drastie bitter sauour horrible smell aloe caballinum distinguished pouder saffron vineger ten time plunged therein dryed taketh new disposition changeth color smell séemeth epaticum citrinum yet knowen broken froted finger anon found stinking bitter fareth epaticum citrinum manner aloe lesse stinking lesse bitter better though aloe bitter kind yet wonderful profitable wholesome purgeth fleumie cholar melancholy comforteth sinewy member clenseth purgeth stomack gleymie humor noyfull reléeueth head ache fumositie ye stomacke gréeueth ye head maketh ake aloe cleanseth sight vnstoppeth splene lyuer prouoketh menstruall bloud maketh good colour bodye discouloured kéepeth dropsie • ureth dropsie beginning powder thereof taken hony slayeth long wormes wombe maketh haue abide fall helpeth goutie men healeth botch priuie member easeth itching eyen cleanseth rotting matter gum mouth healeth soudreth clenseth drieth gréene wound bitter ye mouth sweete ye stomack cōforteth ye cold stomack feeble helpeth digestion al taken diosc plat auice additiō aloe iuice hearbe coniealed like gum vsed commonly purgatiue medicine cō fortable stomacke ¶of reede chap 7 réede called arundo meane betwéene trée hearbe brittle féeble trée hard boystous hearb smooth without hollow norished marreys waggeth winde hurteth ye hande soone splinter isid li 16 speaketh réede saith called arundo hath name aresco drieng drieth soone pondes inde groweth réede root thereof wring full swéete sauour licour drinke therefore varro saith yt réed inde groweth small trée humor wrong roote thereof swéete hony may striue wose lycour additiōthere diuers sort kind réede long poale réede cane ilands canare people vse staues speares theyr straigth hardnesse also sugar réede verye long within groweth iuice whereof commeth sugar common great reed grow marish ground ye small made quilles weauers fishing rod c ¶of amomo cap 8 amomum hath name smelleth cannell doeth called cinamom isidore saith libr 17 amomum groweth siria armenia trée thereof séedeth cluster cleauing togethers hath white flower like violet leaues like brione maketh swéete sléepes good smell thereof amomum hearbe good sauour dioscorides sayeth deale redde leaues ioyned much séede white flower uyolet amomum thrée maner kind one armenia called armenicum best reddish best smell vertue valew another kinde groweth moyst place watrye softe handling hath good sauour third called ponticum red long best new white full séed spred vppon red braunches sauouring heauie waight biteth tongue manner sharpnesse chewed hath colour diuers auicen sayth dioscorides also author meane manner amomum hath vertue heate drye heale smiting scorpion water sod comforteth eyen reléeueth sore ache amomum hath vertue asswage wombe ache destroy ventositie excite menstruall bloud lycour sod helpeth succoureth frentike men epatike sicke liuer haue podagre also also good receipt medicine amomum oft put though men vse ofte take stéede another hearbe called amonides like thereto colour hiew vnlike thereto vertue smell auicen saith additiō amomum little shrub growing armania round together like cluster grape hauing flower lyke white uiolet leaues lyke wythwinde white uine ignoraunt apothecary vse petroselium macedonicum call amomum verye true parseley macedonye whereas groweth plentifullye rembert dodoneus fo 608 ¶of aneto cap 9 anetum hearbe séed may kept thrée yeare great vertue discorides saith better renewed euery yeare roote thereof somwhat worth gréene valewe drye sayth hath vertue heate temper hard matter make softe open diuide depart destroy ventositie swellyng abate ache gnawing gut wombe breake stone excite menstruall bloud open vrine veynes abate yere commeth fulnesse make one sléepe well temper hard gathring body sod oyle layd thereto plaister wise flower thereof sodde wine doeth away head ache head baulmed therewith ash thereof layd dropping priuie chose woman drieth stauncheth dropping anetum sod oyle releaseth shrinking stonieng sinewes helpeth many passion affirmeth saith additiō anetum hot dry ye thirde degrée cureth bloudie flixe mixed cup akornes dronk ale wine waight halfe ounce halfe pint called dill ¶of aniso cap 10 anise hath vertue anetum hath swéet sauor séed therof small round many men call dulcinium said plat hath vertue temper make soft consume wast destroy ventositie comfort digestion open stopping liuer ye splene break stone excite menstruall bloud open amend inner wayes though séed small quantitie yet full good profitable vertue full healthfull wholsome additiō anisum anise séed ye vitall aqua vitae good ye pouder dronk wine poyson ¶of allio chap 11 garlike called allium hath name olendo smelling smelleth strongly isid saith li 16 smell thereof strong yt passeth ouercommeth strong smell therefore men yt must néeds passe stinking place make cleane vncleanly rotten place arme defend themselues strong sauce garlike diosco saith garlike hath many vertues property good euill compouned diuers vertues saith garlike disturbeth wombe stomacke bréedeth thirst bréedeth whelkes wound body layd thereto cholaricke men eate much thereof maketh body hot bréedeth lepra cause madnes frensie grieueth sight maketh dimme therefore noyeth cholaricke men kinde bréedeth red cholar increaseth burnt cholar helpeth well steumaticke men colde garlike double maner kinde wilde tame wilde called scordeon among phisitions floure therof shall gathered put medicine worketh violentlye tame garlike doth tame garlike vse head kinde thereof many manner vertues found therin vertue dissolue temper consume waste put venyme venimous thing therefore without cause called triacle churles among authours old time diosc saith helpeth best biting venime mad dogge eaten salt nut rew stampe foure togethers giue ofte thereof patient quantitie great nut wine laye confection sore without helpeth wound draweth venime wasteth kéepeth saueth deliuereth perill effectually triacle garlike hath vertue open temper diuide depart cut wast great humour thicke therfore helpeth haue stone may well pisse exciteth menstruall bloud cleanseth wombe slayeth long wormes wormes wombe taken sauce pepper iuice mint vineger garlike abateth ache gut reynes also cleansed stamped sod oyle layd plaister sore place helpeth also morphea leprosie ye skin place morphea garsed froted garlyke stamped therto plaister also helpeth biting adder bée stamped layd thereto oyle bay dios saith also helpeth haue dropsie wasteth dryeth humour betwéene skinne flesh swageth swellyng cleanseth healeth great fowle bloudie wound soundeth pouder garlike burned laid therto garlicke sodde well water doth away sore ach place swelling also néedeth beware taken meates grieueth eyen meane verse allia vina venus pulius ventus faba fumus garlike almost hot dry ye forth degree ista nocent oculis sed vigilare magi meaning garlike wine venus pouder winde beanes smoke grieue eyen waking doth lib de plant arist sayth garlike like lily accordeth therwith disposition head cloues hath vertue seminall cloues ye roote greines top stalke ye cloue nether head garlike commeth plant garlyke doth like wise séede groweth ye top stalke cloue ouer head commeth also plant séede therefore cloue garlike set earth bringeth forth plant likewise doth séede hath manye pilles leaues stéeple wise hollow poorie stalke also garlike lily first hath séede stalke greines clustered together within small thin leafe onyon doeth cluster greynes together norisheth sendeth small feete garlike hath hairie rootes lyke lily saffron root garlike lily differ roote garlike spreadeth boughes lily doth garlike reneweth leaues reneweth rootes seedeth second yeare sowen therefore garlike hath many cloues spreading cloues may féeding nourishing second rootes second leaues stalk thereof seconde leaues grow stalk cloues therof vanisheth away earth fareth onion garlike onion diuers euery cloue garlike set commeth plant fareth lily cloue planted earth sendeth stalk commeth euerie cloue lily garlike seminall vertue fareth onion commeth euery cloue onion onion though set whole head springeth plant set seminall vertue euery cloue onion whole head garlike lily diuers stalke ye spire garlike springeth one ende cloue spire ye lily springeth side cloue end huc v que anst de plan secund nouam translationem additiōthere 3 sort garlike allium satiuum garden garlike crow garlike beare garlyke called ramsons ¶of wormwood chap 12 abseynthium wormwood full sharpe hearbe hot drye full sowrish bitter dioscorides saith ther two manner kindes one gréene colour sower bitter sauour deale hoarishe lesse bitter lesse vertuous gathered end springing time dried shadow kept yeare great might vertue hath contrary vertues plate saith laxeth bindeth bindeth thicke substaunce sowrnes laxeth heate bitternes taken body find thick matter hard sowrenes thicknesse substance maketh thicke hard cause binding matter able digested tempreth softneth heate beareth downe sowrenesse putteth body sirop made wormwood helpeth lyuer comforteth stomacke exciteth appetite withstandeth dronkennesse healeth iaundes amendeth chaungeth colour iuice thereof pouder sod vnstoppeth splene solueth abateth ache stomacke wombe ache commeth ventositie iuyce thereof dropped ye eares drieth vp moysture runneth eares wormewood stamped bull lyuer put eares distroyeth tincklyng ringing therein comforteth amendeth hearing iuyce thereof swageth head ache commeth fumositie ye stomacke wormwood pouder commin hony doth away mole speckle ache commeth smiting layd thereto playster wise iuice thereof slayeth long wormes wombe wormes eares dropped therein iuice thereof dronke cleereth sight doth away rednesse web eyen ofte put therein wormwood keepeth saueth bookes cloathes fretting mouse wormes layd therewith chestes coffer macrobius saith helpeth biting wesells dragon healeth dronke licour sodde swageth ventositie swelling wombe dronke diosc saith hath ouer vertues condition property bée full good infecteth tast sowrenesse bitternesse grieueth smel strong odour maketh milke wine bitter al swéet thing medled therefore bées yt vse floure wormewoode make hony bitter diosco sayth plinius saith wormwood shal giuen haue feauers wormwood letteth wambling ye sea first dronke exciteth sleepe laid vnwittingly vnder head withstandeth mothes wormes layd among clothes maketh blacke haire ye haire anoynted oyntment made iuice thereof oyle rose additiōthere thrée sort wormewood first absynthium chap 13 merch called apium common hearb known nigh men hath name somtime victor garland isid saith libro 17 hercules made first garlandes hearbe rootes thereof withstandeth mightely venime isi saith apium many maner kind saieth one called petrosum hath name lyke apium leaues apium gréekes called silenum groweth stonye place mountaines rockes therefore latines call petrocilium perseley petrapium isid saith merch apium another manner kinde dioscorid saith apium frog apium laughing apium emeroydesmarsh parsele smallach apium frog hath name ofte founde watry place frog apium sod wine layd playster wise wombe laid reynes helpeth abateth ache thereof apium osus laughing hath name working purgeth melancholike humour superfluitie humour commeth e • e • gnesse discomfort telleth eaten dronke great quantitie slayeth man laughing helpeth also stone difficultie pissing men pisse often little exciteth menstruall bloud sod water wine nether part body washed bathed therewith apium embroydes hath yt name pouder therof laid thereto fordrieth bleeding commune apium cōmon merch vnstoppeth openeth ye splene breaketh stone destroyeth iaundes helpeth dropsie frensie ye patient head ofte anoynted iuyce thereof medled oyle rose vineger roote thereof succoureth venymous biting withstandeth venime diosc sayth apium grieueth noyeth haue falling euill dissolueth softeneth matter moueth vpward grieueth child also much moisture feeblenesse vertue straightnesse member way age disposed euill therfore nourice féedeth child shall spare apium least childe take euill diosc sayth plat also ¶of aristologia cap 14 aristologia full medicinable hearb though bitter thereof two manner kindes long round either hotte drye roote medicinable leaues shall gathered haruest kept two yeare hath vertue dissolue put wast venyme maketh good breath softeneth hard splene openeth stopping thereof doth away ache wombe side helpeth haue podagre falling euill men lims sinewes shronken powder therof iuyce mint helpeth venemous biting pouder thereof fretteth dead flesh easely softly setter wound roote hearbe putteth dead child ye wombe sod wine hactenus dioscorides de aristologia plinius saith isid li 17 best woman child dronke pepper wine cleanseth filth yt trauayle child purgeth mother exciteth purgeth menstruall bloud additiō aristolochia longa rotunda clematitis pistolochia saracenica foure kindes set foorth dodoneus called english aristologia birthwort hartwort second called rounde aristologia third called braunched fourth long aristologia hearbe good poyson stinging biting venemous beast aristolochia rotunda doth beautifie cleanse fasten téeth often froted rubbed pouder thereof ¶of agno casto chap 15 agnus castus hearbe hot drie hath vertue keéepe men woman chast plin taken whether pouder decoction leaues alone leade bed sleepe vppon therefore called castus saye chast cleane pure ¶of artemisia chap 16 artemisia artemisia mugwort poutevveede damasomum called mother gardein twentye dayes earth earing afterwarde romanes lordes field balsamum spred many mountaines hilles tree lyke vine mircus filleth mountain spreadeth uine without railing vndersetting boughes grace thereof first iuyce second seede third rinde last stock best sweetest smell greatest seede heauie biting tast feruent mouth redde coulour huc vsque plinius lib 12 cap 27 diolcorides sayeth manner kinde balsamum groweth babylonia seauen well bée manner balsamum set another place beareth neither flowre fruit summer time boughes bée softly cut knife boane shéeres sharpe least trée hurt within perish rinde thirled bée set violls glasse gather therein ye drop fall one drop done roufe mouth heateth braine séemeth fire hath vertue dissolue temper consume wast keepe saue dead body good sauour meddeled trée earth gum trée foule blacke counterfeited gumme bitter tast whence euer commeth substaunce thereof gleamie stoppeth draweth therfore diocorides sayth plat also contrary smoothnesse matter able receiue writing letter figure made table bore wel planed receiueth white colour thervpon diuerse letter diuerse figure shape written made afterward maye put away easily soone isidore sayth vtter trée called hec buxus inner stock hoc buxum therefore one said manner hec buxus crescit hoc buxum crescere nescit appeareth woulde meane tree called buxus groweth called buxum groweth trée sad matter fast nutrimentall humour thereof full gleamie cleauing togethers albumasar sayeth lib vegil therefore stocke therof hard sad heauie sinketh water hebenus doth sadnesse fastnesse stock hath pore aire might enter entering might fleete aboue water albumasar sayeth therefore leaues therof long gréeue fall soone one falleth another commeth steed hath many smal leaues thicke little fruit none shauing boxe colde drie stauncheth fluxe sod pit water dioscorides saith dyeth haire yt oft washed broth therof sauour therof bitter plinius saith lib 17 cap 17 smell heauie though grieue tast sauour yet comforteth sight alway greene namely summer winter ye leaues therof waxe deale pale fall albumasar saieth cause gleamy humour therein much fleeting moysture roote therefore leaues fall heat commeth humour drawen outward working heat leaues gréene colde commeth humour suittest inward great drinosses coulour yeolow pale boxe groweth hot place stony therefore hard sadly warred trée within smooth couenable bée planed holdeth long time shape figure made therein thereof bée made fayre image long also bore bore ordeined made kéepe muske manner spicery good many manner v necessity ouer noyous greath letting time rehearse héereall arowe wée haue rehearsed bée sufficient slute additiōthe lennes boxe hot dry vsed medicine verye hurtfull braine balauftias chap sodden uine get layde sunng breast pit also pouder thereof healeth closeth sendreth wounde pouder thereof healeth game cleanseth date away rotting therof fastneth maketh stedfast root saith also saith therof double kind blacke white either iuyce dropped ye nosethrils purgeth head abateth ach eares amendeth doth away nit vncleannesse ye head speckle mole face restoreth saueth haire leaues caustocke ye bete stock taketh strength turneth trée saide de natura plantarum additiō beta candida beta nigra beta nigra romana beetes hot drie abstertiue especially white béete yt cleansing nature ceder • chap 23 cedrus trée gréekes call cedros ceomones dri • sticon vnderstand humour burning trée leaues therof answereth lykenesse cipressus isidore sayth li 17 sayth ther cedery trée merrye smell indureth abideth long time neuer destroyed mought neyther terredo tree worme ceder indureth alwaye thereof bée rastees timber made belonging place king temple also gumme trée called cedrina necessarye kéepeth saueth bookes bookes bée vermissed gumme bée fret wormes neither age time trée groweth affrica siria namely mount libany ceder trée high trée lady quéene trées rabanus sayth super psalt fayre sight alway gréene good smell smell driueth away serpent al manner veniuous wormes saith swéete fruite apple ceder great long bée eitrine else yeolowe coulour wonderfull smell pleasaunt sauour hath thrée manner sauores middle graines apple chrine sowre without swéete rinde meane betwéene swéet sowre pith fruit within ceder many diuerse great dooing vertues also full medicinable wholsome gum therof shaped manner lyke top sharp seruent burneth drieth dioscorides saith wipeth cleanseth away dimnesse eien slaieth destroieth ye wormes eares helpeth agaynst ach féeth helpeth biting serpent also doth awaye tingling ringing eares iuyce hisop swageth abateth swelling iawes healeth certaine wound lung kéepeth laueth soft flesh rotting ceder trée anointed owne gumme kéepeth saueth dead bodyes rosting saide therein also seede ceder abateth cough exciteth menstruall bloud bringeth secundinas bagges child bée wrapped mother wombe cleanseth purgeth mother softeneth slaketh sinewes bée shrunke crampe maketh one pisse cleanseth awaie grauell reines bladder dioscoride setteth many vertues ceder iuyce fruit thereof plinius speaketh maner ceder wise certaine trée called modica first full fruite nigh alwayes fruit thereof ripe greene sowre blossome seldome seene tree many men call tree assyria sayth additiōthere two fort ceder great small small fruit also two fortes one sharp vnto ceder tree formable necessarye edisteng building towres temple greate pompeous coifices may • efayleth neuer abideth duteth lasteth alwayes first estate condition hath right good sauour swéetest cinamum thereof written ecc 1 exod 30 glose saith shrubbe groweth inde aethiopia passeth two cubit quātity called cinamum hath small stalkes bended coulour ash blacke colour broke commeth breath seene subtill small canell déere greate lesse worth held lib 17 isido meaneld canell hath name cinamoro rinde thereof small round cane groweth shore stocke small braunches broke thereof commeth breath mist smelling wéetly super ecc 5 cap 24 glose sayth ye cauell short trée good smell swéete coulour ash twice good medicine pipe also lib 12 ca 21 plinius speaketh canell sayth canel cassia men tolde fable olde time found bird neaste specially phoenix neast may founde falleth owne weight smitten downe lead arrowes men doe segine make thing déere greate price truth meaneth canell groweth among troglodites lydela aethiopia commeth long space sea ship hauen gellenites short trée two enbites long span long least hath stocke foure sixe inch greate smelleth dryeth drynesse lyking thereto fructuous winter contrary kinde trées groweth among brier thick bush therefore gathered without great trauel difficultie man hath leaue gather thereof ye sunrising sun going downe gathered priest measure dealeth braunches taketh thereof parte space time merchaunts buye deale chiefe goodnesse thereof thickest smallest braunch middle flocke little dame nothing lyttle rinde rinde vertue grace canell therfore top ouer partes best goodnesse much rinde trée within little naught worth comparison rinde huc vsque plinlus li 12 dioscorides pla meane canell hee third degree dry second degree canell double manner kind yt wit smal great great lesse worth small leaue vornitiue medicine small better néedfull vadirines best shinne small sharpe biting sauour medled swéetnesse deale red coulour much good smell canell deale white lesse worth good smell canel hath vertue comfort braine hath vermedy softnesse part souder fasten canell hath manye manner vertues dioscori sayth abateth cough commeth thicke moisture pouder thereof medled vineger doth away scab dryeth moisture ein meddled colirium ointment eien swageth swelling reines eureth dropsie healeth biting créeping wormes comforteth appetite exciteth menstruall bloud openeth stopping defieth meale drinke dissolueth vndeeth destroyeth postumes canell dronke wine bringeth secundinas bagges child bée mother wombe wipeth away dimnese eyen succoureth helpeth sounding cardiacle passion additiōthe trée cinamon much vnlyke bay trée especially leaues beareth barrie doth baye trée lesse white doubtlesse therefore home barke tree gathered manner euery third yeare cut branch tree great plentie iland zaylon first gathered yet swéete moneth waxeth drie barke onelye spice wood lyke firre tree light casia chap 27 casia mention made exod 80 certeine kinde spicery good smell molde groweth arabia isidore saleth rod strong rinde red purple leaues rind pepper lyke canell vertue mighty effect déed therof medicine double weight taken stéed canell isidore sayth glose super exod 30 meaneth casia bréedeth watrye place groweth strongly giueth good smell leb 12 ca 21 plinius speaketh casia sayth trée casia groweth fast cinamum field three cubites long braunch greatet braunch canell hath thrée colour first white redde blacke parte best white lesse worth soone eaten wormes holed soft subtaunce lesse bitternesse vertue rinde casia proued new smelling sauour coulour noble casia deale swéete biting sharpe sauour swéete merrye smell brown pepper coulour heauye weight casia best breaketh soone bendeth foldeth another manner kinde ca lyke balsamus saba smell bitter therefore first blacke deale sweete biting sauour good smell praysed among phisitions huc vseq plinius ibidem platea dioscorides meane speake two manner casia one called casia sestula casia lienea rinde lyttle trée groweth nigh march babylonia threof diuerse manner kinde one like canell deale redde round sadds substaunce foldeth broken beaten standeth hath sharpe sauour deale sweete vnneth phisitions vse manner kinde manner kind deale bitter deale diuerse colour phisitions vse manner kinde best breaketh seene bendeth foldeth hath sharpe sauour meddeled swéetnesse good smell hath broken somwhat white coulours distinguished within withred medled among sometime teined medling rinde capar knowen deale bitter sauour hath vertue diuisitiue subtil substance also casia hath vertue temper diuide depart hath owne quality vertue consume wast hath good smell vertue comforte cureth rumes colde cause helpeth haue falling euill comforteth braine purgeth reines bladder ripeth healeth postumes vnstoppeth liuer splerie remes hideth doth awaye stinke mouth chewed exciteth menstruall bloud comforteth helpeth fowning failing heart stroppe bée made mention made eccl 4 tren vlt saffron called crocus hearbe hath name crocus citie coricius aboundaunce thereof isidore sayeth libro 17 hearbe flower hath name crocus flower vertue called crocum freshest newest best yt good smell long little som white whole broken gobbet péeces smelleth well couloureth hand toucheth lyght sharp knowen olde wet sometime counterfaited thing called crocomagina increase waight foyle siluer ground espied slow grinding chaungeth owne smell sod crocomagina called superfluitie spicerie saffron oyntment made huc v que isid dioscorides meaneth speaketh two manner saffron one called hortensis hath name garden groweth therein called orientalis hath also name place groweth best shall put vomitiue medicine beareth purple flower head violet middle thereof thrée flower foure best thereof somwhat red red whitest shall forsaken saffron may kept ten yeare hot drye first degrée temperate qualitie therefore comfortatiue helpeth much féeblenesse stomack fayling heart doth away rednesse eyen commeth bloud defflyng ground rose white egge laid eye dio saith pla also saffron hath another property gréene winter long leaues winter neuer colde summer leaues falleth fadeth withereth altogether groweth againe middle haruest floures breaketh small stalkes arist sayth li vegita saffron much lyke onion ascolonia roote neuerthelesse diuers varieth either roote saffron continued body séedeth ascolonia doth seminall vertue ye roote cloues saffron leane cloues thereof springeth one side fareth ascolonia onion gardeines cloues saffron springeth place generation veynes cloues saffron hath propertie arist saith hath rootes cleaneth thereby earth sucketh nourishing féeding onion garlike head saffron great ripe beginneth departed dealed multiplyed manye heades theyr fell skin rootes euerye groweth plant thereby knowen head roote vertue seminall vertue multiplication preseruation kind therof plin li 20 sayth saffron soone tempered honye swéete lycour tempred soonest wine water best medicine destroyeth swellyng boyling sore ache eyen namely medled wine best stomacke lyuer drinketh saffron first shall dronken garland thereof letteth dronkennes letteth man yt may dronken causeth sléepe moueth head exciteth venus flower thereof done euill called holy fire helpeth cureth saffron made oyntment citrine yeolow called clogomagon gréeke helpeth running eyen best dieth téeth spettle pourgeth botch head abateth swelling cureth biting serpent spider stinging scorpion huc vsque plinius additiō crocus hortensis crocus saracenicus english saffron best colour medicine ¶of cepa chap 42 onion called cepa cepe hearbe hath vertue roote seede therfore called cepe isidore saith hath naught head lib de plantes aristotle speaketh • alon sayeth onion ascoloina beareth leaues twice one yeare onion hath stalke beareth séede thereon hath roote clypped many cloues hath ther vnder rootes though hayrie thereby great roote taketh nourishing féeding radicall humor sent thé hearbe ye first yere hearb profiteth roote second yeare solved séedeth commonly second yeare beareth séed one skin garlike doth top stalke seede springeth spreadeth small stalkes onion double kinde tame wilde aristotle calleth canina hound onion onion canina hath white flower towarde heauen somwhat gréene toward earth onion helpeth postlimes tame onion hath hollow stalke without knot reneweth ioynts leaues aristo saith libr predicto dioscorides saith tame onion good profitable meate medicine gleymie colde kinde namelye ruen long red white drye new rawe sodde doth away griefes wombe abateth stinch mouth softneth wombe maketh meate sauourie iuyce thereof helpeth haue litargio sléeping euill abaseth ofte ache éares woman milke dropped therein eaten couenably forekerneth departeth gleymie humour openeth mouthes veynes exciteth vrine menstruall bloud bringeth venime quencheth biting mad dog helpeth venimes bitings clarifieth skinne openeth poores exciteth therefore sweate maketh break giueth ye body nourishing eaten rawe grieueth cholericke men accordeth fleamatike men bréedeth thirst swelling noieth grieueth head sharpnesse eate much bréedeth madnesse woodnes maketh dreadfull dreames namely men new recouered sicknesse eate much thereof onion yée eate maketh eien watrye grieueth light sauour huc vsque dioscorides additiōthere diuers sort onion white red additiōcucumbers colde moyst second degrée ¶of cucurbita chap 45 cvcurbita name gréeke originall thereof vncertaine latines isi sayth li 1 • plin saith many kind therof cucurbita tame wilde tame spreadeth boughes braunches leaues uine doeth bindeth selfe certaine fastening binding vine doth beareth somewhat white flower spring thereof namely night bloometh beareth blossom without vndersetling fruite thereof fayleth rotteth without reared vp ground rayled log rod vine platea saith cucurbita colde moyst complection temperate quality found hot country land séede thereof sowen commeth hearbe thereof commeth white flower fruite last full séede pith rinde therof first soft hard trée ripe fruite thereof newe accordeth meate séede medicine seede thereof hath vertue depart shed hard matter substaunce thereof subtill helpeth therefore stopping liuer reynes bladder haue feauer ague meate medicine rosted fried purgeth matter vrine lareth abateth heate comforteth sicke seede thereof therewith doth away réeses eyen leaues thereof sod stamped helpeth wound seede therof dronk wine ouercommeth venime shall eaten bréedeth swelling li 17 isid saith wild cucurbita ye coloquintida maner withwinde well bitter hearb springeth braunches toward ground cucurbita doth hath great leaues heauie smell cucurbita hath isid saith looke de natura colloquintide seemeth first maner cucurbita second daphni cap 48 laurel trée called daphnis gréeke laurus latine isidore saith li 17 hath name laurus lau • praising great worship praising conqueror sometime crowned garlandes boughes laurell trée old time called laudea afterward changed r tree called laurus sometime ye vndertide called medidies isi saith ye gréekes call trée daphne alway gréene winter sūmer therfore •• ctors speciallye cap 30 pliny speaketh laurell trée saieth tree properly hallowed triumphal worship conquerours house emperours bishop worshippeth house maketh faire two kindes one called delphica ciprica laurell delphica delphes first crowned first uictors afterwarde laurell ciprica romanes crowned victor manye manner kinde laurell trée diuers gréene colour greatnesse leaues likenesse bayes trée many manner kinde plin reckoneth thirteene manner kindes tree among reckoneth one manner kinde hallowed great iupiter appollo delphicus therefore lande beareth laurell trée safe lightening field house appollo vsed giue answeres presence laurell tree men supposed trée according seruice worship god cause worship triumphes victorie lawful defile ye laurell trée vnhonest vnlawful v offered set vpon altar please god therewith emperour tiberius caesar thundering lightening vsed garland laurell trée head dread lightening sayde also ther plinius telleth wonderous thing emperour sate drucilla empresse certaine gardeine eagle threwe right high place wonderful white hen empresse lappe whole sound hen held hir bill bough laurell trée full bayes diuinors tooke heed hen sowed bayes kept wisely came woode called silua triumphans wer wood worship victorie masterie afterward emperour bare laurell trée hand garlande thereof head afterward emperor ye wise shuld crowned laurell trée wood victory huc vsque plin diosco telleth laurel trée sayth trée séemly shape great smell good wonderfull vertue ye gréene leaues thereof smell full well bée stamped healeth stinging bées waspes doth away swelling keepeth bookes cloathes among mothes wormes saueth frétling gnawing fruite laurell trée called bayes browne red without white within vnctuous round shape hot complection drye second degrée subtill substaunce vertue pourging comforting therfore profitable put many medicine bayes made precious oyle helpeth many euills colde passion additiōthe bay trée taken lauriell notwithstanding two seuerall trées yet lauriell rather hearb trée read dod ¶of diptanno chap 49 diptannus medicinable hearbe roote thereof accordeth medicine substaunce thereof shall whole pearsed falleth pouder broke hath vertue dissolue temper drawe wast venime venemous biting dronk laid wound dioscorides saith platea also sayd hath vertue • riacle many thing thing put thereto exciteth menstruall bloud bringeth secundine bag ye childe ye mother womb bringeth dead childe ye mother womb helpeth haue falling euill palsie iuyce rewe saith pli li 26 ca 8 said hinde taught first vertue diptannus eateth hearb may calue easelyer sooner hurte arrow seeketh hearbe cateth putteth yron wound basilius saith exameron ambrosius expositor super ca speaketh hinde calues isidore saith hearb groweth manye place groweth fat field little worth groweth drie place stonie best little thereof tasted heateth mouth saith libr 17 isidore saith manner diptannus mount creta called candie thereof hearbe diptannus hath name virgil sayth hinde wounded goeth landes seeketh hearbe diptannus hearb great vertue driueth putteth yron bedre therefore beast smitten arrowes eate thereof driue yron body hearbe hath maner might war driue arrowes dart quarells isidore sayth additiō dictani candie wherof thrée sort right dictani hot drye like heneroyall subtiller partes good ¶of draguntea ca 50 draguntea hearbe hath name sea stalke thereof 〈…〉 keled adder hath lykenes adder dragon isi saith lib 17 many men call hearbe serpentaria colubrina hath red floure departed shaped mouth serpent middle thereof springeth adder tongue sharpe blacke round middle floure thereof riseth head great seede round first gréene red beginneth ripe hearbe hath great vertue might diosc saith roote thereof dried made pouder water rose • • anseth face maketh cleere good colour healeth fester french sope dryeth vp maketh mouth thereof wide bone within broken rotten may drawen taken full helpeth canker vineger hot lime leaues thereof sod wine ripeth thirde degree draganto cap 51 dragantum plat auicen meane manner gum certaine tree tree kinde humour hardened norishing heat strengthening cold thereof treble kinde white pure cleere best deale red citrine good ye white hath earth medled therewith white accordeth cold medicine red citrine hot may saued kept fortie yeare hath vertue cooling moysting cleansing hath colde moysture hath vertue fastning thing together vertue gum helpeth euills breast electuaries sirops moysteth drie breast restoreth humour lost abateth rough bealeth chipped thins whelkes lyppes mouth cleanseth face maketh white helpeth haue gowles bloudie fluxe said platearius ¶of ebeno chap 52 ebenus trée growing aethiopia blacke colour plaine trée smooth groping handling hard heauie straitnesse pore sinketh anone head abateth ache iuyce thereof heat oyle put ye eares helpeth deasenesse also iuie compounded contrary worketh contrarie cause therefore hath vertue riping drawing cleansing easing therefore oft leaues thereof layed sore gumme therof dissolueth tempreth helpeth stone goate bucke fed iuie leaues maketh sharpe bloud breake stone bladder reines ther manner iuie deaw falleth leaues thereof wereth gleymie turneth glewe vertue thereof great assayed phisicke smoke thereof exciteth menstruall bloud bringeth secundines bag childe mother abateth reume comforteth head wit helpeth agaynst cough stixe sharpe ende stalke cubite long roote thereof laxeth vpward downwards shall neuer vse eleborus ye master digested made readye hand yet fall wiselye therefore hippocrates saith thou wilt take eleborus moue thy body least thou ouer sléepe hath vertue resolue moyst matter tourne ventositie thereof commeth stopping spirites death dioscor saith platea also blacke eleborus much perilloua additiō read ficus hath name fruitefulnesse fruitful tree beareth fruite thrée foure time one yeare one ripeth another springeth anone soone figge trée aegypt fructuous holden stocke thereof done water sinketh anone ground riseth commeth vp aboue water hath lyen mudde common course kinde wet waight moysture abide vnder water pithagoras time hawkes sed figges brought vse flesh stronger meate said fig doe away shriueling skinne face wrinkle hand olde men eate therof among theyr meate telleth full cruell bull become milde anone tied fig trée telleth figge trée may made beare well fruite remedy trée together make chéese floure corde • casealis humour thereof full vnctuous therefore fig tree beareth much fruite vnctuous tourneth fruite thin watrye tourneth leanes broad clouen sharp endes sayd genitals baulined iuyce thereof moued lecherie mouing spoken glose sup gen 3 ibi fécerunt sibi de folijs sicus perisumata arist saith happeneth fig trée wereth barren sometime default humour sometime superfluitie humour either case needeth medicine default humour ye gardeiner doth thereto couenable dounge fresh water superfluitie humour pearceth ye tree nailes voydeth superfluitie humour sayd de arborum medicina lib 14 ca 8 plinius speaketh al rehearsed isid saith ye fig trée aegypt beareth like trée morus quantitie leaues sight beareth fruit foure time summer first springeth ripe héerto fig tree cipris like burgeneth bringeth fruite foure time burgening thereof ripeth except first carued cut superfluitie milke may passe thereof knops thereof commeth foorth without leaues ende bough like populer roote oliue leaues lyke thereto greatnesse trée fig trée tender trée feeble therefore soone grieued strength colde namely beginneth burgen spring also libr 12 ca 6 plin saith saith figge tree inde beareth certaine small apple hath many bough thicke bend ye groūd weight sticke ground spring new branch ye old stock maketh great shaddowe heards come abide vnder succour heate winde weather ouermost boughes trée stretch vpward full high side voughes spread wide olde trée growen make great shadow leaues thereof full broad shaped somewhat lyke shield beareth many apple small passe vnneth bignesse beane riped among leaues heate sunne swéete accounted miracle héereto lib 15 cap 19 plin saith trée called wilde fig trée hath another name called caprificus ripeth neuer giueth hath selfe often gardeiners make cliftes rinde roote fig trée graffe theron graffes caprificus couenable graffing thereof roote disposed receiueth new aire good humour also might vertue gréene colour white humor matter fig passeth nourishing thereof rehearsed ye tretise de causa fructificationis arbonim c herbarum also saith trées shall set nigh trées beare well fruit blast winde may borne therefrom figge trée thereto southerne winde better northerne winde northerne winde grieueth fig trée thé southerne winde therefore fig trées thriue lesse north countrey white humor thereof wasted remoued wind hath masterie effect fig trée touching rootes leaues rinde fruite looke tarctatu de carica litera c openly contained additiō ficus satiua ficus siluestris figges pound salt rue nutmeg withstandeth poyson corruption aire secret preseruatiue mithridates king pontus vsed venime poyson ¶of fraxino ca 62 ash called fraxinus trée groweth rough place mountaines isid saith thereof made shaftes speares therefore ouidius saith et fraxinus vtilis hastis say ash good shaftes speares lib 16 ca 13 pliny saith among trées kinde hath gendered ash right profitable high trée round euen sharpe vpward lease made noble praising homerus speare achilles place lyke cedar trée beguileth buyer rinde away leaues thereof helpeth venime iuyce thereof wrong dronke helpeth best serpentes ash hath great vertue serpent come shadow thereof morning euen serpent set betwéene fire ash leaues flye fire sooner leaues greece ye leaues thereof poison beast grieueth beast chewe cudde grieueth beast italy bloometh first twig spring therof leaueth leaues beare flower thereof double kinde gréekes tell one long knottie leaues hards lyke laurell trée men put difference ash diuers place groweth ash groweth field hath crispe leaues ash groweth mountaines hath thick leaues leaues better huc vsque plinius platea saith ashe trée hot drye second degrée rinde leaues thereof anise mushrumpes groweth thereon accordeth medicine stauncheth flire wombe spewing also sod raine water vinegar layd stomacke additiōthe lye made ye ash barke ash trée cureth white scurffe séeth saide lye bramble leaues ¶of fago cap 63 beech mast good deere hoggesa béeth called fagus trée matter therof néedful many thing lib 17 isidore sayth béeth tree beareth mast hath name fagus sometime men liued fruit thereof tooke meate théreof fage gréeke say eate isidore saith libro 17 cap 7 sayeth mast béech cornered closed smooth skin lyke nut kernell rind soft marrow therof derest mise fatteth glires séemeth mise somewhat quantitie fruit accordeth culuours turtle feedeth nourisheth rind trée full profitable namelye among north picts therof made vessel seruing diuerse v dooing hee saith cap 10 also sayde mast therof ful swéet nourishing féeding flesh beast bee fedde therewith full profitable may bo sodde light trée full sadde fast substaunce pory full hoales dureth therefore ful long saith neuerthéles substaunce therof accordeth many thing make shingle thing belongeth building substance béech cleane pure eaten wormes néedful glasiers craft ash therof thing blast fire glasse craftely arayed lyttle fuell founde accordeth wel euery manner wonderfull work trée smooth many pore soone eaten wormes rotteth soone soone cloue set fire plinius meaneth béech beareth flowres trée tilia doth well smelling neuerthelesse bées haunt flowres therof gather wilde honnie hollownesse trées additiō men doe gather nut béech man vse yet béech sweete good cat almost good medicine kernell pine apple faba chap 64 beane called faba hath name ethimology gréeke isid saith lib 17 manner codwarr serueth potage olde time men vsed eat therof héer double kind one called beane aegypt common beane sometime called fresa men gren oft grind breake saith dios saith yt beanes bée sowen garden fieldes stalke therof ariseth edge corner great hollow knot leafe leaues euery knop leaues broad plaine sound narrow endes beanes beare white flowres red black speck aboue end good smell bées haunt much flowres beanes stalke bée many coddes think long distinguished many den chamber beanes set theyr place departed coddes first gréene without white within softe hardneth little little heate sunne blacke last token ripenesse dioscorides platearius meane beane colde dry except greene moyst first degrée nourisheth lyttle eaten gréene bréedeth thick humour swelling ouer parte wombe greeneth therefore stomacke bréedeth thicke bloud melancholike also thick smoak greeueth braine therwith beanes cause vaine dreaines dreadfull séething roasting thereof swelling ventositye abated destroied ye eateth beanes continually ach gnawing guttes roapes beanes stop splene make harde wombe beanes eaten hulles harde defie bréed much swelling cleane beane hull away cleanseth cleansing therof purgeth face cleanseth lung dronke bealeth postumes teates pappes doth away wormes blearinesse eien medled rose stencheth humour fall come eien chewed layd temple stauncheth bloud runneth slit laide beine cut stancheth milke runneth breast helpeth haue podagre goutes sod shéeps lallowe laid sore smiteth swellinges gathering postumes bée sodde uineger layde thereto beginning libro 18 cap 12 plinius speaketh property kind beane sayth among poulse groweth roddes beanes called best many meddle beanes bread corne make ye bread yt heauie beanes bée dampned pithagoras sentence sayd oft vse therof wit dulled cause many dreames else men meane dead men soules therein therefore vatro sayeth bishoppe shoulde eate beanes among corne onely beane springeth leaues full wathing moone sod sea water salt water sowen going downe seauen star called pliades ripe gathered winter loueth water blometh drought blossomed amendeth land yt groweth stéed doung therefore thessalia field ye beanes grow eared beanes bloome many place beanes growe without trauaile tilling namely mauritonia landes north occean hard vnneth may sod beanes growe aegypt sharpe prickes therfore crocodile flye dreade least eyen bée hurt sharp prickes beane x cubites long head popie therein beanes closed head red rose beanes growe stalk coddes genicolatus stalke therof ha •• • enches lar • e leaues 〈…〉 somewhat bitter root thereof eaten rawe sod like quantity rootes réed rue vsque plinius lib 18 cap 12 saith chap 17 virgillus inquit intro et amurta fabam profundentibus grandesiere cam promittit one sayth beanes grow sooner thriue better watred pisse thrée day ere sowen hue vsque plin additiōgréene beanes ripe colde moist bée drie haue power binde wild field beane serueth vse man wholesome scarce good prouender horse except wheate bran well baked hard frumento chap 65 wheate called frumentum hath name fruendo vsing eating thereof corne hath name fruges isidore sayth ouer part roote called frumen sauour meate principallye knowen propertie wheate haue eyles high eare graines corne hollowe hoales manner wheate stalke springeth roote eare stalke inuironed small hole graines corne bée closed eare groweth small cyles sharpe dartes thereof eare hath name spica dartes bée called spiculum eyles defend eare dartes small bird shoulde bite eare take awaie graines wheate small beast stalke compassed leaues bulles succoured therewith bend grounde weight heauinesse corne eare stalke called stipula vstipula hath name vsto burnt gathered strawe burnt helpe amende lande kepte fodder beast called palea first meate yt laid beast namely countreies tuscan kinde thereof colde suffereth snowe falleth shodde hot compelleth apple ripe huc vsque isidorus lib 17 many manner corne called fenmencum isidore sayth pli also lib 18 wheate barly rye meale whome shall spoken afterward owne place corne called frumentum generally men shall take héed ground sowen qualitie grounde corne thriueth one ground faileth another fordryeth plinius sayeth vnderstoode corne lande also manner time sowing must regarded corne soone sowen late winter séede soone sowen summer séede late sowen sowen vnder sorrow aboue wheat sowen certaine manner time certaine barly manner time meale commin hieronimus saieth expresly super esay man take héede couenable time sowing gathering corne plinius sayth libro 18 done better one time another corne gathered full moone saued corruption also fayre weather time sowe serere latine commeth sereno coelo isidore sayeth serenum coelum cléere skye manner speach men shall sowe greate raine stormes virgil sayeth plinius sayeth cap 13 winde bée strong corne apayred three time state corne corne bloometh blossome falleth ripeth anye euill blast eare fadeth destroyed looseth fruit corne also much raine gréeueth lost colde humour else turneth vnkindly hearbs superfluitie leaues also sodeine immoderate heate gréeueth closed clowde humour drawen inner part roote strong heat hot humour gleamie wormes bréede roote fretting gnawing wormes substance corne wasted also corne graines wormes bréed jeaues destroye graines corne eares rainye weather passing heate bée corrupt rotten also passing drinesse corne lacketh humour lost default nourishing féeding else greene flyes bréede therein called cantharides cantharides log fly yt variable coloured venimous operatiō also sting fret thrift corne sometime many long fly lesse bréed therein destroy euery deale also séede corne néedeth cleannesse purenesse plinius saith ther cap 17 séeds touched lallowe grease spilte lost also corne groweth néedeth busily husbandrie néedeth ye corne cleane wéeded cleansed superfluitie euill weed saith among best wheat sometime growe euill wéeds venimous carle rey commeth corruption mallice humour drawen might heate worketh sufficiently matter also said corrupt dewe cleaueth leaues commeth corruption corne maketh werred rustie among manner corne wheat beareth price mankinde nothing friendly nothing nourishing héer séeke littera séeke de messe segete additiōthe first best kinde wheate opinion columella redde wheat second spi • e wheate third called ye pound wheat sū mer wheat rawe wheat chewed mouth good laid biting mad dog wheat norishing séede man farie cap 66 far manner corne hath name sometime broken morter men vse craft mill commeth farrago isidore sayth hearbe barly kind yet gréene fruit therof breaketh ripping additiō zea far spelt two sortes one hath commonly two cornes séede ioyned togethers whereof graine owne skinne chaffe couering single hath one graine spelt nature lyke wheat somewhat colder drawing néere nature barly somewhat dryeng bread thereof much inferiour made wheate nourisheth lesse graine none vsed england almaine germanie fol 131 turner farina chap 67 meale called farina matter bread hath name farina far far corne broken betwéene mill stone commeth meale else name commeth farciendo filling whē meale made bread filleth ye womb else meale properly called farina corne well ground betwéene mill stone flowre bran meddeled departed stowre meale boulted departed bran called simila similago also hath another name called pollen pollis thereof commeth haec polenta hoc pulmentum commeth pultes isidore sayth libr 20 cap 7 men meane polenta manner potage made best pured stowrethickned milke called pap young child hath name pollenta polline delicate meale flyeth mill stone ye mill called amolum another name throwne ye mill stone lightnesse therof stowre called simila smal without greatnesse weight polenta hath signification said glosa super iosue 5frumetie shall eate polenta yeare haec polenta corne sod pilled hulled shalled froting handes though pilled hulled shalled beating stamping morier called polenta pilenta pilled shalled morter name euer hath meale good meate medicine thereof bread made meddeling water baking fire sometime thereof meate made seruaunts called cibarius full delicate meate sometime sowre bread medled sowre dough bake vnder ash baked turned wend fire called focacius cake baked duen called clibanarius manner wise many baking crafte bread made meale isidore sayth li 20 manner bread comforteth nourisheth pleaseth man heart restoreth lost giueth vertue strength trauaile passing fresh bread cleane made wheat friend accor • ine kinde constantine sayeth dietis meale ground mill sisted siue medled hot water sowre dough haue ye better sauour knead mould shape loues baked afterwarde last many trauailes man lyfe fedde susteined therewith also meale good medicine medled •• e manner thing according meale meddeled hony healeth cleanseth face scab whelltes dioscorides sayeth also meale wheate rie sodde wine grease laid breast teat healeth softneth hardnesse commeth tunning milke saith ripeth postumes gathering euill humour slaketh sinewes ouercome spilt crampe shranke sayth additiōmany wayes serueth vse flowre wafer eggpies flawnes custard summerset shiere whitpot kentish pudding pancake friters dainfye fartes portingale suger plate biskets comfit carawes last euilly bestowed making starch vlase ruffes fondling flie withall many wayes besides serueth vse flowre néedefull profitable fermento cap 68 sowre dough called fermentum maketh paast feruent maketh also arise isidore sayth libro 20 cap 1 sowre dough compounded diuerse vertues hath substaunce vertue lyke therefore hath vertue heaue paast bread change amende sauour thereof turne lykenesse matter meddeled hath vertue drawe soone euill humour bodie dioscorides sayth ripe open postumes botch meddeled salt openeth pore body subtilty dissolueth tempereth humour called fermentum latine zima gréek paast made onely meale water called asima sima without sowre dough sima sowre dough reareth paast bread meddeled therewith chaungeth sauour thirleth distributeth partes thereof sayde super epistolam 1 cor 5 additiōwith gran also called curgings dragges ale made famous potage deuenshéere called drouson fumo terre cap 69 fvmus tarre hearbe hot dry first degree hath name springeth groweth earth great quantitie smoak doth fumositie commeth earth sayd placeari gréene hearbe better vertue dry hearb horrible sauour heauy smel neuerthelesse vertue cleanseth purgeth melancholia sleme cholera helpeth ye scab dropsie commeth colde cause helpeth haue podagre stopping liuer splene hearbe hath vice bréedeth swelling ventositie therfore ventositie thereof shall bée abated fenell bréede sretting gnawing platearius sayeth additiō capnos fumoria fumeterre two sortes common sort called fenistorye hot dry almost second degrée feniculo cap 70 fenel common hearb great vertue might hot drie seconde degrée hath vertue temper shed open carue cut subtill cause quality thereof said pla séede roote leaues thereof accorde medicine therof isidore speaketh lib 17 cap vlt sayth latines call fenell feniculum iuyce stalk roote thereof sharpeth sight said serpent tast thereof doth away age yeares ye gréeks cal hearbe maratrum isidore taketh certeine spéech plinius li 20 cap 14 serpent saith maketh fenell noble away age tast thereof restore sight maketh sharpe iuyce thereof sayth vnderstanding inwit arraied therwith dimnesse put iuyce thereof full good collirium made agaynst dimnesse eyen fenell double manner kinde wilde tame seede therof dronke wine helpeth biting serpent stinging scorpion iuyce thereof dropped eares slayeth wormes iuyce thereof comforteth strengthneth hardneth stomack abateth wambeling breketh stone multiplieth milke brest roote thereof pouder last lykewise man looseth fairnesse passing drawing toward age draweth death tourneth last pouder heye gréene springeth clotheth maketh faire downes medowes maketh men beast haue liking looke fruit sowre hard stoppeth constraineth neuertheles comforteth stomacke exciteth appetite specially eaten fasting eaten meat comforteth ye mouth stomacke thrusseth togethers showeth downward meat layeth maketh soft wombe fruit sowre compounded watry matter earthie quencheth sharpnesse cholera comforteth ye stomack dissolueth departeth thick humour colde sharpeth swéet humour giueth vertue ivsquiamus gréeke english called henbanehenbane canicularis latine hath name canicularis either side stalke thereof groweth crab head fa • eth pomegranards isidore saith li 17 mouthes thereof departed clouen haue diuers séedes lyke poppie séede hearbe called • • na mad vse thereof perillous eate dronke breedeth madnesse slow lykenesse sléepe therefore hearb called commonly mirilidium taketh awaye wit reason isidore sayth venemous hearbe hath blacke séede red white • linius saith dioscorides blacke worst venemous red lesse euill white least euill therefore vse thereof accordeth medicine hath vertue constraine binde also breed sléepe haue blacke seede haue blacke leaues rough hard purple floures hard leaues thicke sad haue reddest seed haue white floures also butter floures leaues softer haue white seed haue white floures fat leaues ful iuyce hearb cold ye third degrée dry second degree therfore abateth swelling bindeth wombe stauncheth bloud healeth tooth ache commeth heat abateth hot reume huc v que diosc plinius aristotle libro vegitabilium speaketh henbane seede sayeth seede henbane poyson slayeth among parthian eaten ierusalem good ground euill groweth mallice thereof venime abateth increaseth magister historia sup exodum saith crowne chiefe bishop sloode floure lyke hearbe greek call iusquiam • vnder floure vtter side crowne miter circle gold forhead noll circle distinguished treble order vpon circle stoode golden flower like plantayne temple temple hearbes priuiledged lykenesse worthy set tokening figure crowne myter chiefe priest additiō hiosciamus blacke yeolowe white blacke hurtfull ¶of castanea cap 88 castanea casteyne trée great trée high called castenea among gréekes isidore saith fruite thereof double lykenesse ginetall closed huske taken shale manner gelding therefore trées called castanie gréeke haue name castrando gelding trée feldeforth olde root springeth yoūg sprigges grovve tree beare fruite springeth woode place isidore saith trée full profitable stocke thereof good building fuell rinde leaues medicine though fruite ye trée hid vile rinde rough harde yet taken thereof found swéete namely sod rosted isaac dietis saith fruit hot middle first degrée drye second swéete heate sourish drinesse casteynes bréede swelling men eate many thereof breedeth also head ach fumositie closed therein purge cleanse fruite must rosted sod water earthy matter may wasted fire fruite made lesse harde lesse fast el maye tempered softnesse moystnesse fresh water nourisheth well bréedeth good humour tempreth drinesse body breast namely eaten sugar acata secundum alium librum cholaricke fleumaticke men shal eaten hony good medicine restraineth wambling spewing comforteth gut called ieiuniū also casteyne tempered lyttle honnie healeth best biting mad dogge man biting also fruite made plaister barley meale vineger healeth effectuallye swellyng breast teares also rindes leaues burnt made powder tempered vinegar layed young man head playster wise maketh haire increase kéepeth haire fallyng huc vsque isaac dictis additiōamongst kinde wilde fruites chesnut best méetest eaten nourish reasonable well yet hard digestion well rost dipped butter nourish best ¶of lauro chap 89 laurell trée called laurus trée victoryand worthy praised many maner wise singular excellencie grace vertue sometime conquerours crowned garland laurel trée victorie gréekes call trée daphnis singular property trée haue set booke litera séeke thou shalt finde lentisco chap 90 lentiscus lowe medicinall tréemastike called scinus among gréeks hebrewes another name glose saieth super dan 13 iuyce leaues thereof healeth lyps chinnes whelkes sayde called lentiscus pricke thereof blunt softe folding vse call thing softe plyant lentus isidore saith lib 17 fruit trée commeth oyle rinde commeth resina called masticke best bréedeth iland chio isidore saith lib 16 dioscorides platea plinius meane leaues trée full hot drye trée haue vertue binde fasten comfort helpeth therefore spewing manner running bloud humour ••• thereof say mistix hath lyke vertues gumme hath name mist • gand • wing chewing made tough cleansing harde waxe among ye feeth chewed cleanseth purgeth gum rotted humour fasteneth wagging rocking téeth maketh white cleane strengtheneth comforteth rootes thereof cleanseth amendeth euill breath masticke gathered wise •• ende springing time rindes trée tenultus cut flie ground made cleane cloathes spred ther least lycour falleth shuld fall ground lycor faire cléere cleane best dim medled earth nought worth mastike cleanseth purgeth brain causeth spit much comforted vertue digestion destroyeth ventositie windes sowdreth ioyneth together wonderfull manner broken thing precious stone thing broken molten hot tile flate plinius dioscor meane lenti • ca trée wt many prick • déepe roote grounde clouen diuided many part fruite thereof lyke myrtus greynes lesse reared within ripe within manner rough wooll iuyce wooll stauntheth running dropping woman additiōof masticke trée commeth gumme masticke cleere small greynes quantitie wheat cornes ¶of lilio chap 91 lily hearbe white flower • though leaues floure white yet within shineth likenesse golde dioscorides plat speake lily say hot moyst lily wilde beareth purple floure yeolowe beareth white • pure mightie working vertue lily ripeth dotches sore therefore helpeth pastumes botch bée stamped auxungia grece also vertue thereof tempereth fasteneth matter therefore helpeth hardnesse splene place ye splene side splene annoynted iuyce lilyes well meddeled incorporate olde oyle vertue thereof cleanseth purgeth ponder thereof medled rose face washed therewith vertue thereof easeth sore therefore leaues sod layd sore burnt healeth sore roote therof doth brused oyle layd therto vertue thereof tempreth softeneth hard matter therefore bringeth menstruall purga •• vertue thereof abateth swellyng helpeth postumes come swellyng ventositie roote thereof stamped oyle ofte said thereto huc vsque dioscorides plin saith lily roote maketh floure therof worthie noble many manner wise roote thereof dronke wine heateth biting serpent helpeth ye mallice venime frog roote sod wine medled oyle helpeth podagre knot féete maketh hayre growe place sealded burnt also roote sod wine medled honie helpeth veynes cut leaues thereof sod wine healeth sore wound séede thereof brayed layd holy fire floures leaues heale sore hotches huc v que plin li 20 ca 19 item cod lib cap 5 lily next rose worthines noblenes certayne gathering oyntment thereof made noble oyntment oyle called oleum liliorum oleum rosaceum ofte made rose root therof springeth stalke thrée cubit long top stalke hangeth floure downward narrow stalk wexeth bredth wider wider shapen bell floure hath small threddes containe séede middle standeth chiues saffro • nothing gracious lily fairnes cosent swéetnesse smell effect working vertue coulour thereof treble white redde purple huc vsque plinius libro • 0 capitulo 5 roofe lilye hath manye cloues roote garlike arist sayth lib vegitab euery cloue vertue feminall springeth plant set alone séeke héereof de allio litera héereto arist saith stalke lily hath many knot stalke bended layd downe couered earth roote grounde ere séed bread vnclose within dayes thou shalt finde euerye knot small cloue sprong roote wonder also said lily floures first gréene afterward white stalke cut roote kinde humor stalke closed pith kind heate pith tourneth ouer part stalke maketh digestion matter floure floure spreadeth white humour full digested therefore sayd uersifiers likened lily wan wit busie last thing euer shall last sayd lily hath vertue seminall séed roote lily diuers varieth léekes garlik haue seminal vertue diuers place héereof loke chapter garlike onion litera c also lily stalk floures new cut put clodde claye keepeth floures fresh long time lilye flower smelleth full swéete white whole broken stinketh full sowle broken froted handes woman nourish féede child men heard ye withstandeth mouing venus thereof double kinde wilde tame wilde call seralia backe thereof hath sharpe prickes séeth sawe lyke isid speaketh seuentéenth booke last chapter isaac dietis speketh hearb saith hearbe wild lettuce lyke shape tame hath longer braunches smaller sharper lesse gréene scarsitie moysture therefore much bitter drier therefore many men meane exciteth menstruall bloud putteth rawe humoures dioscorides saith tame lettuce cold moyst temperate passeth measure neither qualytie therefore vse thereof accordeth meate medicine subtill substance namely fresh therfore soone digested abateth gnawing burning commeth cholera rubea cooleth heate boyling bloud exciteth sleepe healeth head ach commeth cholaricke humour sumositie multiplyeth milke woman semen men reason good bloud bréedeth perfect quantitie qualitie olde hard moysture thereof wihtdraweth hearbe bitter vse thereof bréedeth bloud worst appaireth sight maketh fayle slayeth feelyng stiffeleth naturall féeling sowrenesse thereof lettuce grieuous get childrē runneth consealeth seminall matter namely séede thereof ofte taken meate drinke huc v que isa dietis lib 20 cap 8 plinius speaketh lettuce sayeth manner kinde lettuce groweth selfe without tillyng manner lettuce called caprina throwen sea flayeth fish nigh thereabout milke thereof vineger water wine healeth dropsie hearbe leaues stamped sprong salt healeth sinewes forecut another manner lettuce groweth field leaues therof stamped healeth botch laid medle among ye gréekes maner lettuce called isopum esoperum third manner lettuce groweth woodes called stancio leaues thereof grounde meale floure healeth wound stauncheth bloud healeth rotted wound roote leaues abateth euill called holy life another manner lettuce round leaues shorte called heracia among many men hawkes scrape hearbe take iuyce thereof touche heale theyr eyen therewith doe away dimnesse blindnesse olde iuyce healeth euills eyen namelye woman milke medled therewith healeth biting serpent stinging scorpion iuyce thereof dronk wine leaues stamped layed wounde plaister wise swageth healeth manner swellyng also séede manner lettuce wilde tame chasteth sléepe dreames lecherie suffereth body polluted neither desiled oft taken meate ofte vse thereof much thereof eaten grieueth ye cléernesse eyen plinius thereto giueth many praisings chapter shall suffice time ¶of lappa chap 93 lappa cle • e hearbe broad leaues thicke ground hath top stalke knot crooked prickes oft cleaueth man clothes lib 17 isid speaketh héereof saith hearb called lappa hath great leaues disposed ground called philantropos among gréekes rough cleaueth man clothes groweth olde wall called philantropos louing mankinde cleaueth man clothes maner affection loue séemeth thereof double kinde sharp round disposed lykenesse horse foote therefore many men call vngula cabalina horse hoofe either hath leaues heauie mightie sauour smell meaneth yt manner kind hearbs wort wt broade leaues clete leaues lappates soft fat plaine wonderfully wralled lapped cleauing togethers short caulstock knotty without full pith within hearb accordeth meate medicine thereof good meate made may kept long time busily compounded sod vineger smapie séed hony meat commonly called compositum hath singular vertue withstand dronkennesse plinius saith lib 10 20 eaten meat kapeth dronkennesse taken meate dronkennesse maketh passe away doctrine teaching rasis meaneth yt nothing better broken bone good ye stomack sinewes therefore commandeth biddeth hearb giuen haue quaking pa • ste spit bloud child bréedeth plenty milke iuyce therof helpeth venim smiting serpent namely séed thereof helpeth biting hound isid saith lib 17 legumine cap 65 legumina codware yt serueth potage hath name legumina legendo choosing chose men old time chose best codware made meat therof graines deale greater thicker graines wheale baily properly called legumina gendered hull wheat code closed therin fareth pesen fetch bean legumina codware diuers quantitie colour figure shape sauour among codware lupine beanes greatest pesen fetch meane fille vaches smallest quantity diuerse coulour white blacke red meddeled diuers coulours shape bée diuers round bée euenlong thrée cornered plaine sauour differ bée sowre hard made soft good eating séething bée bitter themselues lupine bée made swéet sauoury good watring codware shall gathered begin ripe fall soone coddes well séene shed • areth lupine plinius sayth libro 18 codware substance thicke fast colde drye harde defie hard séething fast hard substaunce may well sod pitte water seeth codware well needeth running water well streame oft codware boystōus meat made accordeth strong men complection kinde codware selfe hard digest nourisheth much comforteth digested bréedeth swelling ventositie ventositie abated thereof medling thing destroy ventositie comin anete dioscorides saith affirmeth additiō codware bréedeth swelling vsed kéepe good dyet beanes pea sortes doe breede winde c ¶of lente cap 96 lens lentis manner codware seruisable potage isido saith lib 17 hath name moyst softe namely grasse lens lentis commeth lencicula diminutiue thereof writ c difference lens lendis nit little head worme writ genitiue case except nomnatiue case therof one speaketh manner lens lendis capiti lens lentis conuenit • say lens lendis nit head lens lentis titl accordeth mouth till colde drye compowned contrary isaac saith one vertue thereof rinde another pith meale hath rinde manner sharpnesse lareth wombe pith meale sowrish comforteth stomacke constraineth bindeth gendreth thicke melancholike bloud filleth brain thicke smoke therfore cause horrible dreadfull dreames grieueth stomacke ventositie swelling stoppeth passage veynes bodye dryeth substaunce sinewes skinnes braine grieuous skin eyen distempereth moysture thereof fordrieth sayeth greueth whole eyen much grieueth sore eyen fordrieth oft vse breedeth body wicked euils passion namely eaten skin hulles bodye bée drye complection somtime helpeth hot moyst helpeth haue dropsie bée eaten without skin gendreth much swelling stretching gut skin till great fresh easie seething best meate medicine malice till tempered skinne put away pith sod fresh water oyle put thereto pepper comin thing huc vsq isaac dietis plin saith lib 17 cap 12 till loneth leane land fat dry wether aire codware loueth water blossome drinesse blooming additiō lentills common hard digestion causeth dreadfull dreames bréedeth canker leprosie madnesse yet summer flaxe groweth euen stalk yeolow floures blew commeth hoppes therein seede hoppe beginneth flaxe drawen vp gathered whole lyned afterward made knot lyttle bundells laid water lyeth ther long time taken water layed abroad till dryed turned woond sunne bound pretie nitches bundle afterward knocked beaten braied carfled rudded gnodded ribbed heckled last sponne thred sod bleaked bucked ofte layed drieng wetted washed sprinkled water vntill white diuers working crauayle manye manner flex fairest groweth aegypt thereof bislus made right faire white snowe plin saith li 19 ca 12 flaxe strong thereof commeth winning thereof kinde vestment made priest flaxe néedfull diuers v thereof made clothing weare sayles sayle net fish hunt thred sew rope binde string shoote bondes binde line meate beareth swéete apple hot moyst beareth sower apple colde drye may kept longer swéete accordeth medicine trée medicinall fruite thereof accordeth lyttle meat isid meaneth lib 17 sayeth phisitions denie body shuld nourished meate pomegranards suppose accordeth medicine feeding body trée namelye fruite thereof hath vertue constraine binde comfort fasten harden dry thin humour fléeting staunche cholaricke spewing staunch bloud isaac teacheth openly dioscor plat also taken couenable manner due order helpeth passion body within without ye swéet breedeth ventositie swelling doe lesse quench thirst diseased feauers therefore agrée worse haue agoe sower doe ye ioyce sower drinke made yt called exizacra abateth heate feuers defieth chaungeth matter feuers exciteth appetite restoreth wonderfully repaireth comforteth kinde fayleth reason great heat helpeth chasing lyner cardiacle passion failing hart flower fruite rinde thereof slaieth old wormes wombe made powder dronke effectually comforteth purgeth téeth gumbes helpeth many euills dioscorides isaac meane pomegranards helpe aforesaid thing effectually though yeolow discoloured sowrish wearish drye without rinde yet comfortatiue restoreth superfluitie running dropping proper kinde therof helpeth vertue retentiue hold body helpeth agaynst reume falleth spirituall member sod raine water breast washed therwith stancheth spewing ae braunch thereof sod vineger laied stomacke pouder trée healeth wound easely softe plin sayth mirtus white blacke either binding blacke ye therefore profitably taken bléeding giuen spet bloud pisse bloud ¶of myrra cap 102 mirra trée arabia fiue cubites high lyke thorne called achantum dropping therof gréene great smell bitter hath therefore name myrra isidore sayeth libro 16 dropping commeth thereof selfe best dropping commeth chin slit bée made therein accounted lesse worth mirhre precious gumme arabian make fire shredding thereof thereof full grieuous smoake withstood smell storaye el smoake men take vncurable sicknesse euills best mirra pure gathered among troglodites arabia isi saith plinius li 12 cap 17 saide mirra tree fiue cubites high groweth woodes arabia leaues thereof bée lyke leaues oliue bee cripse haue prickes like boughes iuniperus boughes thereof carued cut slit two time droppeth slit dropping called stacten best manner mirra called mirra electa mirre chosen mirra seuen manner kindes saith cap 17 oncées called trogoditica wel chosen second called gelbanitica third called diantrides fourth colaticia fift pracena called also salbana thin mirres sixt called duratim odonferam white feined gum clod lentiseus seuenth called indica worst manner mirres feined huc v que plinius dioscorid saith mirra dropping trée hardened bough heat sun best citrine red within deale bright héereof small great called trogoditica hath name ilande groweth trogoditica hot dry hath vertue comfort gathering increasing partes together vertue good sauour smell dissolueth departeth consumeth wasteth euenly qualityes thereof dead body kept safe sounde balmed confection mirre mirra kept vertue nigh hundred yéeres helpeth cause fleumatike inordinate running dropping comforteth digestion purgeth gleamye humour namelye spirituall member amendeth stinch smell mouth healeth dryeth euills gummes healeth destroyeth wasteth whelk lip comforteth braine comforteth strongly strengtheneth mother fordrieth wasteth superfluitie thereof helpeth conception slayeth wormes eares fretteth dead flesh bréedeth saueth quicke flesh best additiō mirrha also name thereof spirit féeling restored comforted slaieth bitternesse louse wormes letteth breeding thereof abateth stinking sweat kéepeth saueth bodyes whole sounde rot mandragora cap 104 mandragora hath name beareth apple great sauour greatnesse apple macian called malum terre among latines poet call antropomoros root therof deale shapen man counterfeited rinde therof medled wt wine giuen drinke yt shall cut body shuld sléepe feele ye sore cutting héereof two manner kindes one female lyke leaues letuse beareth apple male hath leaues lyke béete isidore sayeth libro 17 diosco saith mandragora sléeping hearbe leaues thereof spread grounde hath two rootes thrée cleauing togethers blacke without white within thick skinne male hath white leaues thinne roote like apple grow ye leaues gall grow oken leaues yeolow swéet smell manner heauinesse fresh fauour accord therefore meat onely medicine rindes thereof sod wine cause sléepe abateth maner sorenesse time man feeleth vnneth though bée cut yet mandragora must warily vsed flayeth men take much therof sayth plat said cooleth deale slayeth maketh sleepe stronglye therefore iuyce thereof woman milke laide temple maketh sléepe yea though hot ague hearbe colde substance sayd fruit thereof quencheth euill called holy fire abateth réese cholera fluxe wombe huc vsque plat sayde kinde shape man woman roote thereof rather feined churles witch sayd maketh woman conceiue seemeth saint austen sayth nay super gen 2 cap 19 sayth rachel desired madragora looked bookes philosopher treate vertues hearbes found thing bookes time sauing authoritie saint austen many author meane mandragora hath vertue const dioscorides plinius plat meane mandragora taken due manner disposeth mother conceiuing mother matrix conception let much heat drinesse mandragora disposeth hot woman moist conception conceiue mandragora colde dry said platearius disposition letteth woman kindly colde dry disposition mandragora hath many vertues smiteth destroieth swelling bodye dioscorides saith withstandeth venimous biting stancheth droppigns running aboue beneath set sayd plinius booke libro 35 capit 16 sayde mandragora bée two kindes c followeth manner digge mandragora busie beware contrary windes digge make thrée circle swoord abide digging vntill sunne going downe suppose haue hearbe chiefe vertues nyre thereof gathered dried sunne apple therof dried shadow smel apple heuy bréedeth sléep smell saith additiō mandrake two sort blacke whitish yeolow cause sléepe bée inwardly receiued verye daungerous another kinde called mala insana raging apple apple loue read dodo fol 439 milio cap 105 milium mile hearbe long stalk knottie reed seede thereof full small colde dry isaac saith dietis witnesseth lightnesse hollownesse thereof absence gleaminesse vnctdositie nourisheth little comforteth stomacke drynesse thereof bindeth wombe dioscorides sayeth diuritike assate swageth ach helly gendereth good bloud •• leth dryeth stomacke said dietis menta chap 106 menta hearbe good smell hot drye comforteth stomacke thereof double kind wilde tame one groweth garden woodes mountaines heateth first hearbe called colocasia gréeke nepta calamentum latine isidore sayth libro 17 cap penul hearbe full medicinable manner mintes grow moore medes mightie vertue heate haue heauie smell sauour mint garden hearbe multiplyeth selfe springeth soone ground stalke therof bended downe ground heeled earth turneth roote bringeth forth anon new mint mint gardeines full vertuous gréene drye dissolueth tempereth wasteth proper qualyties thereof comforteth exciteth appetite odour good smell sharpnesse therof sod vinegar away stinch mouth cleanseth purgeth corrupt rotted gum abateth vineger perbraking casting commeth féeblenesse vertue retentiue helpeth sauour smell sownding féeblenesse spirites comforteth cleanseth superfluitie mother abateth sodde wine ach gut reines sod wine oyle laid cureth healeth hardnesse breast teates come running crudding milke iuyce thereof withstandeth venim slayeth dronken wormes wombe care also mint sodde wine oyle dissolueth healeth colde postumes healeth cough huc vsque dioscorides pla also isaac sayth libro 2 dietes taketh away abhomination wambling abateth yoring cleanseth smootheth tongue froted therewith exciteth venus additiōthere sixe kindes mintes curd mint crispe mint baliac spere 108 nut trée called nux called nut also hath name nux dropping leaues thereof gréeueth noieth tree nigh théreto many latines call trée iouelans another name trée somtime hallowed iupiter fruit thereof hath greate vertue put among frogge stooles venumous meates spilleth destroieth quencheth al venim therein isidore sayeth libro 17 fruit thereof hath harde rinde without bitter swéete kernell within manner apple closed hard skinne rind shale called nut pince castanie auellane saith nut trée high long large bough knot broad leaues sinewy euen long sharp end euill smell sauour shadow therof pissing contrarie feauers come shiuering colde bée dronke vineger sayth also furthermore dieth cleanseth haire letteth falling thereof hath many vertues might fruit thereof accordeth meate medicine men hotte complection eate thereof many oft bréedeth head ach maketh turne giddy bée couenable nourishing eate temperatly temperate complection defied well inough vertue thereof knowne effect medicine called pampinus leafe branch defended succoured colde heate wrong frost snow hard weather fall place leaues plucked away sunne come fruite ripe spéedely doe away shadowe yt letteth ye riping saith
