propago propaginis young braunch vine springeth slip vine new set ye ground isidore saith highest braunches vine called flagellum bee wagging blastes winde set pight ground make vine spread multiplye newe vine thereof springeth new plantes branch uines braunches called propagines propaginate vnderstand s plant vine put new branch ground new vine may spring thereof make uineyard spred wide large propagate say spred spring isidore saith also uine branch bent downe grippe earth hid earth conceiueth vertue generation beareth new braunches vertue generation leaf aboue braunches breaketh vertue hence turneth outwarde braunches vertue bene downe ground medled earth tourneth rootes therof springeth new braunches draweth nourishing séeding rootes turneth rootes la • e • feedeth continually suche tree shred pared spring spred length bredth popler trée thrée sort one white blacke third called aspe oyntment made bud good inflamations brusings squattes falles swelling ¶of pino chap 121 pine apple trée called pinus picea hath name pinus sharpnesse leaues old time men called pinus sharpe trée called picea thereof sweateth woseth pitch isidore sayeth libro 17 ilandes germania ye pine apple trée commeth dropping wosing made harde coldnesse heate tourneth precious stone called electrum isidore sayeth electrum hath another name called succus iuyce tree named called pinus also trée good thing kept continued therevnder figge tree gréeueth noyeth thing therevnder isidore sayeth pine trée high trée euen light many small hoales right strong therein many knot pine apple trée right strong oftentimes thereof mastes made ship right good timber edifieng buylding trée taketh right soone fire burneth commeth nigh fire plenteous fatnesse therin thereof commeth pitche rinde trée hard rough humour within fat gleymie humour drawen summer heate sunne chaungeth tourneth rosin rosin first white right blacke sodde pitch made thereof sauoureth full well doth smoake thereof also great séething sauour thereof abateth trée beareth many leaues small sharpe trée gréene colour winter also summer though trée fattest yet groweth mountaines right drye place also stony though trée great springing yet pared shred towarde grounde springeth spreadeth vpward toward heauen groweth slowly gleimie humuor thicke soone deffed digested trée spoyled ye rind dry better betwéene rinde trée wormes bréede trée beginneth drie wormes fret gnaw trée therfore saue trée kéepe accounted chiefe medicine takeoff rinde wormes bréed corrupt humo •• rinde betwéene tree rinde also lib 16 plinius saith ye pine tree alloren trée healed earth • orye vnder ground dure last long time pipe conduiles made pine trée laid deepe vnder earth dure many yeares rotteth corrupteth soone lye aboue earth moyst place altogether hid vnder grounde running water runneth thereon wexeth hard dureth house long time rotteth soone neither worme eaten corrupt dropping raine déepe vnder earth cureth abideth full long time safe sound without corruption contrarye ver rotteth anone vnder earth dureth best within house kept drye plin saith li 21 ca 10 additiōof pine trées ther fiue kind appeareth dudoneus herball beareth kinde many apple beast back saith isa diet saith peares double maner kind wilde tame either kinde boughes braunches sower stopping biting fruite full diuers wilde peares sower earthy colde drye tame vnsauourie hard tast generally vndigest accordeth therefore meate onely medicine bindeth stoppeth strōgly fluxe wombe stauncheth cholaricke spewing sad running water laid stomack tame peares gréne substaunce thereof medled watry swéetnesse therefore according meate medicine better according meate medicine meate meate laxe beare downe meate place digestion comforteth sinewes mouth ye stomacke many peares eaten fasting bréedeth wormes wombe colliea • • sio incurable swéete peares temperate cō plection lesse cold accordeth therefore better colde drye peares haue propertie sod toad stooles ¶of quercu ca 134 oke called quercus nowne declined quercus cu cui trée beareth mast fast trée sad dureth long time hard rinde little pithe within none bréedeth leaues manner thing sower vsanery phisitions call galla beareth fruit called akorne therewith swine bore country fatted hath strong roote crooked full deepe ground cleueth full fast therto rinde fruite twig therof sowrish cold drye good medicine hath name quercus seeking asking therein god nation gaue aunsweres isid saith li 17 el theron men old time sought akornes eate poet sayth mortales primo ructabanti guttura glans old time trée hallowed iupiter ouidius sayth men desired akornes broad tree iupiter okes grow mountaynes woodes namely land basan groweth okes beareth akornes passe trées hardnes strength ierome saith sup amos ca 2 quercus ilex one looke book litera fruite quercus called akorne groweth among leaues blossome springeth hande akornes long euenlong full plaine smooth deale bright mirrour cléere nayle sayd diet akorns colde drye therefore hard defie vnobedient digestion hardeneth wombe commeth slowly downe stomacke bréedeth head ache thick fumositie passeth therof stomacke braine gréene beginning browne red ripe grow shell shaped round plain smooth within kernell full sad hath little skin departeth betweene kernell shale shale kernell huske full sower dry well sauoured wellripe rosted fire sod fresh water better sauour taketh better sauour heate swéetnes ye water akornes helpeth venime stop way pore venime may passe soone heart dryeth rotted humour stauncheth stinteth menstruall fluxe running multitude floures smell coulour also vertue leaues wilde rose broad whitish medled little rednesse smelleth wel tame rose vertuous medicine tame rose hath manye leaues sette nigh together red white wonderfull good smell sowrish sauour somdeale biting great vertue medicine brused broken vertuouser better smellyng springeth thorne harde rough neuerthelesse rose followeth kinde thorne araieth hir thorne faire colour good smell rose beginneth spring closed knop greynes knop greene swelleth springeth harde leaues sharpe middle thereof springeth soft leaues compasse wexe red lyttle lyttle full rado dis shane shauen groweth root beginning hearbe tree soft substance poores rough crooked soft fat substaunce take better incorporation moisture hath many pore take sooner humour send féeding nourishing leaues branch rough great drawing nourishing feeding hath office body hearbs trées mouth hath body beast cleaueth earth roughnesse draweth selfe yt according humour sendeth pore veines nourish plant crooked cleane faster earth root diuers shape disposition diuers working heat yt worketh substantiall matter ye root matter somtime thin somtime thick somtime mene al saith cōmento super li de plantis matter watry thin strong heat roote euenlong sharpe shape ye moisture nourishing bée thicke earthie root hard drye humour strongly fastned runne vertue might heate matter bée meane heate strongthen heat draweth like swift part equall moouing partes roote round figure shape heat feeble matter gleamie heate may send vp much matter make spread reare lyghtest partes thereof heauyest partes breaketh hether thether theyr owne heauynesse weight therein abideth euen shape knot roughnesse roote gendered humour earth working heate heate heauen entereth commeth therein vertue therof agréeable féeding nourishing drawen incorporate thereto also place disposition ground root taketh disposition complection groweth swéet ground meanly drye bée nourished raine water better nourished soft land marreys standing rotten water whereof draw nourishing reason malignitye corruption water worse least wholsome meate medicine isaac saith root hid vnder ground sight sheweth vertue thereof working flowres fruit bough roote lyeth hid vnder ground liueth profiteth better better fayleth drawen grounde dryeth fordryeth tree hearbe root part counted lesse price neuerthelesse root mother well hearbe trée either nourisher néedfull susteiner déepe roote put grounde steadfast foundation hearbs trées though root soft substance therof yet vertue subtiltie kinde heat pearceth betwéene hard stone commeth innermost part therof winter time kinde heate slieth colde aire gathereth selfe innermost root multiplyed temperatnesse nourishing selfe winter time root conceiueth taketh water humour drawen sendeth forth nourish bréede braunches flowres springing time ye spring time tree hearbs dry dead winter time humoure commeth vp ouer partes quicken springing time also qualitie good euill root commeth vp bough twig oft shewed fruit flower vertue vice ye root oft sowrenesse bitternesse humour roote defied benefice aire heate heauen purifieth matter oft falleth bitter roote commeth swéete fruite flower fareth roote vine nut trée oliue huc vsque isaac dietis vniuersalibus also aristotle saith trées stay beare fruites wont remedied roote roote slit stone put slit thicke humour corrupt passeth séething cleane humour pure new aire drawen commeth root trées renued healed also isaac galen saye muscus atheniense sayd hearb root much nourishing hath séed nourishing fareth pasnepis rapis colevvortes carreis againward séed hearb nourisheth ye roote nourisheth certaine hearbe approprieth name root hot dry like raphane vertue hath vertue temper depart dissolue consume wast open poores helpeth scauers come colde openeth stopping splene tempereth hardnesse thereof succoureth dropsie hath harde sauour sowre accordeth medicine meate raye againeward accordeth meate medicine hot moist nourisheth hearbs root isaac sayth dietis maketh soft flesh sweete ventositie bolning thereof therfore nourisheth better well sodde hard defie bee rawe euill sod stoppeth pore ye veine also good way medicine ye iuyce good podagre feete goutie place bée aswaged sorenesse ache séede rape also ye séede raphane oile made náedfull manye v namelye lamp yet lawful put oyle lamp candlestick house god sayth glose super exodo 27 sayd distinction bidden offer oyle raphon myrtum mirtinum pure oile oliue tree lawfull offer oile lawfull light fire came downe heauen c rampno cap 138 smal fuize anonisthe cambmoke called rampnus right hard trée knot bough braunches prick hath small leaues full sharpe prickes side doth harme feete handes toucheth treadeth thereon hath soft leaues beginning springeth groweth sharp prickes master historie super iud 9 taketh witnesse iosephus sayth chambmoke hath singular vertue gendereth fire selfe leaues therof fall dry sayde full drye soft fatnesse therefore corne sowing time called manye men goddesse lady sowing seminarium beginning euerye thing vessell séede put sowe sementum profite winning commeth seede hugo sayth héereof bée vearses difference grecismo meane seminall humour beast called semen grain corne bée sowen fielde called sementis properly sementinum seminum well beginning thing plinius libro 8 24 cap sayeth séede good kepte one yeare two thrée little woorth kepte longer time grain lowest threshing floure best séed best séed heauyest best heauie white within qualytie land séede shall sowen thicke thinne soone late must sowen soone moyst lande least séede rosteth raine late drye lande raine come soone thereafter least séede lye long drye vanish bée lost lesse séede shall bée sowen fat land leane land fat land groweth full fast destroyed selfe one séede ouersetteth another last greate multiplication selfe séede sowen soone shall waxe thicker séede late sowen late séede shall thinne least dry thicknesse cunning sow euen lyke thicke hand shall accorde stepping passe away foorth right foote séede shall bée chaunged colde place hot neither againewarde nothing shall bée commanded contrary séede sowen leane land commeth thin strawe small eares somtime voide fat field one roote séed commeth cluster stalk haruest day night bee lyke long time contrarye séede time also springing time men shall sow full hoare frost sooth winter séede sowen hoare frost breaketh springeth seauenth day frost vneth springeth within 40 day huc vsque plinius ca 20 seede small graine rounde hath selfe vertue multiply saue kinde therof sowen swelleth humour earth closed within yt tempereth maketh subtill humour earth bringeth draweth temperatnesse ye grain graine waxeth soft great small skin séed cleaueth burgening springeth lyttle lyttle rootes pight downward ground rootes burgening séede draweth awaye selfe féeding nourishing openeth last priuelye earth thereof springeth stalkes twigges flower fruit séede though séede yt sowen right little yet therof commeth right great thing huge fooles account séede lost sowen neuerthelesse better wise kept sowing also séede vertue seminall kinde heat worketh therein humour nourishing féeding drawne thereto vertue heate féeding growing séed commeth stalk stalke commeth eare called spica hath name spiculo dart eile isidore sayeth libro 17 eares groweth many eiles sharpe dartes kinde maketh eyles corne eares succour armour sodeine réeses biting small bird wormes isidore sayth diuerse kindes séeds eare diuerse figure shape sometime eare broad fareth barlye sometime foure edged fareth wheate sometime round plinius sayeth aristotle also also eare toppe stalke compassed small skinnes bull therein séede nourished mother kept saued vntil ripe hull springing first graine bée closed cleaueth afterward graine swelleth wateth great namely wheat sayd super libro aristotelis de plantis generally beginning working rearing heate head corne eares areared vpward whē ripeth bēdeth somwhat downwarde heauynesse weight graines eares bee greene bée sometime sprong corrupte corrupt aire dewe taketh rust thereof ripeth better sprong couenable dewe raine haue dewe heat heauen moysture dew suffereth graines fall hull plinius sayth libr 17 constantine isaac albuma meane goodnesse land goodnesse eare knowen good fat ground groweth good eare great quantitie fruitfull graines dry lande leane againeward plinius sayth stipula cap 157 stubble called stipula hath name burning thing burnt corne ripe gathered stubble burnt field may eared isid saith li 17 else hath name hugo saith stipo beset compasse stipula properly strawe leaues hofen left fielde repers haue reped corne hook gathered home many men gather stubble apt many diuers v men thetch house therewith féedeth beast therewith stéed strawe sodder maketh fire therwith baketh bread therewith séeth meate plinius sayth libro 18 cap 30 looke palea littera p stubble little thing hollowe drye full soone sette fire tlowing winde meale cleane white soft accordeth many meates also medicine looke de fauna littera f de polenta littera p scopa chap 159 scopa tréeb • somes broomes hath name scopando spewing commeth scopis scopo pa vnderstand cleanse purge • therwith house swept cleansed isid sayth lib 17 many call tree birch hath light leaues •• peby name scopa • late writer make mention leaues therof bée full thin full light rindes gather humoure commeth thereof drinke steed wine drinke quencheth thirst bréedeth much swelling telleth nourisheth maketh men dronke also ye iuyce kept long vessell vnderdung chafed heate sun corrupteth rotteth turneth fatnesse made ointment séething fire many mē draw therof wer pitch though right blacke stinking yet néedfull many diuers v therefore wilde wood men desert vse seede thereof sticked therein hugo saith néedeth gyest beame long strong great namely middle lest bend crooked small middle dread bending crooking ofte néedeth vnderset post pillers thwarte ouer trée set wise double one hath red fruite greatnesse fetche hath pale fruite greatnesse beane fruite hath merry smell fat handling touching much rosin siria great trée matter thereof right soft durable wexe blacke meale doure right little bran nourisheth best wheate springeth immoderate vneasie weather time vnperfect also wheat diuers old new ye meane olde kept long time drye hard defye nourisheth little substaunciall moysture thereof soone fordried abateth heate aire new wheat kept little time superfluitie moysture gleimie earth moist gleimy fast hard defie bréedeth swelling ventositie hurling kurling wombe wheate meane betwéene new olde betwéene moyst drye temperate therefore better nourisheth accidentall moysture wasted heat ayre tempereth somewhat ye substaunciall moysture therefore wheate better nourisheth better well digested leeseth gleiminesse thicknesse earth isaac saith wheate hot temperate betwéene moyst dry bread therof hot heat fire baking kinde heate thereof strengthened accidentall heate fire also wheate hath propertie nourisheth better greines likenesse man complection saieth also wheate drinesse cleanseth wasteth therefore iuyce meale therof cleanseth pourgeth breast lunge doth tisanum made wheate tisanum made barly clenseth tisanum made barly helpeth cough bloudye flixe also wheate sodde oyle laide vpon hard postume dissolueth also wheate soo iuyce rue dissolueth softneth running kurding milke breast teafes balmed therewith also wheate tempered iuyce henbane layed sinewes letteth euill humour shal fall downward also grems wheate chewed helpeth biting wood hound draweth venime saith also wheat made oyle helpeth manie thing namely itching seads wet drye shingle welt froted rough cloath done vertue oyle shoulde better enter also bran non incisus men meane libanus 〈…〉 arabia like laureit tree leaues beareth fruite twice one yeare springing time harvest▪ gum droppeth thereof itselfe beginning summer better summer rinde slit compelled come droppeth haruest white pure first cleaueth boughes twigs▪ thus best white fast sounde euenlong gendring stone called therefore masculinum thus commeth haruest beginning winter rind slit windeth tree stalkes called capreoli haue name taketh compasseth tree holdeth order crookes vine helpe succour knot braunches vine helpe sustaine withstand winde stormes breake blast wether also called corith • ring bend haddeth thing nigh thereto boughes braunches vine slaked farre succormed shaken disperpled hurled blast winde come beare saue fruite without perill thing accordeth vine earth opened root made great hole roote maye take plentie moysture humour also sunne beame may better come thereto work therein also vine néede cut pared purged superfluitie waterie bough vaine also vine néed letting planting thereof commeth young vine called propagines first twig spring spred young vine vine néed deluing paring grounde shouell spade mattocke away superfluitie hearbes root vine may knot kerffe shall passe therefore shall slont euen ouerthwart rayne drop soone come fall away ofte comming drop long abiding vpon plaine kerffe top vine shuld grieved hurt small leane vine thereof matrimonye vine good tree medicinable branch fruit therof commeth licour better passeth iuyce trées vine cut thereof commeth dropping clene pure dropping good profitable put colliriis medicine eyen passing dropping substantiall humour vine cleansed purged roote therfore vine beareth afterward pure fruite swéete leaues vine broade plaine greene softe within deale rough without cloued ragged vtter side sharpe make great shadowe shadowe thereof summer time full pleasaunt loue rest vnder leaues full medicinable cleanse woundes heale full cleanly leaues sodde water abateth seuourous beate healeth doth away • learednesse eies succoureth venimous biting venimous trauell stauncheth wombe also ash thereof good foresaid thing ash thereof medled iuyce rew oile abateth end softneth doth away swelling splene plinius saith li 24 ca 1 saith vine leaues doth away headach swageth inflasions uine leaues barly meale healeth hetie goutes helpeth greatly yt haue bloudie flixe drinke iuyce thereof oile laid hairie place plaister wise doth awaye haire namely dropping cō meth bough ye vine rind ye vine doth awaye wartes dry vine leaues stauncheth bléeding wound closeth healeth woundes moreouer ash vine purgeth healeth soone fester abateth ach shrinking sinewes healeth oyle stinging scorpion biting hoūds ash rinde selfe restoreth multiplieth haire fallen vitis vinifera ripe grape hot moist first degrée raison drie grape hot dry saith galen wilde vine called labrusca chap 108 wilde vine called labrusca hath name groweth vtter side lande noune labrusca commeth labrum lippe brimme vttermost side land groweth isidore saith libro 14 labrusca wilde vine lyke vine beareth wine leaues fruit beareth small fruite none beare fruite harde sowre bitter oft vine beareth wine passeth kinde fourneth wilde uine filled neyther digged neyther shred neither pared againewarde oft labrusca turneth vine beareth wine good filling • ut shredding knitting plinius sayeth though labrusca bée good meate yet good sayth wise labrusca called ampeloesargia gréeke labrusca hath many leaues rinde full iuyce wine beareth somdeale red grape like sod iuyce grape woman purge skin face grape stamped iuyce leaues profitably laid euills sore ioynts lendes loynes grape stamped vineger healeth scab men also soure footed beast additiōthe fruite right vine second kinde called labrusca also tearmed paslula de corintho englysh currant wholesome fruit purgeth fleame comforteth heart ¶of vitulamine cap 179 vitulamen hath name vitis vine bastarde plant braunch barren without fruite ye springeth roote vine el vine knot braunches vnkind beare therefore fruite charge grieue vine letteth taryeth fruite draweth ye humor roote nourishing themselues drawen feeding nourishing fruite therfore must plucked rooted vp done away least let growing fruite vine growe long time therefore braunches called bastarde vitulamina passing kinde kind branch lib sap cap 4 letter rabanus olde men though austen lib de doctrina ••• ••• na meane better sayd adulterine plantagines bastarde planting sayd vnderstanding simple men letter good perfect vnderstanding men spu • ia vitulamina ¶of vinea cap 180 uineyard called vinea place vine set growe papias saith call vinetu place many vine set vineyard busely tilled kept purged cleansed superfluity ofte visiled ouerséene earth tiller keeper vine appaired neither destroyed beast closed wall hedge wayle set high place kéepe vineyard fruite destroyed lefte winter without kéeper wayter haruest time many come haunt vineyard winter vineyarde full pale wereth gréene bloometh springing time summer smelleth full swéete pleasant fruite haruest time smell vineyard bloometh contrary venemous thing therefore vineyard bloometh adder serpent flye load also may sustaine suffer noble sauor thereof vineyard gréene coleur merrie pleaseth sight lyking smell swéete smelling sadeth taste swéetnesse sauour pleasing touching handelyng softnesse smoothnesse leaues comforteth touching therewith loueth cleane ayre faire weather plinius sayth loueth cloudes mystes neither much raine loue hot lande drye meanly fat swéete landes fat moyst vine outrageth beareth manye great long leaues boughes braunches little fruit grauellye lande leane vine ouer drieth sayleth finde sufficient nourishing also bitter lande salte roote thereof corrupted malitious humour commeth entreth substaunce roote therfore vine loueth sweete lande temperate quality high mountaines standeth well sun best place vineyardes therein sweet humour strong heate vineyarde sunne sweete grape beareth first fruite gréene harde sowre afterward made swéete working sunne fore lurke hide themselues vnder uine leaues gnawe couetouslye fret grape vineyard namely kéepers warden neglygent retchlesse profiteth vnwise men doth cloase within vineyarde hound bee aduersaries fox fewe houndes closed wast destroye moe grape many fox destroy yt come eate therof theeuishly isidore saith therefore wise que videre kind hath giuen man high mouth vertue looke heaven therefore basilius sayeth man defiled lust liking flesh obeieng lechery wombe made pere vnwise vnreasonable beastes made like also meaneth aristotle also auicen sayth euery beast hath semen gendereth another beast lyke selfe therefore euerye beast may kéepe saue alwaye kinde selfe kind giueth member puteth semen another mēber wherin may receiued mother female taketh semen general kinde beastes male female male manner worker shaper female matter worke therefore euery female beast hath member called mother el somwhat el stéede mother wherin may receiue semen broode falleth diuersly diuers maner beastes otherwise beastes lay egges maner beast containeth perfect beastes within themselues auicen setteth ensample many following aristotle setteth beast bloud afore beast haue bloud saith alwayes noble huge great quantitie vertue except fewe beast water sea saith yt euery beast hauing noble bloud moueth foure instrument vnreasonable beastes foure féete el moueth stirreth two handes two féete fareth mankinde mooueth stirreth winges two féete fareth bird fowles feather diuers manye manner beast found hauing moe féete foure fareth fish called crab small shragges also haue moe winges thē twayn fareth butterflyes bées long flyes little bloud treasure kinde therfore sore lims worke effectually first maner many lims doe seconde manner beast sore lyms able worke effectuallye hinder haue heat part heate bloud heart néere thereto auicen toucheth ye generall property beast sayth manner beastes communeth accordeth member man horse flesh sinewes diuers many thing first qualitie manner setting mouing member simple member compouned fareth snaile hath shelles irchin hath prick man hath none horse hath tayle man hath none beastes also diuers quantitie many mouth opening eyen opening owles eye much opening eagle eyen lyttle also member diuers number tale beast two feete foure feete fóete foure fareth spider spider hath eyght fáete spider hath tenne féete also qualitie colour figure shape softnesse hardnesse oxe foote full harde man foote full softe also diuerslye set fareth teates mare elephant contrariwise right strong auicen saith diuers appetite haue great appetite desire serue venus féeble elephant turtle haue appetite serue venus manner kinde beast onely beast owne kinde continent chast hare fawnes also euery beast ye gendreth another beast hath eyen except mole yt hath eyen closed within web web giuen moale féeblenesse sight euery beast hath eares moueth eares except man euerye beast breatheth wayes knowen mouth el nose preuye wayes preuy hole poores bées flyes beast glide ground euerye foure footed beast hath bloud hath marrow namely man hath much marrow cō parison body needfull man many diuers workes dooings euery beast yt hath horn cloue footed horne without except one beast unicorne hath one horne forehead one hoofe foote horse additiōthe unicorne cloue footed horned many call serpent serastes héere speak beast haue horne kinde bone snayles haue certaine horne softe gleymie properly horne thing giuen snayles helpe succour snailes féeble sight grope séeke viatico constantine saieth haire white hound without blacke speck helpeth haue falling euill kéepeth falling haire hanged necke thing saith phythagoras lib romanorum saith ring made hoofe white asse hath blacke speckes hath falling euill beare weare ring ring kéepeth falling also saith gall bull anoynted vnder nauell laxeth softeneth wombe also saith teeth serpent ought taken head serpent lyue beareth wooll pleasing heart mild kinde isidore saith lib 12 cap 1aries dur est ouīum hebrue ail tel cald • eu dikerin arabie rabsa rabsali duke leader prince shéepe therefore kinde giueth great strength passing shéepe séemly ram duke defender shéepe strong mightie shéepe therefore isi saith ram called veruex hath name vires strength man male maister shéepe vertuous stronger isidore saith nowne veruex commeth vermis worme ramme hath worme head fretting worme itching ramme excited pusheth full strongly smiteth full harde méeteth therefore ram called aries also hath name are gréek vnderstanding vertue flockes male called arietes vertuous mightie get gender lambes passe shéepe greatnes body might strength vertue also name aries commeth aris altar isidore saith beast first offred altar among nation ramme called aries slaine aaron altar moses law ramme principally cleane beast sacrifice meate offered couenably sinne people cloue footed cheweth cud eaten indifferently people isidore sayth libro 12 sheepe called sometime bidentes among eight téethe commonly haue two téeth higher therefore natious offered principally sacrifice god sayth libro 8 capitulo 47 plinius speaketh singularlye ramme sayth kinde ramme iustines youth noye lambes followe eawes come farre tractiue profitable age neuerthelesse hee ceuell heart ewe cruelnesse abateth horne bée pearced • igh eare righte gendring staue bound gendreth female lesse bounde hee gendreth male gendreth male northerne winde female southerne winde ram haue black veynes vnder toūgs lambes gender colour veynes black vnder toūge lambe shall blacke white lambes ere white speckeled th • lambes arist auicen meaneth looke within de oue ram hath full harde forhead nigh horne feeble temple somewhat gristly therefore defence kéeping féeble parte kinde giueth great horne right hard féeble place temple crooked bended round shell somwhat sharp endes insomuch maye defend head sharpnesse hardnesse horne withstand enimies fighteth sharpnesse horne saith seemly kinde leaue defendour flocke without weapon defence therefore kinde giueth two horne bent circle defend succour owne head féeble selfe bolde hardie aduersaries enimyes trust weapon hée strengthened defended therefore goeth boldly slocke beareth head pitcheth downe foote treadeth strongly ground cloue footed • lées thicke long haire lock defendeth himselfe miuries hot aire colde strong thicke fell skinne therefore one side ram skinne reason strength thereof suffereth sustaineth violent craftes currier parchment maker passing fell skinnes shéepe able receiue hold printing painting diuers colour sayth time loue ram fighteth eawes réeseth horne aduersaries push enemie harder draweth backwarde réeseth leapeth vpward smiteth fiercenesse busheth kinde violence li 8 auicen speaketh rammes saith ram goates buck goe much rain hide themselues winter colde goe sometime hot place colde raineth flye raine vntill dead ram kind follow goate buck rest till heard take one make goe follow soone dread kindly thunder shéepe shéepe lambe heareth thunder casteth hir lamb dread standeth feare sléepe shéepe midnight part chaunge turne side side sléeping springing time haruest sléepe one side vnto springing time sléepe side hold vp head sléepe except sicke chew cud sléeping doe waking happen stray go away come againe hearde bringeth againe isaac dietis saith ram youth bée lesse moyst gleymie sucking lambes age hath mastery ouer complection therefore theyr flesh better flesh lamb eawes gendereth better bloud namely gelded theyr heate tempered accidentall moisture flesh good sauour passe age full olde age fayle heate gelded gelded passe great age heate faileth double cause lacke gendring stone also age therefore body cold dry sticke harde vnsauorie comparison goate ox worst age body ram kindly hot moyst better bodyes beast kindly cold drye great age huc vsque isaac dietis aristotle auicen lib 6 meane ram goate buckes lyke beastes haue nown agnus commeth agnoscendo knowing passing beastes lambe knoweth owne dam insomuch bleate among manye shéepe flocke anone bleating knoweth voyce owne dam auicen aristotle meane lambes yened springing time haruest time winter yened springing time huge great body strongger bodye yened haruest winter country land many men set winter lambes afore lambes springing time meane onely beast profitably yened winter time plin saith li 8 ca 47 ther said lambes conceiued northerne winde better conceiued southern wind male gendered conceiued lambes haue coulour flesh wooll ramme eaw haue colour veines ye tonge veynes white lambes white veynes blacke lambes blacke bée speckeled lambes speckeled sucking time lambe bendeth knées dam giue milke thrnsteth pusheth • dder dam beséecheth dam bleating sawneth taile hath found dam beareth vp head sucketh neuer first areareth vp head hath small wooll crispe manye maner wise folded selfe cold grieueth lambes namely raine wether glad ioyfull company folke cleing forie dreadeth full sore alone lamb hoppeth leapeth flock plaieth dreadeth ful sore séeth woolfe flyeth sodainlye away anone astonied dread stinteth sodaynly dare flye farther prayeth spared bleating simple chéere taken enemie also butcher bind fast defendeth téeth neyther horne spoyled either fell skinne still innocent harmlesse beast whether lead pasture death hée grudgeth prauncheth obedient méeke plinius sayeth perill leaue lambes alone die soone ther fal strōg thunder lambe hath kindly féeble head therefore remedy bring together leite goe together may bolder companye hardy agno anniculo ca 5 agnus anniculus lambe full age one yéere within space one yere better ye farther frō sucking moisture complection increaseth weaning departing milke superfluitie moisture tempered namely yet gelded said openly dietis lamb twelue moneths olde found body cleane flesh able sacrifice meat though speckled flesh wooll speckle flesh reproueth lambe putteth sacrifice stinch corruption flesh skin within glose saith super exod 7 super malac hierome saith super leuiti speck diuersitie speckled flesh letteth sacrifice bodie whole sound without scab skinne plinius saith libro 8 cap 48 lamb yéere old able according alters god vse flesh vse flesh lamb néedfull mankind therfore body neat kept profit mankinde néedeth haue businesse kéeping lambes shéepe diosco saith lambe hath blacke durt shall dissolued tempered vineger made plaister cleanseth away blacke speckes red body helpeth euill men call fire helpeth saueth burning scalding meddeled waxe oyle agna chap 6 female lambe called agna rammes daughter lesse bodye moyst male lambe female complection sayde dietis flesh thereof sucketh glemy supersluitie moystnre commeth age complection hath mastrye bodye therefore gendered flesh thereof fleamatike gleamie hard defie vnneth passing member dested glewie gleamie humour gendered thereof passeth soone downe stomacke slippernesse humour isaac sayth flesh thereof better rosted sod superfluitie thereof moisture consumed wasted strength vertue greate fire female lambes bée simple fearefull male female hath lesser kinde heate male bée cause without horne horne superfluitie female lamb defalt boldnesse hardynesse knowe doe therewith auicen sayth also libro 3 aristotle sayeth lambes haue euill bée fat reines tallowe couereth reines dye tallowe increaseth good pasture therefore lambes put pasture lest waxe fat look within de oue additiōshéepe lambes haue also disease ret happeneth change drie laire brought fennie marsh groundes subiect tike come want pasture cough maggets alce kinde deare called aethiopian bull report alce hath ioynts leggesaddition therefore doth neuer lye leane trée find report gesner truth conlour like fallow deare short broad horned beast right elcke whose hide best buffe made doublet bréeches translated bible english appeareth 14 chapter deu among cleane beast elcke named chaimois camois hebrue called zamer muscouites call lozzos haue vsed one name another farther knowledge gesner folio 2 breed hircania coūtry asia apro chap 7 bore chasit ye hebruethe boare called aper swine liueth woodes flelds cruell milde isidore sayth called aper affer fiercenesse body fierce cruell among ye gréeks boare commonly called fiagres vnderstand fierce cruell called among latines vetres hath greate might strength sayd plinius auicen meane boare fierce beast cruell vnneth hée tamed made milde though hée gelded though beast mild time gelded also bore fierce beast also cruell fiercenesse cruelnesse hée despiseth setteth naught death réeseth full pitcously point yt speare hunter though smitten sticked speare bodye yet great ire cruelnesse heart hée hath réeseth enimy taketh comfort heart strength worke himselfe aduersarye tuskes putteth himselfe perill death wonderous fiercenesse weapon enimy hath mouth two crooked tuskes right strong sharp breaketh renteth cruellye hee withstandeth vseth tuskes steed swoord hath hard sheld broad thicke right side putteth alway weapon pursueth vseth brawne stéed sheeld defend himselfe spieth perill shoulde befall hée whetteth tusk froteth trées assaieth froting trées point tuskes blont féele blont séeketh hearb called origanum gnaweth cheweth cleanseth comforteth rootes teeth therewith vertue therof auicen saith li 28 ca 10 plinius sayeth vrine boare medicine euills ye eares meddeled oyle rose also gall helpeth stone sayde libro 38 cap 40 vrine heauye himselfe hée may arise hée pisse holden downe though hée dead sayde vrine burneth ¶also sayth gall boare exciteth gendring also saith lib 5 field swine lencth well root wroteth diggeth earth wroteth vp rootes cutteth tusk waxeth fat hath rested seuen day namely drinke little boare fighteth woulfe hateth kinde ye woulfe lieth waite pig stealeth full oft therefore saith lib decimo quarto kind giueth boare tuskes desende female pigges female féeble themselues male worse complection male bolde mightye female female fierce whē wroth grieueth hurteth digging froting biting renting téeth tuskes boare hurteth tusk striking vpward yt cause may hurt lieth ground female grieueth little stand boare wroth fretteth soameth mouth doth gendereth female plinius rehearseth foresayd thing saith thereto lib 8 cap 2 sayth egedius sayeth boares swine bée farrowed toothed also boares sharpe fierce loue bite cruellye sowes dig cratch earth theyr clawes set vp bristle whet tuskes smite therewith shew woodnesse brest horrible groning grunting eate little goe runne female therfore right leane boares goe valley darke dwell woodes kéepe theyr child liue rootes fruit wild trées espie saute hunter réeses wolues go young maye flye put perill theyr young harden theyr shéeldes froating trées shal fight wrap durt drie themselues sunne make durt hard fast among haire may surely beare susteine stroke enimies fighting libro 6 aristotle sayeth female sowes boares haue farrowed bée full sharpe cruell rent come nigh young cruell biting huc vsque plinius isaac sayth boares flesh harde drye cold tame porke continuall moouing drye meate drye ayre hot ayre alwaye within grease fat harde flesh lyking eating therfore tame bore strongly chased tied also beaten slaine theyr flesh may tender sauoury strong moouing dioscorides speaketh boare sayth durt dronk wine water singular remedye cast bloud helpeth sore side medled vineger souoreth strengthneth broken bone looke within de porco asino chap 3 asse called asinus hath name sedendo sitting beast sit vpon men sate rode vppon ass vsed horse ride vpon isidore saith libro 17 simple beast slow therfore soone ouercome subiect man seruice else name asinus commeth hauing synos yt wit beast without wit asinus commeth asellus lyttle young asse fayre shape disposition young tender passe age elder asse fouler waxeth day daye hairie rough melancholyke beast cold drye therefore kindlye heauie slow vnlustie dull witlesse forgetfull neuerthelesse beareth burden may away trauaile thraldome vseth vile meat little gathereth meate among brier thornes thistle therefore auicen saith libro 8 aristotle sayeth also small bird nestleth bush thornes brier hate asse therefore small sparrowes fighteth asse asse eateth thornes ye sparowes make theyr neasts also asse rubbeth froieth flesh thorn bird egges sparowes falleth ye neast ground asse reareth heaueth vp head strong blast thornes mooueth shaketh great noyse birdes afearde full sore falleth neast therfore bréed bird suffereth leap face asse bite smite réese eyen billes asse haue wouude scab ridge side pricking thornes wise sparows leapeth asse pecketh bill wound sore asse passe frō neasts though sparow full lyttle yet vnneth may asse defend himselfe réese pricking biting aristotle sayeth doth auicen also ranen hateth full much asse therefore rauen flyeth aboue asse laboureth bill peck eyen déepnes eien helpeth thē asse thicknes hardnes skin therewith asse closeth eyen healeth sight defendeth réesing pricking foules also long eares moouing thereof helpeth therewith hée fearesh smal bird réese peck eyen also libro 8 aristotle sayeth beare fighteth asse bull eateth rawe flesh cause fighteth desireth eate flesh libro 18 cap vit plinius speaketh asse sayth smoak ass hoofe helpeth birth childe insomuch bringeth dead childe shall otherwise layde slayeth quicke childe bée oft layde lyeth long time new dirt beast stauncheth bloud wonderfullye lyuer holpeth falling euill child libro 28 cap 10 plinius sayeth ass milke ass bloud helpeth biting scorpion men saye yt man looketh ass eare smit scorpion anone mallice passeth also venimous thinges flieth smoake ass liuer also eodem cap 9 said ass milk helpeth venimous plaister mallice seruse quicke siluer also li 9 ass bone brused stamped sad helpeth agaynst venimme broath therof dronken vrine male asse nardus kéepeth saueth maketh much haire libro 8 cap 44 plinius sayeth asse beast maye worst awaye colde bréedeth therefore colde countryes land bréedeth pontus therefore ari saith though asse full colde dry yet ful lecherous moued gendring ere 30 moneths olde though due worke gendering yet gendereth broode ere hee full thrée yéere olde plinius sayth birth asse idlenesse 30 moneths lawfull profitable thrée yeare also aristotle saith li 5 plinius saith thereto asse foaleth selde two coltes female shall foale flyeth light séeketh darke place seene loueth foale much passeth fire come foale ye asse breadeth full sore passe ouer water scrapeth therein compelled must needes passe ouer water riuer wadeth therein pisseth therein asse passeth gladlye may sée water plankes hath féeble braine soone grudged dreadeth therefore falleth chinnes bridge water séeth running vnder asse drinketh gladly small well vsed may come drie footed wonder tell yt though asse sore thirst water bée changed vnneth drinketh thereof like water wont drinke plinius li 28 cap 7 sayth female asse eateth barlye wet menstruall bloud manye graines shée eateth wet many yeres afterward shall conceiue mule gendered betwéene asse mare gendering mare chosen passe age foure yeare ten yeare gender alwaye either beast two manner kind one gendered betwéene horse asse betwéene asse mare one kinde withdraweth ye fed together youth one manner milke therefore said heardes desire haue mule burdones gendered diuers kindes beast vse crafte bring forth young coltes mare set darkenesse teates ass féede ass milke horse colt age bée mooued time gendering gender ass also lykewise ass coltes set sucke teates mare fed mare milke colt gender mare age gendering betwéene asse mare commeth beast called ninnulus olde time tall beast gendered burdus call beast gendered betwéene asse mare mule libro 15 aristotle sayeth asse gendereth mare full fat conception mare corrupted coldnesse semen asse semen asse cold kinde matter matter mare hot therfore whē hot meddeled colde meddeling tempered therof may come conception colt may saued yt gendered betwéene horse female asse also likewise colt yt gendered betwéene horse mare hée asse mare mule gendereth colde naturall complection horse asse hath mastrye mule therefore mule gendereth another beast hée saith also saith yt asse gendereth asse afterwarde hee maketh cast colt cause therof auicen saith coldnesse semen asse cōmeth corrupteth destroyeth temperatnesse first semen semen asse cold complection brought temperatnesse kind heat ye male horse semen female asse yt colde kind complection coldnes ye kinde female strength therofthe first temperatnesse commeth ye hot semen horse colde semen asse cause euery female mule barren auicen saith male asse yt father mule passing cold complection mare mother yt hot heat horse kind therfore though heat semen mother mare tempereth cold semen asse beast may bée gendered yet beast yt gendered coldnesse father mother abideth hath mastry therein disposeth kindly barrennesse manner asse called indicus asinus onager ye vnicorne •• writer assume hath horne middle ye forehead whole footed foure euerye beast hath two horne cloue footed therefore asse indicus hath horne cloue footed aristotle saith lib 2 euerye cloaue footed beast hath horne againeward horned cloue footed fareth bul sheepe hart aristotle sayth libro 7 aristotle sayth asse mule horse eateth fruit hearbes grasse fatted water loue thick water cléere cow loueth better cléere water thicke also lib codem aristotle sayth part ass waxe sick one manner sicknesse called milide sicknesse first head hot fleame runneth noseand falleth lung asse dieth beast flyeth colde beast found country north ioynts ridge boane strong asse stronger bound sinewes behind reines therfore ass beare heauy burthen behinde reines shoulder euennesse day night springing time asse mooued lethery roreth exciteth female loue dreadfull roring stron • draweth breath winde bringeth odour smell female nose drawing thereof desire lerherye burneth plinius saith asse hath another wretched condition knowen nigh men put trauaile ouer night beaten staues sticked pricked prickes mouth wrong bernacle lead hether thether withdrawne léese pasture way oft refraining bernacle dyeth last vaine trauailes hath reward death seruice trauaile liuing much owne skinne left taken awaye carren throwen without sepulture burialls much carren eating deuouring somtime buried wombes houndes wolues angue chap 9 kinde serpentes adder kinde may wrappe folde owne body called anguis hath name hath many corner angle folding goeth neuer straight isidore sayth libro 12 anguis called serpens créepeth priuy pace créepeth wt smal pace yt hid folding sliding withdrawing scale accounted among créeping wormes additiō whereof came prouerb anguis latit herba snake vnder leaues wrath ye hart créepeth brest womb isi saith li 12 called also colluber either dwelleth shadowe glideth slipper bending wrinklings draught adder slideth held adder many manner kind slaieth felt dieth venim féeleth sore poet lucan sayth signiferum iuuenem tureni sanguinis album torta caput retro dipsas calcata remordit vix dolor aut sensus dentis fuit c dispas serpent wrast owne white head backward bit young baneret turenis bloud vnneth felt biting sore sayth isidore also tirus least adder yet aristotle saith lib 7 vnneth remedie found biting also serpentes adder diuerse disposition figure shape haue two head adder amphisibena isidore speaketh libro 12 sayth amphisibena hath name hath two head one one ende another ende runneth glideth wrigleth wrinkle corcels draught body either head among serpent onelye serpent putteth himselfe cold putteth himselfe goeth also lib 8 cap 14 plinius sayth sayth amphisibena hath double head though one mouth little cast venimme also serpent haue many head doubled trebled quatrebled isidore sayth idra serpent many head one séene marreys prouince archadia sayde one head smit thrée growe againebut fable perfectly knowen idra place casted vp water wasted destroyed citie nigh idra head ye streame stopped many head streames break hercules séeing burned ye place stopped wayes water therefore said hercules kill idra serpent fiue heades isidore sayth libro 12 also serpent varie diuerse coulours blacke redde serpent tyrus bée worst speckled serpent scytale shineth diuersitie speckle looketh thereon wonder speckle hath lyking looke thereon slow créeping wonder diuersitie speckle catcheth yt maye followe going créeping diuers coulours speckle worse venime venime accounted sharpe hot serpent hot feruent winter time skinnes hath chaunged feruent hot bée body héereof lucanus speaketh sayth et scytale sparsis etiam nunc sola pruinis exuujas positura suas frost nigh serpent changeth skinne isid saith c also ophites serpent painted diuers speckle hath many manner wise noy gréene hath diuerse colour distinct heereof speaketh lucanus saith manner serpent ophites hath many manner burning gréeuings hath speckle coulours painted burning speckle also serpent diuerse diuersitie stéede place lurke den earth sicketh pouder dust sucketh humour ground plinius saith water adder dwell brimmes water serpent enidris water adder smitten adder hée swelleth dropsie many men call boua durt ore remedy therefore isido sayth lib 8 also natrix adder hath name infecteth venim well commeth nigh lucanus sayth saith natrix insecteth water isidore sayth libro 7 serpent dwell wood den shadowye plate hunt small birdes beastes sucke moisture thereof aristotle sayth libro 14 serpent adder lye awaite sleepe find mouth open beast créepe loue heate humour finde adder little beast fighteth called saura litle euete men meane lyzard beast saura ware serpent present leapeth vpon face ye sléepeth cratcheth féet wake warne serpent auicen saieth little beast saura isidore saith libr 12 eute waxeth olde eien waxeth blind hée goeth hole wall east openeth eyen afterwarde sun risen eien heateth taketh light manner serpent dwell fire fareth salamandra yt isidore plinius account among venimous beastes salamandra hath name isidore saith libro 12 strong mightie burning among venimous beast might venime venimous beast n • yeth one one noyeth slayeth many créepe trée infecteth ye apple slayeth eate therof falleth pit slayeth drinke water venim beast contrary burning among beast onely beast quencheth fire lieth burning fire wtout consumption wasting also smarting ach burneth fire abateth swageth burning thereof isidore sayth plinius accordeth therewith point libro 10 cap 47 saith salamandra like ewte shape neuer séene much raine falleth faire wether touch colde quencheth fire ise doth casteth mouth white matter touching wherof man body leeseth haire touched therewith chaungeth tourneth foulest coulour also bée diuerse manner going passing créep glide awaye wiggeling crookedly alway stretch goe forth right isidore sayth libro 17 bée sayth cenchris serpent bendeth neither wiggeleth holdeth alway right foorth lucanus sayeth serpent eateth gladlye flesh sucketh gladly moisture therof spinner sucketh flyes serpent swalloweth egges bird bird liue haue swallowed bring hinder end putteth suffereth abide wombe also libro 2 aristotle sayeth gut serpent lyke gut foure footed beastes laye egges haue gendering stone haue wayes fish haue mother long diuided theyr bowelles gut bée long length body tongue serpent blacke long thin clouen twaine sharpe moue farre therefore moue easily wombe serpent long straight lyke large gut gut lykened hoands gut hath womb lyttle gut stretcheth vnto passing superfluitie hath lyttle heart nigh vnto neck like kidney sight heart lung subtill partes sinewie krindled hangeth downward heart long liuer long straight therevpon gall flesh lesse gall vppon gut serpent splene little rounde téeth deale sharpe crooked ioyned together bée departed téeth sawe serpent hath thirtie ribbes number dayes moneth sayd yt serpent fare swallowes birdes eyen bée put yet sight commeth againe taile serpent groweth againe bée cut taile ewt also serpent haue egges first within layeth afterwarde one one egges beastes gendered except serpent called tyrus vipera also arist saith li 3 tyrus serpent gendereth beastes within shée hath first egges within egges beast bred within therefore said yt mother serpent long making body mother beginneth ye nether part passeth vp either side ridge boane diuided two partes hath wall interclose betweene two partes therefore two egges set arowe mother serpent layeth egges also lib 5 aristotle saith yt tune gendering serpent wrappeth clippeth themselues together séeme one body two head knowen haue séene also libr 7 aristotle sayeth serpent namelye tyrus swalloweth birde ought else first areareth himselfe afterward restrayneth himselfe vntil thing swalloweth passe inward stomacke little smal serpent may liue long without meate knowen serpent kept sell also aristotle lib 8 telleth wéesell sighteth serpent armeth himselfe eating rewe fighteth namely serpent yt eate micea snake wéesell hunteth eateth mouse also li 7 saithno difference heere betvveene snake c adder ye serpentes lone well wine bée therefore hunted wine also serpent loueth passing well milke followeth sauour thereof therfore serpent crept mannes wombe may drawen odour smell milke saith dioscorides also libro 14 aristotle sayth serpent haue propertye may moue head backwarde resting bodye cause therof ioynts ridge boane gristle therefore full plyaunt needfull serpent may bende head backward sée long body small else might rule body holpe rearing head rule wisely body also serpent swimme water wiggeling folding bodye creepe ground kinde giueth serpentes goe vppon féete sinnes swimme cause therof great length 〈2 page missing〉 body many féet shuld moue full euill foot also many finnes set nigh together shuld moue heuily wer set far sunder wer sufficient susteine beare vp ye deale body yt long pliant therefore fish doe haue fin drawing clitching fin foules bird clitching spreading wing serpent bending weigling pliantnes body fish like serpent length cause haue fewe fin swimmeth euenly pliantnesse ye body lampraies conger eles mannee fish like serpent making haue onely two fin vse onely pliantnesse body stéede fin wing creepe therefore vpon grounde liueth long time without water serpent doe without meat also idem eodem serpent haue wayes gut somtime superfluitie passeth body beast haue ye gender haue way vrine without bladder item eodem serpent found wrapped together come together loue haue yarde gendering stone bee without yard bitings gréekes call venim yos isidore sayth libro 12 capit 4 followeth adder called aspis bée diuers manner kind haue diuerse effect dooings noy grieue wit dipsas called scytula latine biteth slayeth altogether serpent destroieth renteth onely bodye also destroyeth venim wasteth bone sinewes poet sheweth manner ossaque dissoluens cum corpore tabificus sep ceps slaieth vndoeth destroyeth body bone inchaunter come denne charmes comurations hath come laieth one eare ye ground stoppeth ye taile heareth voice charming commeth ye charmeth obedient saieng huc vsque isidorus plinius libro 8 capitulo 24 speaketh adder aspis sayth member bée smit adder swell vnneth remedie found heale biting without cutting partes bee touched flyeng adder venimous hath wit loue affection loueth make loue wedlocke liueth well without companye therefore one slaine pursueth flewe busie wreake vengeaunce passeth thinking knoweth slaier reefeth neuer great company men people busieth slay passeth difficulty space wayes wreake sayd death make let put swift flight water riuers mallice kind giueth remedye medicine kinde giueth right dimme sight eyen set side head set forehead therefore may see aduersarye foorth right aside therefore hee maye follow enimy sight followeth hearing smell two wit strong mightie sayth also marcianus saith adder aspis grieueth men affrica moore take childrē yt haue suspect put adder child kind adder aspis grieueth thē kinde anone dyeth venim adder plinius sayth expresly lib 6 cap vltimo saith sometime beast grieueth men land slaieth straungers men land serpent spare wonderfully men yt borne land serpent anguis riuer euphrates gréeueth hurteth men lande noyeth sleepe lande paine slay busily men nation nation euery also plinius saith aristotle sayth certaine mountaine scorpion grieue stranger sting slay men countrey additiō aspis little serpent affrike whose sting curable onelye water stone washed take sepulchre auncient king c cooper aranea chap 11 venimous spinner called aranea worme hath name feeding nourishing aire isidore sayth li 12 spinneth long thrids short time alway busie weauing ceaseth neuer trauaile hath oft harme worke oft web worke broken blast wind el dropping tame looseth trauaile auicen sayth spinner little créeping beast many foot hath sixe feete eight hath alwaye feete euen odde verye needfull going possing alway euen charge burthen generall haue two féete moe haue féete longer shorter diuerse workes make féete make thridde small drawe long knit thrids together right amende thrids hooue web among beast rounde bodyes spinner hath best féeling touch hoouing middle webbe hee feeleth sodeynly flye farthest parte thereof réeseth sodeinly flie enimye hée haue mastrye flye hée win beth wrappeth flily among threds web escape falleth first head sucketh moysture thereof lyueth hunting fly humour flyes lyking taste honnie lyking taste baes sayth aristotle also also kinde spinner diuersity male female aristotle saieth lib 5 female bodye male hath longer feete plyant able mouing weauing time gendring loue female draweth hir male threds web thereafter male draweth female drawing ceaseth vntill bee ioyned togethers male set vpon wombe female manner néedefull roundnesse wombe ioyning togethers ende springing time beginning summer sometime haruest beginning winter spinner grieuous theyr biting venemous also libro 8 aristotle saith spinner many kindes small diuers colour sharp swifte moaing blacke coulour theyr hinder leg long slowe mouing onely goe worke generation ofte blacke spinner inhabite ground among hole dennes abide web vntill little beast fall therein flye taketh sucketh moysture thereof hungred putteth flye certaine place kéepeth vntill hungred againe hath sucked moysture throweth awaye deale surneth againe hunting hunteth ere haue amended breath webbe one breake webbe beginneth amend going downe sunne rising sun trauaileth many lyttle wormes fall web female bringeth forth hir brood male hunteth helpeth hir hideth hir selfe vnder web séene small wormes namely great hir greatnesse worketh easely female layeth first egs thereof afterward shapen small spinner mother setteth weane anone hatcht moue anon dispese themselues therto weaue haue learned weaue hunt mother wombe young spinner arayeth anon net according pray manner kinde spinner hunteth little ewte they• finde begin weane vppon binde strongly mouth leap vpon sting till dyeth item eodem saith spinner founde bée hiues spinner corrupt honie sucke lycour make webbes honnie combes corrupte auicen sayth plinius also de generatione araneae libro 11 capit 25arane kinde spinner worthye chiefe wondering manye manner kindes among certaine manner kind called spalangio phalangium bodye thereof little speckeled diuers colour sting swifte leaping grieuous biting another spinner bodyatocius blacke coulour long legges weaueth dennes ground thirde kinde cunning working weaueth full subtyll webbes greate wonder howe matter thriddes come wombe spinner may indure greate worke weauing greate webbe drawen men thinke spinner wombe yet vnneth founde voyde séemeth bée true democritus sayd much corruption wombe spinner dirte much matter thred might therefore arist reproueth democritus lib 8 saith said true poynt reason séemeth spinner round beast little meates default bloud beate saith spinner taketh much meate without comparison cōmeth weaue web superfluity dirte meate foode taketh superfluitie dirte néedfull digestion due kéeping sauing beast aristotle saith also plinius saith sayth spin threds rounde long moderate feete clawes stretch warpe wonderfull craft neather side ouer drawe bring againe thred thwart ouer point poynt straight draughtes small space betwéen ye threds couple knit threds middle lyke farre middle poynt worke drawen layd beginneth middle poynt goeth round ofe maketh knottes hole like farre asunder hole space betwéen wonderfull crafte ye knot made foure cornerd euenlong round néerer bée middle narrow bée straight farther middle large wide sight séeth vnneth iudgement reson perceiueth wherby spinner reyneth thred thred knitteth fast knot knot reareth himselfe wonderfull lyghtnes owne threds small vnneth séene man eyen yet passeth web swiftlye though flew hether thether place place also saith long vtter threds web dure hap web broken maner wise spinner beginneth middle amend broken though would holde nothing whole sound webbe middle sure also saith spinner token diuination knowing wether shall fall ofte weather shal fal spin weue higher lower also saith ye multitude spinner token much raine also li 14 cap 3 de lesione ficuum saith somtime spinner weaue make web aboute burgening bud vine also flower blossomes trées compassing cobweb trées vine lost burgen bloome biting spinner called spalangio venemous slaieth except remedie succour sooner vertue plantaine slayeth venyme thereof laid thereto due manner therefore wormes eutes frog dread stinging spinner defende themselues iuyce plantaine plinius saieth dioscorides auicen capitulo de venenis c macer saith aristotle plinius meane web spinner come gut manner cratte kinde web wouen subtill working wonderfully knit net wise made smallest threds séene flyes wormes laied séene threds great cobweb made trauayle businesse wonderfully soone destroyed vndone may sustaine fire spinner dread winde blaste winde cobweb soone broken vnknit though spinner venemousspiders doe care ovvne kinde haue seene one spider fight kill another yet web commeth ye gut thereof venemous accounted full good profitable vse medicine dioscorides saith cobweb white cleane defiled filth powder hath vertue constraine ioyne restrayne therefore stauncheth bloud runneth wound keepeth matter rotting healeth new wound layd therto withstandeth swelling ye tarieth heting wound maner spinner called spalana pli saith li 29 cap 4 spinner lyke ant much bodye hath red head deale body black sprong white speck smiting bitter sore biting serpent vipera spinner liueth nigh furnace ouens milles remedie biting smiting shewe bitten smitten another spinner kinde therefore kept found dead skinne thereof stamped dronke medicine biting wesell also another spinner rough great head sorenesse ache stinging ache sorenesse scorpion biting knées shake fayleth also biting commeth blyndnes spewing another manner spinner called mirmicaleon mirmiceon called another name formicaleon like ante white head aud hath blacke bodye white speckes biting paineth aketh stinging waspes called formicaleon hunteth ant sucketh moysture sparrowes foules deuoure ant biting spinner remedie braine capon dronke swéete wine little peppernote congealing lambe wine healeth biting spinner doth ash ram cloe honie also flyes wing able flye ordayne watch manner castle rest night vntill daye till one bée wake thē twice buzzing thrice manner trumping flye daye faire morrowe diuine ware rayne winde holde theyr house know ware hand faire weather passe foorth theyr worke swarme companye gather flower feete water theyr mouthes beare drop together roughnes body younger goeth worke beginneth thinges elder worketh home flower bring first charge fore féete afterward hinder féet vntil turne home againe mouth full fully charged receiue charged manner thrée foure dischargeth ordayned home theyr office diuers make house cleanse make fayre hiue dresse meate brought home eate asunder least vncleannesse meate worke among make combes ordinately lyne hang aboue certaine thing holdeth vndersetteth shall fall putteth lyttle stone may stedfast blastes winde heauinesse stone among wonderfull obseruaunce discipline lore one marketh taketh héed worke chastiseth anone slaieth worke among wonderfull great cleannesse suffer long roddes small tough compasse wind horne beast beast tyed held striueth praunceth long therewith striueth winding fastening roddes faster faster bound holden hath long striuen yet maye delyuer great bull lyke bull hath haire shad either side necke fareth haire horse haire • rōre softer horse haire shorter haired continually vnto eyen deale redde citrine voyce lyke voyce bull horne deale much dirte aristotle sayth auicen also ¶of basilisco cap 16 cockatrice called basiliscus gréeke regulus latine hath name regulus litle king king serpent afeard flye sée slayeth smell breathe slayeth also thing hath lyfe breathe sight sight fowle birde passeth harmelesse though farre foule yet burnt deuoured mouth ouercome wesel men bring wesell cockatrice denne wherin hée lurketh hidde father maker thing lefte nothing without remedy cockatrice flieth séeth wesell wesell pursueth slayeth cockatrice halfe foote long hath white speckes cockatrice slayeth commeth nigh scorpion water hée aethyopes well many men suppose head nylus beside wilde beast called catobletas hath lyttle body nice al member great head hanging alway toward earth el great noyeng mankinde sée eyen dye anone kinde hath cockatrice serpent bred prouince syrena hath bodye length breadth cockatrice tayle twelue inch long hath specke head precious stone feareth away serpent hissing presseth bodye much bowing course way forth right goeth meane dryeth burneth leaues hearbes onely touche also hissing blast rotteth corrupteth thing aboute great venime perillous slayeth wasteth yt commeth nigh length speare without tarrieng yet wesell taketh ouercommeth pleaseth god kindly thing without peere biting wesell death ye cockatrice neuerthelesse biting cockatrice death wesell yt sure except ye wesel eat rew venime aristotle sayth auicen first wesell eateth hearb row though bitter vertue iuyce hearb goeth boldly obey commeth enemie though cockatrice venomous without remedy alway yet léeseth mall • ce burnt ash ash accounted good profitable workeing alkamie namely turning changing mettall additiōthe basiliske cockatrice among créeping wormes pestilent among men pestilent minded spoiler clergie vnconscionable rage many minister haue bene forced leaue lyuings go begging tituled clemencie gospell become oppression god bring shortly confusion basiliskes pliny time self haue bene plagued speak hearbes kéepeth holdeth alway venime sighteth common spinner spinner called spalangio ouercommeth venime biting benefise plantaine venime accounted cold stonieth therefore member toucheth maketh lesse feeling froze venemous beast comforteth therefore himselfe touching touched swelleth manye speekes hath vnder wombe many manner wise venimme accompted grieuous hath eyen though site shining worse burning sight though hath cléere eyen yet haleth ye light sunne séeketh darke place flyeth dennes sunne riseth beames shineth vpon earth froggs loueth swéete hearbs eateth rootes eating infecteth corrupteth rootes hearbes • therefore ofte gardene rew set venime enemye eoades venemous wormes vertue rew chased away may come hearbes rootes growe therein toade loueth stinking place dir • ie • hateth place good smell odour sayd flyeth vineyard vine begin bloome maye suffer sustaine theyr good odour smell libro tricesimo capitulo 4 plinius speaketh toad sayth manner right venemous frogges isidore sayth libro 12 charged bowe lye downe méeke charge méeke short called caine gréeke el haue name camur gréeke crooked take charge vpon b • nde crooke knées also camelles bée beast beare charge burthen milde softe ordayned beare charge cartage men bée found many countryes landes namely arabia camells arabia diuers camel landes camell arabia hath two bounches backe camell another lande hath one bounche backe isidore saith eodem libro 8 capitulo 19 plinius saieth manner cast féedeth camells among tame beastes camells two manner kindes bactria arabia camell arabia hath two bounches backe camell bactria hath one backe beareth burthen another breast leaneth thereon camells soothlesse aboue ox chew cudde ox shéepe isidore sayth libro 12 cloue footed shall sayde héereafter full swifte plinius sayth therefore good battayle warre beare charge cariage camell goeth daye wont doe taketh burthen wont beare camell hateth horse kinde suffreth thirst foure dayes stirreth water feete drinketh el drink doth good camell liueth fiftie yeare hundred yeare wereth mad sometime camells gelded ordained battaile warre stronger put worke generation huc vsque plinius auicen speketh camel maner camel saith moueth first ye right soote lyon doth onelye camell hath hunch backe choi •• footed hath fell clifts fareth goose foote cleft fleshly ye rielies bear • e foot therefore men maketh thē shooes least foot hurt bée tender beneath sometime camelles heart bone found heart hart camell hath foure teates two vaders ye row hath female camell boweth selfe goeth knées shée wilt coupled male talent desire strong feruent time loue eateth little desireth alway bée assayled male nigh place shée first assailed arist saith li 5 one propertie camells solitary alone mountain time loue man may come nigh yt time heard alone camells yard sinewy full hard therefore men make bow string yardes item ibidem eodem camells haue certaine time ordeined worke generation female nourisheth colt wombe 12 moneths ingender thrée yéere olde rest yéere louing also sayth libro 8 certaine manner camells bée gelded able flie saith camells swifter horse large pase wide héereof look within de dromedatio aristotle sayth lib 9 cap 17 camell doth woorke generation owne mother certaine citie camell héeled mantell owne sonne leape falling cloth couered hée knew owne mother though hée déede hée leaped downe slew man beguiled aristotle setteth ensample like horse certaine king also libr 11 cap 37 plinius speaketh camells saieth among foure footed beast camells ware bald men estridge certeine beast among foules also saith among beast without horne camelles bée toothlesse ouer iawe accord therfore téeth beast yt chew cud disposition wombe horn ari li 14 sayth yt beast eateth thorny matter hath yt wombe camell hard horned beast hath u téeth either iaw therefore camell hath teeth either iaw onely beneath though hornelesse néedeth camel wombe disposition like womb beastes toothlesse ouer iawe making téeth like making téeth horned beastes followeth camells meate thorny hard néedeth tongue fleshie hardnesse palat therefore kinde vset palat earthy part téeth therfore camell cheweth cud horned beast wound like wombe horned beast hée taketh meate first wombe vndigest second wombe meat beginneth defie better defied third womb fourth wombe full digestion compleate diuersitie wombes néedful hardnesse meat grindeth cheweth meate little teeth li 13 aristotle sayth yt camell hath gall distinguished vpon yt liuer elephant hath matter liuer full whole sound bloud kindlye sweete beastes gall found found full small veines therefore olde men sayde anaxagoras sayth camells beast long lyfe gallesse beastes lyttle gall liue longer beast much gall therefore anaxagoras sayde gall cause sharpe sickness gall multiplyed vnto lung shedde partes bodye aristotle sayth false many beast gall found haue ryght sharpe sicknesse sometime euills slaye fareth camelles haue podagre phrensie podagree foot strained euil slaieth sometime bée neuerthelesse without gall vt dicit ibidem huc v que aristoti also dietis vniuersalibus constant speaketh camell sayth yt camell hottest beast kind therefore leane kinde heat draweth fatnesse bloud therefore camell leane camells milke thin milke beast lesse vnctuous lesse nourishing heating opening departing milke nought else bloud oft sodde therefore camelles milke fall sauour sharpe tempereth therefore humour maketh thin cow milke contrarye thereto thicke vnctuous nourisheth much looke property within de dro • nedatio cameleoperdo cap 20 cameleoperdus called cameleoperdalis also beast aethiopia isidore sayth libro 12 plinius libro 8 cap 30 hath head camell necke horse legges foot bull speck perde beast befprong white speckes distinguished bright colour cléere called cameleoperdalis hath head camell speckes perde plinius sayth beast worth sight fiercenesse milde soft almost name sheepe sayth beast clene meat moses lawe sacrifice cloue footed bul cheweth cudde camell therefor lawfull eate thereof written deut 14 c additiōthe aethiopians call beast nabis necke lyke horse féete lyke oxe head lyke camel spotted redde loftie low behinde camelion cap 21 camelion lyttle beast diuerse coulours bodye chaungeth full soone diuerse coulours hée sayth also another beast founde taketh also chaunging contrarye coulours isidore sayth auicen meaneth camelion stellio lusard one shineth starre chaungeth coulours fearefull beast lyttle bloud chaungeth therefore coulours foure manner diuers hath face ewte sharpe clawes crooked bodye sharpe harde skinne crocodile libro secundo aristotle sayth camelion beast lyke ewte body side bée euenlong neather partes wombe fish ridge boanes bounch vpwarde fish face beast compowned swine ape tayle full long small end féete crooked little ewte féet departed twaine comparison one foot another comparison thombe man deale hand two partes diuided finger clawes like claw bird bodye rough sharpe bodye bardan eyen bée déepe great round conteined skinne lyke skinne body skinne couereth eyen turneth casteth oft eien hether thether chaungeth coulour skinne blowen colour somewhat blacke black speckle therin diuersitie al bodie namely eyen also tayle full heauie moouing foule colour death body little flesh hath little bloud head ende taile hath little bloud also heart veines come therefrom also hath bloud eien though right little braine nighe eyen bodye bée departed two abideth working spirite thereof lyttle moouing abideth bodye splenenesse dwelleth dennes ewte huc vsque aristotle libro vicesimo octauo plinius sayth camelion beast like crocodile varyeth therefrom onely crookednesse back longnesse tayle beast accounted fearefull camelion changeth therfore colour might strength kinde goshaukes hée draweth flie taketh wilfully beast deuoured democritus sayth head throate set fire oaken woode maketh raine thunder plinius scorneth saieng beast euer accounted among clene beast super leui 11 isichius saith sicknesse feyneth himselfe soft milde though cruell said camelion liueth onely aire mole earth hearring water cricket fire vearses meane quatuor ex puris vitam ducunt elementis rounde may kept aboue fourtéene dayes without putting forth aire caprea cap 22 wilde goate called caprea hath name carpendo gathering thereof isidore speaketh libro 12 saith called capri capree gather braunches twig men meane haue ye name climbe vpon hard crag meane haue name noyse make legges wilde goates called caprie sée sharplye gréekes call dorko • dwell high mountaines sée hunter come farre headlong high cragges saue themselues harmelesse theyr owne horne called also dame damule papias sayth looke within litrea de damula also beast caprea wild goate swifte running light leaping sharpe goat voideth sorrow woe capriolo cap 23 capriolus auicen sayth lyke hynnulus hinde calfe beast chaungeth téeth one may perceiue hath greate téeth token long life also long continuance beast capriolus hath right fayre pleasaunt eyen also sharpe also libro 8 aristotle affirmeth saith beast caprioli haue wit wounded séeke hearbe pulegium cerinum pennie royall ease thereof drawe arrowes theyr bodye sticke therein businesse running swiftnesse mouing flesh discharged superfluitie moisture flesh made tender better defie better sauour smell heuie sauour thereof taken away constant sayth get meate flight pursued valley fieldes hée taketh course flyeth high place mountaines mountaynes iude bée caprioli cateth hearbes good smell sauour theyr féete certaine hollownesse certayne humour bée gathered goates horne wooll burnt remedy goates horne diuerse manner kinde venim ouercome superfluitie dead flesh fretted freshe flesh new gendered passing running humour staunched helpe rotted woundes fretting gnawing haue remedy though cankered festered new goat skinnes wound holpe healed goat bloud medled mery sod excludeth poyson venimme biting créeping wormes smiting scorpion saued healed hot lung goat laid venimous biting draweth venimme abateth ach sorenesse gal putteth away dimnesse eyen fresteth webbes pearles sharpneth sight cléereth eyen goat liuer roasted helpeth lepra oft taken meatrand dirt helpeth many sickness euills sayth goates durt helpeth haue podagre tallow goat buck medled ye iuyce iute goates vrine heated dropped luke warme eares healeth eares ake setteth property biting knowledge trespasse fault also reade garamantus king came exiling brought two hundered houndes fought agaynst enimies wonderfull hardynesse also iasons hounde cilicie would take meate lorde slaine hée dyed greate hunger sorrowe also read ye celius senator placencia defended hound yt ouerset men armes 〈…〉 wounded till hound slayne sabinus hound forsooke neither prison death abode dead
